section.title: Introduction
section.p: Sections 1. and 2. discuss the taxation of domestic income of resident companies. The taxation of foreign income of resident companies is discussed in section 7.2., and the taxation of non-resident companies in section 7.3.

section.title: Geographical jurisdiction
section.p: The geographical jurisdiction of Finnish tax legislation is defined in chapter 1 of the Income Tax Law (Tuloverolaki; Inkomstskattelagen; TVL). Generally, resident taxpayers are subject to tax on their global income and non-residents are taxed on income originating from Finland, if listed in sections 9 and 10 of the TVL.

According to domestic law, Finland covers the mainland and the province of Åland. For national income tax purposes, the province of Åland is part of Finland, but it has the right to levy its own provincial and municipal taxes.

section.title: Statutory framework
section.p: The main income tax law for companies is the Business Income Tax Law (Laki elinkeinotulon verottamisesta; Lag om beskattning av inkomst av näringsverksamhet; EVL). The net business income of all types of taxpayers is determined thereunder. If the Business Income Tax Law does not contain a relevant provision, then generally the Income Tax Law (TVL) is applied. Both laws apply to companies and individuals. The Law on Tax Procedure (Laki verotusmenettelystä/Lag om beskattningsförfarande, VML) and the Law on Tax Procedure for Self-Assessed Taxes (Laki oma-aloitteisten verojen verotusmenettelystä/Lag om beskattningförfarandet beträffande skatter som betalas på egen initiative, OVML), which entered into force on 1 January 2017, contain important provisions on the arm’s length requirement, constructive dividends and tax avoidance, as well as provisions relating to assessment procedures. There is also a comprehensive body of tax laws and decrees.
The tax administration (Verohallinto) issues instructions on substantive matters, and these bind the tax authorities.

The case law, and especially the precedents of the Supreme Administrative Court (KHO), are important for both the tax authorities and taxpayers. Both the Central Board of Taxation (KVL) and the Supreme Administrative Court publish advance rulings, which do not reveal the taxpayer’s identity, and which they consider to have precedential value.

section.title: Type of tax system
section.p: Companies which are treated as corporate bodies are subject to corporate income tax (yhteisön tulovero; samfunds inkomstskatt) at a flat rate. There is no local or municipal taxation on corporate taxpayers.

Finland applies the classical double tax system with some modifications. Dividends received by corporate shareholders are tax exempt with certain exceptions under the participation exemption as described in section 6.

section.title: Taxable persons
section.p: Resident private companies (Oy), public companies (Oyj), cooperatives, European Companies (Eurooppayhtiö, SEs), European Cooperative Societies (Eurooppaosuuskunta, SCEs), branches and permanent establishments of foreign companies are subject to corporate income tax.

General and limited partnerships, and economic interest groupings (EIGs) are not recognized as separate taxpayers and, generally, their profits are taxed in the hands of the partners (sections 4, 9 and 16a of the TVL).
Certain entities are not taxable persons. For details, see section 11.

section.title: Definition of residence
section.p: With effect from 1 January 2021, a definition of the concept of residence is introduced in tax legislation. Accordingly, a company is a Finnish resident if it is registered in Finland, incorporated in Finland or has its place of effective management in Finland (section 9 of the TVL and section 1 of the OYL). Such companies are liable to tax on their worldwide profits.

Companies not included in the abovementioned definition are treated as tax non-residents. Such companies are liable to tax on income from the Finnish sources only, unless the domestic law or the relevant treaty prevents Finland from taxing their income.
Before 2021, a company was in practice regarded as resident only if it was registered in Finland or incorporated under Finnish law.

section.title: General
section.p: In general, all income derived by companies is taxable. For exempt dividends and capital gains; see sections 6.1.3. and 1.7.5., respectively.

The tax assessment is based on profit and loss calculation on the corporate tax return. In addition, the company must annex its audited financial statements (income statement and balance sheet) to its tax return.

Income is generally computed on accrual basis. The tax laws require few adjustments. However, certain reserves for future expenses, which are required under commercial accounting principles, are usually not tax deductible.
Conformity between accounting and taxation is required (section 54 of the EVL). To be tax deductible, the item must be recorded in the accounts and included in the profit and loss account.
Resident companies are subject to tax on their worldwide income. Branches of non-resident companies are taxed on their Finnish-source income and on income attributable to the branch.

A company can in principle have taxable income from three sources, i.e. business, other income, and farming. Worldwide income and expense items, including interest expense, must be allocated to the relevant category and the taxable profit or loss is attributed to a source. Loss carry-forwards may only be deducted from the taxable profits in the same source. The netting of a loss generated in another income category is not allowed against a business profit. The taxable profit for business income is determined according to Business Income Tax Law (EVL) and the taxable profit for other income according to Income Tax Law (TVL).
The concepts of business income and the related expense are wide. It is rare for companies to have income or expense which would be deemed as other income.

In practice, the hiring-out of immovable property not needed for the business of the related companies could be treated as other income. Family-held companies may in practice be deemed to have such assets (long-term investments, deposits and immovable property for recreational purposes).

With effect from 1 January 2020, the categories of income for resident companies which are listed in section 3 of the TVL (e.g. limited liability companies and cooperatives) were amended. From that date, all types of income generated by such companies from commercial activities have been treated as business income and taxed under the EVL, except for income from agriculture. Most resident companies have only one category of income. The amendments did not affect the relevant tax rules for, inter alia, housing associations, real estate companies and exempt entities. If the entity is not listed in section 3 of the TVL, its income continues to be taxed in all three income categories.
If the company derives income from non-commercial activities in 2020 or later, that income generally falls under business income, but the related assets will fall under “other assets”.

The Law on Group Contribution only concerns business income. A loss in another income category may not be netted against a group contribution by a related business company. In an unclear case, an advance ruling may be obtained.

A taxpayer may use the completed contract method or the percentage of completion method in the accounting and tax treatment of long-term contracts. The percentage of completion method may be used if it takes more than 1 year to manufacture or construct the object (e.g. a ship or a building). Expenses must then be treated in the manner in which revenue is recorded. If the taxpayer chooses the percentage of completion method as its basis for accounting and taxation, every long-term contract must be treated in the same manner (section 19 of the EVL).

Companies may elect to use the IFRS principles instead of local GAAP for accounting of separate group companies and to base their corporate tax return on the IFRS financial statements. If they make such an election, they may apply the following principles instead of the rules explained in section 1.2.3. and subsequent sections:

item.p: income is recognized on long-term projects in the same way as in the IFRS accounts;

fixed overhead and interest expense included in the acquisition cost of inventory, fixed assets, investment assets and other business assets for IFRS purposes are treated in the same way for taxation purposes;
companies may value their inventory as the net realization value used for the IFRS purposes;

unrealized gains and losses on tradable financing instruments (kaupankäyntitarkoituksessa pidettävät rahavälineet) are seen as taxable income and deductible losses in the same way as in the IFRS income statement. Unrealized gains and losses recognized as income/expense in the IRFS accounts of banks and finance institutions according to section 151 of the Law on Finance Institutions, Banks and finance institutions are treated similarly for income tax purposes;
unrealized gains and losses on real property held for investment purposes which are treated as income and loss, respectively, for IFRS purposes do not affect company’s tax treatment.

group contribution (see sections 8.1. and 8.2.) may not be booked in the IFRS accounts as income or expense. Hence, companies that elect to use IFRS accounting as a basis for accounts and taxation may not benefit from the group contribution system. Therefore most quoted companies continue to use IFRS for consolidated accounts only and continue to prepare the accounts of the group companies according to local GAAP.

section.title: Taxable period
section.p: The tax year normally runs from 1 January to 31 December (section 3 of the VML). Companies whose accounting period is other than the calendar year are taxed on the accounting period or periods ending in the calendar year. Normally an accounting period covers 12 months, but when a business is started or terminated, or when the accounting period is changed, it may be shorter or longer (not more than 18 months).

It is relatively simple to change the taxable period of a company and it may be done any number of times. The change must be reported to the tax office 2 months before the new accounting year ends if the accounting year is shortened. If the accounting year is extended, the change must be reported 2 months before the old accounting year would have ended. The taxpayer must have made all necessary amendments to the articles of association and registered the change in the trade register to benefit from the change.

Taxes are levied in the 10-month assessment period, which usually ends by the end of October of the year following the tax year for calendar-year based companies. Advance taxes are normally paid in the tax year, i.e. during the accounting period of the company.

section.title: Exempt income
section.p: Dividends are exempt in most cases (see section 6.1.3.). Capital gains on the sale of shares and liquidation proceeds are tax exempt under certain conditions (see section 1.7.5.). Capital contributions by shareholders, refunds of income taxes and the related interest, unrealized profits resulting from the revaluation of fixed assets and, in general, of shares and other securities are not considered to be taxable income (section 6 of the EVL). Gains derived from mergers of two or more companies and benefits from a settlement or a relief from debt if the debtor is insolvent are not considered to be taxable income either (see section 9.2.).

section.title: Inventory
section.p: Inventory is defined as (chapter 4, section 4 of the Accounting Law (KPL); section 10 of the EVL):

item.p: merchandise, raw material, semi-manufactured goods and other commodities, which in their unprocessed or processed forms are intended to be used in the business; and
fuel lubricants and other commodities which are intended for consumption in the business.

section.p: Inventory is valued at the lowest of direct acquisition cost on a FIFO (first in, first out) basis, replacement cost or net sales value at the last day of the accounting year. A taxpayer is also entitled to add essential overhead expenses and interest to the acquisition cost of inventory assets, if the same is done for accounting purposes (chapter 4, section 5 of the KPL; sections 28 and 14 of the EVL).
Similar valuation principles apply to securities and participations for banks, banking firms and companies dealing in shares and other securities.

section.title: Depreciable assets
section.p: Fixed assets are entered on the balance sheet at their acquisition cost, reduced, where assets are subject to wear and tear, by depreciation according to plan (chapter 5, section 5 of the KPL). The taxpayer is entitled to add essential overhead expenses and interest to the acquisition expense of fixed assets, provided the same is done for accounting purposes (chapter 4, section 5 of the KPL; section 14 of the EVL).

If the taxpayer can prove that the net book value of a depreciable asset exceeds the market value of that asset, the taxpayer is allowed to deduct, for tax purposes, the additional depreciation which will reduce the net book value of the asset to the market value with effect from the end of the accounting year concerned. A similar additional depreciation for machinery and equipment is allowed if the taxpayer can prove that the total net book value of all machinery and equipment, due to a decrease in values, destruction or damage to property or other reason, exceeds the market value of the machinery and equipment. However, additional depreciation of the cost of construction, equipment, machinery and other assets for the prevention of water and air pollution is allowed only where there is actual damage to the asset (see also section 1.5.4.) (section 40 of the EVL).

Goodwill, patents and other intangible assets are valued for tax purposes at their acquisition cost, reduced by any amortization deductions previously taken. These intangible assets are amortized according to the straight-line method over their economic life, but not exceeding 10 years (see section 1.5.) (sections 24 and 37 of the EVL).

section.title: Non-depreciable assets
section.p: Depreciation for tax purposes is not allowed for fixed assets which are not subject to wear and tear, such as land, securities and participations in other companies and partnerships.

Securities and participations are classified as fixed assets if they are intended to be used permanently in the business or profession (section 12 of the EVL). For valuation of securities and participations classified as inventory, see section 1.3.1.; and as financial assets, see section 1.3.4.

Non-depreciable assets are entered on the balance sheet at their direct acquisition cost increased by, for example, transfer taxes and lawyers’ fees. Any unrealized increases or decreases in value do not, in principle, affect taxable profits.

If the fair market value of land, securities or participations is, with effect from the balance sheet date, permanently essentially higher than the purchase price, the difference may be included in the balance sheet as a separate revaluation item. To the extent the revaluation later proves to be excessive, it must be revoked (chapter 5, section 17 of the KPL). The recording or revocation of the revaluation is not a taxable event for companies other than banks and financial institutions.

Any extraordinary depreciation deduction for fixed assets not subject to wear and tear, claimed under prior law, must be added back to the taxable income to the extent that the market value at the end of any future accounting year exceeds the net book value (section 5a(4) of the EVL). This applies also to securities even though extraordinary depreciation is no longer allowed.

section.title: Debt claims and liabilities
section.p: Debt claims are ordinarily classified as financial assets (section 9 of the EVL). In the case of financial, insurance and pension institutions, securities and participations, but not debt claims, are classified as investment assets if they have the nature of a long-term investment or investment security (section 11 of the EVL). Classification as fixed, financial or investment assets determines the asset’s method of depreciation.

Debt claims are stated in the balance sheet at face value but not higher than their probable value (chapter 5, section 2 of the KPL). Receivables belonging to financial assets may also be valued at market value (chapter 5, section 2a of the KPL). Credit losses concerning accounts receivable may be written off in accordance with the generally accepted accounting practice (section 17 of the EVL). Future increases in such accounts are added back to taxable income (section 5a(1k) of the EVL). A permanent loss in value of a receivable, other than a trade receivable, may be written off if the receivable has also been written off in the accounts. Losses relating to tax-exempt income are not deductible (sections 7 and 17 of the EVL).

Liabilities are stated in the balance sheet at face values (chapter 5, section 2 of the KPL). However, they may be stated at a higher value if so warranted by an index or another variable to which their value is tied.

section.title: Foreign currency assets and liabilities
section.p: Foreign exchange assets (accounts receivable) and liabilities (accounts payable) in foreign currency must, in accordance with the KPL, be converted into Finnish currency (euro) using the exchange rate at the balance sheet date. If the parties agree to a certain rate, that rate must be used later in the conversion (chapter 5, section 3 of the KPL).

According to section 26 of the Business Income Tax Law, gains and losses on assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency are taxed or deducted in the year during which the rate has changed. If the asset or liability has been hedged by a currency swap or another hedging instrument, the realized gain is taxed and the unrealized gain expensed during the tax year in which it has been booked as income or expense in the accounts.

section.title: General principles
section.p: As a general rule, deductions are allowed for all costs and expenses incurred by the business within the tax year for the purpose of earning, securing, or maintaining the taxpayer’s income (sections 7, 8, 17 and 18 of the EVL). Expenses are thus tax deductible under the accrual principle. Reserves for future expenses are generally not tax deductible.
Payments to affiliates of amounts exceeding the arm’s length cost may be disallowed.

Transaction costs (such as lawyers’ fees), transfer taxes and similar expenses, which must be capitalized in connection with the asset to which they relate or are assessed, are depreciable if the underlying asset is depreciable, such as buildings. If the asset, such as shares or other securities or land, is not subject to wear and tear, neither the acquisition price of the asset nor the expenses relating to the acquisition are deductible until disposal. Expenses relating to obtaining tax-exempt income are not tax deductible.

section.title: Employees’ remuneration
section.p: Salaries and wages paid to employees are generally deductible (section 8 of the EVL). There are no limits on payments to employees.

Social security contributions relating to salaries and wages are tax deductible. Employers are entitled to deduct pension insurance premiums even if they would have been paid for private pension insurance schemes arranged by the employer. Private pension insurance schemes may in some cases be treated as salary income to employees and be taxed accordingly. The premiums are, however, tax deductible in any case. Obligatory pension insurance schemes may not be treated as salary income to the employees.
Daily allowances and mileage compensation are tax deductible although, if not exceeding certain limits set by the tax authorities, they are tax-exempt income in the hands of the employees.

Fringe benefits, such as housing and company car benefits, are taxable salary income in the hands of employees. All costs relating to the arrangement of these benefits are tax deductible to the employer.
Conventional gifts to employees are tax deductible, but if they are valuable or given in cash, they are regarded as salary income to employees.

If the employee is granted option rights or is allowed to buy or subscribe to the employer’s shares (or in the case of a foreign-owned subsidiary the foreign parent company’s shares), the employee receives a taxable benefit if the purchase or subscription price is lower than the fair market value of the share at the time of the purchase or subscription of the shares or at the time of the execution of the option right. If it is a question of an issue of new shares and the issue is directed to the majority of the personnel, the subscription price may be, at most, 10% lower than the fair market value without the benefit being considered taxable.

The benefit is taxed as earned income in the hands of the employee, i.e. as salary. The employer must therefore withhold advance wage tax and pay the employer’s social security contributions on the benefit. If the benefit is granted by a foreign parent company to employees of a Finnish subsidiary, the cost for the benefit (e.g. the value of the shares given to the employees) may be charged back to the Finnish subsidiary. The cost of benefit and the social security charge are tax deductible for the employer. If the employee is the sole or majority shareholder, and the benefit is not accounted for as salary, it may be deemed to be a hidden profit distribution and the deduction may be denied for tax purposes (see section 6.1.5.).

section.title: Directors’ fees
section.p: Fees, fringe and other benefits paid to the members of the board and supervisory board are, in general, deductible. An exception exists if the director is a significant shareholder and the fee is deemed to be a hidden profit distribution (see sections 6.2. and 10.1.).

section.title: Dividends
section.p: Dividends are not deductible. This applies to amounts treated as a hidden profit distribution, e.g. a price paid in excess of fair market value by a company to its controlling shareholder. For tax treatment at shareholder level, see section 6.1.5.

section.title: Interest
section.p: In general, interest expenses are deductible. They are tax deductible for a debtor even if tied to its result (section 18 of the EVL). However, a general limitation on the deductibility of interest expenses between related parties applies (see below). Companies may deduct interest on a loan obtained to finance a dividend payment or on a loan to finance an acquisition of a target company or a portion of it. The fact that the related dividend income may be tax exempt does not prevent the deductibility.

The sourcing rules explained in section 1.2.1. may effectively limit the deductibility of interest in rare cases. The reason is that interest expenses relating to income other than business income may not be netted against the business income. An example would be a debt-financed acquisition of real property which is not used in the business of the taxpayer or in the business of related parties. In such a case, interest expenses could be deducted from the revenues generated by the real property.

Generally, a local holding company may be used to push down acquisition-related debt. Thus, a local debt-financed holding company may be deemed to conduct business and qualify for a local group contribution.

Interest paid to related companies and to other related parties, such as shareholders, must correspond to that charged in an arm’s length transaction. The interest in excess of the arm’s length level is not tax deductible and may be regarded as hidden profit distribution if paid to a shareholder (see section 6.1.5.).
For further details on limitations on interest deductibility, see section 10.3.

section.title: Royalties
section.p: Royalty payments are deductible. If paid to a related company, the royalty must correspond to that which parties dealing at arm’s length would charge.

section.title: Service and management fees
section.p: Service and management fees are deductible. If paid to a related company, their amounts must correspond to those charged in an arm’s length transaction. The company paying the fees must be able to prove to the tax authorities that it received the services charged and that it received them in order to obtain or maintain income.
Service and management fees between companies that belong to an international group are carefully reviewed by the tax authorities in tax audits.

section.title: Research and development
section.p: Expenses explicitly listed as deductible include research and development (R&D) expenses (section 8(1)(6) of the EVL). The law does not contain a definition for R&D expenditure. In light of case law and jurisprudence, deductible R&D expenditure includes costs incurred in surveys, planning or marketing aimed at the development of production or marketing, and planning for development of products. Examples of research activity expenditure are payroll costs, acquisition cost of material and equipment used in the research activity, as well as acquisition costs of buildings, machinery, furniture, equipment, etc., acquired for the purposes of the research activity. For the deductibility it is not required that the project to which the expenditure relates is successful.

Deductible R&D expenditure may be incurred directly by the taxpayer or indirectly through a research company or institution. In the latter case, payments to research institutions have been excepted as deductible even where the payment is not a consideration for specific research results received by the taxpayer; in this case, the research must be related to the field of business of the taxpayer. Payments for expenditure incurred abroad are treated the same way as expenditure incurred domestically. In the case of payments abroad within a group of companies, the provisions regarding the arm’s length requirement and hidden profit distribution (see section 6.1.5.) should be observed.

According to the general rule of section 22(1) of the EVL, expenditure is deductible in the year during which it has been incurred. Section 25 of the EVL repeats the same general rule specifically for R&D expenditure (other than expenditure for the acquisition of a building or construction, see below). The latter provision, however, also allows upon a taxpayer’s request such expenditure to be deducted through depreciation allowances, in which case the taxpayer may freely determine the number of years (between 2 and 10 years) and the amount of allowances taken per year.

Under section 34(2)(5) of the EVL, expenditure for the acquisition of a building or construction (or part of a building or construction) used exclusively for research aimed at promoting a business is deductible at a rate of 20% (declining balance method).

The total deduction for R&D expenditure (whether deducted currently or through depreciation) may not exceed the amount recorded in the taxpayer’s accounts during the tax year and earlier years (section 54(2) of the EVL).
Between 2021 and 2027, a temporary incentive for R&D costs applies (see section 1.9.2.).

section.title: Other deductions
section.p: Donations are deductible for corporate income tax purposes in the following cases (section 57 of the TVL):

item.p: donations of at least EUR 850 but not more than EUR 250,000 per donation if the donation is made to a university or other higher educational institution of Finland or any other EEA country, to benefit the sciences, the arts or the Finnish cultural heritage; and

donations of at least EUR 850 but not more than EUR 250,000 per donation if the donation is made to an approved association or foundation of Finland or any other EEA country, or to a fund connected to such an approved organization, to benefit the sciences, the arts or the Finnish cultural heritage.

section.p: As regards (2), the donee must be approved by the tax administration. Approval is given for a limited time, not exceeding 5 years (renewable) (section 2 of the TVA).
Other donations and gifts are not deductible, except for customary advertising gifts.
Travel expenses are deductible. To be deductible, travel expenses must be properly documented.
Income taxes, including foreign withholding taxes and fines, are not tax deductible.
Contributions between group companies may, under certain conditions, be allowed as deductions (see section 8.2.).

section.title: Non-deductible expenses
section.p: Non-deductible items include (section 16 of the EVL):

item.p: expenses not necessary for earning income;

expenses incurred in earning or maintaining tax-exempt income. Expenses exceeding the amount of tax-free income are tax deductible. Interest expenses on loans used to acquire foreign subsidiaries are tax deductible, although the dividend income derived from abroad may be tax exempt (see section 1.4.5.);
fees paid for joining collective bodies maintaining electrical supply, telephone, water, sewerage or heating networks;
excessive salaries or other types of compensation paid to a shareholder or a member of his family;
taxes on income including foreign withholding taxes and additional penalties for non-payment of taxes or for inadequate tax returns;
a loss arising in connection with a merger;
fines and other similar penalties; and
50% of entertainment expenses.

section.p: Also non-deductible is economic support given by a company to another group company. For example, a parent company may not deduct a loss resulting from forgiving a subsidiary’s debt to avoid its bankruptcy. The form of support is not decisive, what is important is its true nature. The provision denying the deductibility of group support is applicable where the supporting company, alone or with other group companies, owns at least 10% of the share capital of the recipient. The provision is not applicable to decreases in value or losses of sales receivables.
Other non-deductible items include:

item.p: bribes and similar payments;

the purchase price of shares when a public company acquires them from the stock market, except if it gives them as an employment-based bonus or compensation to its employees (section 18(3) of the EVL); and
capital losses and liquidation losses in most cases (see section 1.8.2.).

section.title: General principles
section.p: The Business Income Tax Law (EVL) contains detailed rules on the depreciation of different kinds of assets (sections 30-45a of the EVL). Depreciation of land, securities and participations in other companies or partnerships is not allowed.

The general method of depreciation is the declining-balance method which is applied to fixed assets, such as machinery, equipment and buildings. All machinery and equipment is pooled for tax depreciation purposes. Depreciation is allowed on every item which was put into use before the end of the accounting year.

Straight-line depreciation is applied to long-term expenditures and intangible rights, such as patents and trademarks. The company may take full depreciation if the asset is acquired or, in the case of long-term expenditures, the expenses are incurred prior to the end of the tax year.
For natural resources, the depletion method is applied and the computation is based on the quantity of the natural resources used.

In order to be deductible for tax purposes, the depreciated amounts must also cumulatively be expensed in the accounts of the company. Because of this requirement, companies record depreciation of assets required for tax purposes and exceeding the plan for accounting purposes under the heading “Depreciation in excess of plan” in their profit and loss accounts. Accrued depreciations in excess of plan are presented in the balance sheet under the heading “Accelerated depreciations” (see section 1.9.1.).

A taxpayer may freely elect whether to depreciate the assets for tax purposes in a particular tax year. However, amortization or straight-line depreciation must be claimed annually. In certain cases it may be beneficial not to make depreciation for tax purposes, especially if the company has losses. Accounting depreciation may be omitted for tax purposes in the tax return. The postponed tax depreciation may then be utilized in a later tax year, provided that the depreciable assets have not been sold or otherwise disposed of.

If a taxpayer’s tax year exceeds or is less than 12 months, the maximum depreciation claim is affected. The maximum claim per tax year according to the declining balance method is not increased even if the tax year is longer than 12 months. On the other hand, the company may claim the maximum depreciation if the tax year is shorter than 12 months.

section.title: Right to claim depreciation
section.p: Legislation follows the legal ownership principle in determining which entity is entitled to take depreciation deductions:

item.p: in lease transactions, the lessor who is the legal owner of the leased asset. There is no difference between an operational lease and financial lease; and
in instalment purchasing, the purchaser who acquires the object and pays in instalments.

section.p: Also where the seller retains legal title to the asset until the payment of the full price, the entity entitled to depreciate is the purchaser, if it is the definite intention of the parties that the purchaser will become the legal owner of the asset which is sold. Also a lease arrangement may be regarded as instalment purchasing if the lessee has an option to buy the leased asset for a nominal price at the end of the leasing period.

All assets acquired must be used (or at least they must be in such condition that production with or other kind of utilization of the assets is possible) in the tax year in which they are depreciated for the first time.

section.title: Immovable property
section.p: Land may not be depreciated. A company is allowed to depreciate the net book value of buildings and constructions by the declining-balance method, up to the statutory rates provided for various kinds of buildings and constructions in the Business Income Tax Law (section 34 of the EVL). The base for the depreciation is the acquisition price of the buildings and constructions, including all incidental costs, such as transfer taxes. Each building is depreciated separately.

The acquisition value of assets acquired also includes expenses for extension, change, renewal, and other similar basic improvements and also, at the request of the taxpayer, significant expenses for repair (section 35 of the EVL).
The maximum depreciation rates permitted for various types of building and other construction in a particular tax year are (section 34 of the EVL):

entry.p: Shop, warehouse, factory, workshop, farm, power station and comparable building
Tank for storage of liquid fuel and acids, similar building used for storage, and construction of metal or comparable material
Light construction of wood or comparable material
Building or construction, or part of building or construction, used exclusively for research aimed at promoting business

section.p: The percentage per annum is applied to the remaining tax book value of the building or other construction.

The acquisition value of air-raid shelters or a portion of the acquisition value of a building which relates to a shelter, is depreciated at a rate not exceeding 25% per year. Hence, the acquisition value is depreciated in 4 or more years. A 25% per annum straight-line depreciation rate also applies to the acquisition value of construction, equipment, machinery and other assets for the prevention of water and air pollution (see section 1.5.4.) and the acquisition value of natural gas pipelines used for natural gas distribution (section 36 of the EVL).

section.title: Plant, machinery and equipment
section.p: The law contains no provisions governing the depreciation of an entire plant. Instead, depreciation is taken on the individual assets in the plant or on machinery and equipment, that is, on a group of assets. The acquisition value of lifts, central heating, plant machinery and equipment, ovens, refrigerators and freezers, ventilation and air conditioning equipment, communal aerials and other similar assets, even though such items constitute part of a building, is depreciated using the method that is applied to machinery and equipment.

In general, a company may depreciate, using the declining-balance method, up to 25% of the total net tax book values of the company’s entire pool of machinery and equipment (section 30 of the EVL) (see section 1.7.). The total net tax book value consists of the net tax book value of machinery and equipment at the beginning of the tax year, increased by the acquisition value of other machinery and equipment acquired during the year, and reduced by the proceeds derived from the sale or alienation thereof. The accounting treatment differs from the tax treatment.
A taxpayer may choose any depreciation percentage between 0% and 25% annually.

In theory, under the declining-balance method, a zero tax value of the total machinery and equipment will never be reached and, unless new machinery and equipment is acquired correspondingly, the taxpayer faces steadily decreasing amounts to be taken as depreciation, even though the maximum rate of 25% is applied. Even if the tax value of machinery and equipment were to approach zero, the taxpayer would not be entitled to depreciate the value thereof to zero if the machinery and equipment still have market value.

The acquisition value includes the purchase price of the asset, all related costs, such as installation costs and related levies, duties and taxes, excluding VAT (because VAT is credited within the VAT system).

The acquisition value of assets acquired during the year includes expenses for the extension, change, renewal, and other similar basic improvements of machinery and equipment and, at the request of the taxpayer, also significant expenses for repair (section 30.2 of the EVL).

As an exception to the main rule, the acquisition value of automobiles which are used for business purposes, such as buses, trucks, and taxis, may be depreciated by applying the following maximum depreciation rates to the acquisition value over 5 successive years: 25%, 20%, 20%, 15% and 15% (section 33 of the EVL). If this depreciation method is used instead of the main depreciation rule, the profit on the sale or other transfer of assets at prices in excess of the net book value is deemed to be taxable income in the year of the sale or transfer.

As another exception to the main rule, the acquisition value of pleasure boats (i.e. boats not directly used in business) is depreciable over a 10-year period at the minimum by applying the straight-line depreciation method (section 33a of the EVL). Hence, the maximum annual rate of depreciation for pleasure boats is 10%. It should, however, be noted that if the boat has initially been purchased for entertainment purposes, only 50% of the original purchase price is depreciable (see section 1.4.9.).

The acquisition value of construction, equipment, machinery and other assets utilized to prevent water and air pollution is depreciated by write-offs of not more than 25% per year (thus, in 4 or more years).

Equipment, machinery and other assets that have a probable economic life of 3 years or less may be depreciated immediately (section 33 of the EVL). If such assets are not depreciated (expensed) immediately, they must be depreciated according to the main rule that applies to machinery and equipment. In principle, equipment, machinery and other assets that have a probable economic life of more than 3 years must be capitalized and depreciated according to the rules above. However, fixed assets that have a value of less than EUR 1,200 (EUR 850 before 2021) may be expensed immediately even though the economic life exceeds 3 years. The total value of assets so expensed may not exceed EUR 3,600 (EUR 2,500 before 2021) per tax year.

If the taxpayer can prove that the market value of fixed assets or, in the case of machinery and equipment, the market value of all assets, at the end of the tax year is, after depreciation at the maximum regular rate in that year, lower than the remaining value for tax purposes, additional depreciation equal to the difference is allowed (sections 32 and 40 of the EVL). However, for shelters or construction, equipment, machinery and other assets for the prevention of water and air pollution, the additional depreciation deduction is allowed only if the reduction in value results from accidental damage or a similar event.

section.title: Trademarks and patents
section.p: The acquisition value of patents and other intangible rights which are granted only for a limited period (e.g. copyrights, trademarks, publishing rights and production method rights) and which can be transferred separately, may be written off using straight-line amortization over a 10-year period. However, amortization may be taken over a shorter period if the holder has the right to exploit the intangible for less than 10 years (section 37 of the EVL).

section.title: Goodwill
section.p: The acquisition value of goodwill is written off in equal annual instalments over the probable period of use or, if such probable period exceeds 10 years, over 10 tax years (section 24 of the EVL). If the probable period does not exceed 3 years, the acquisition value of goodwill may be expensed. The acquisition value is the price paid for goodwill.

Goodwill is deductible only if it is acquired separately or together with other assets from another company. Goodwill included in the acquisition value of the shares of a subsidiary is not deductible as a separate item.

There is no tax relief for a loss arising from a merger between two companies, although the merger loss was caused by the inclusion of goodwill in the acquisition price of the shares of the merged company.

section.title: Other assets
section.p: Gravel and sand pits, mines, quarries, peat bogs, and similar natural resources are depreciated according to the depletion method (section 38 of the EVL).

Railways, bridges, quays, dams and basins, and similar assets are depreciated by equal annual write-offs over the probable economic life of the asset or, if it exceeds 40 years, over a 40-year period (section 39 of the EVL).

Advertising campaign expenses, expenses for the establishment of a company or business, leasehold improvements, etc. that produce or maintain income for 3 or more tax years, are written off in equal annual write-offs over their probable economic life or, if it exceeds 10 years, over a 10-year period (section 24 of the EVL).

section.title: Cessation of use, transfer or disposal of assets
section.p: If immovable property, trademarks and patents, goodwill or natural resources are sold, the sales price is directly allocated to the remaining tax value of the asset. If the sales price exceeds the remaining tax value, the difference is deemed to be ordinary taxable business income in the hands of the taxpayer.

If machinery and equipment are sold, the sales prices of different items are recorded as deductions of the total net tax value of machinery and equipment (section 30 of the EVL). At the end of the tax year, the depreciation is hence computed on the lower remaining tax value of machinery and equipment.

If extraordinary depreciation on securities and participations other than shares is or has been carried out, and the market value of the depreciated asset rises back to the original acquisition value, the depreciation must be recaptured and included in taxable income in the tax year in which the value increased (section 5a of the EVL).

section.title: Unutilized depreciation or amortization allowances
section.p: The change of ownership in a company does not affect its ability to claim depreciation or to utilize cumulative depreciation recorded for accounting purposes but not yet depreciated for tax purposes.
As the ownership change affects the deductibility of loss carry-forwards, companies may elect not to claim maximum depreciation in order not to generate a loss for taxation purposes.

section.title: Bad and doubtful debts
section.p: General bad and doubtful debt provisions may not be made.

Banks and other credit institutions are entitled to make a doubtful debt provision annually. The provision may not exceed 0.6% of the amount of claims outstanding at the end of the tax year, provided that the amount of the annual provision, together with previously made provisions, does not exceed 5% of the amount of claims outstanding with effect from the end of such tax year (section 46 of the EVL).

section.title: Replacement of assets
section.p: For certain types of fixed assets (listed in the law) which are subject to wear and tear, a replacement reserve is, at the taxpayer’s request, allowable under the Business Income Tax Law if a corresponding entry is made for accounting purposes (section 43 of the EVL).

A replacement reserve for machinery and equipment is only allowed if machinery and equipment are lost or damaged due to fire or other misadventure. The replacement reserve is the amount by which the damages or other compensation received exceeds the depreciable tax value of the pooled cost of machinery and equipment.

Buildings and other constructions, air-raid shelters, assets used for the prevention of pollution, and railways, bridges, quays, etc. are fixed assets that may be depreciated individually (see sections 1.5.3. to 1.5.7.). For these assets, a replacement reserve is also allowed only if any particular asset is lost or damaged due to fire or other misadventure. The replacement reserve is the amount by which the damages or other compensation received exceeds the depreciable tax value of such asset.

In addition, replacement reserves may be created for the sale or other disposal of a building which serves as the taxpayer’s business premises, or of shares entitling the taxpayer to the possession of the premises used by him in business (although securities or other fixed assets not subject to wear and tear may not, in general, form a basis for depreciation) (section 43(2) of the EVL).

The replacement reserve must be deducted from the cost of acquisition of fixed assets brought into use for two subsequent tax years or from the reparation cost of a damaged asset or newly acquired premises. For special reasons, this period may be extended by 3 years with the approval of the tax office.

Any part of the reserve which has not been deducted from the cost of fixed assets within the prescribed time period is increased by 20% and added to taxable income in the last tax year in which the reserve could have been deducted. Any part which is unused after an extension period granted by the tax office is increased by 40% and added to taxable income.

section.title: Other reserves and provisions
section.p: For costs arising out of product guarantees given by businesses which construct buildings, bridges, quays, roads, dams or similar construction or by businesses which produce aircraft, ships (the hulls of which are not less than 10 metres) or machinery, a guarantee provision may be deducted from taxable income in the tax year in which such construction or machinery was sold (section 47 of the EVL). The guarantee provision represents anticipated guarantee expenses. Other businesses are not allowed to deduct any guarantee provisions, although such provisions may be created for accounting purposes.

Reserves for probable future payments of employee pensions and salaries, company restructuring, environmental damage, etc. which are made for accounting purposes are not tax deductible until the costs in fact have been incurred.

section.title: General
section.p: Regulations on capital gains are included in the Business Income Tax Law (EVL). Capital gains are generally regarded as ordinary business income and taxed accordingly (section 5 of the EVL). If investments in other companies, partnerships, etc. or in immovable property are not regarded as having been made for business purposes, the capital gains are taxed according to the Income Tax Law (section 45 of the TVL). However, the computation of capital gains in both laws is equal as regards capital gains derived by companies.

The tax is levied on capital gains realized on the disposal of assets for cash or other property. For instance, share-for-share exchanges are taxable transactions, although the actual payment of tax may be deferred under the special provisions implementing the Merger Directive (2009/133) (see section 9.2.2.).
Capital gains on shares are exempt under certain circumstances (see section 1.7.5.).

section.title: Capital assets
section.p: Capital gains realized by a company from the sale of any asset are included in their entirety in the taxable income of the company unless treated as exempt capital gains described in section 1.7.6. (sections 5 and 6b of the EVL). In addition, income from the sale of a depreciable asset is deducted from the relevant tax cost base before generating a potentially taxable gain.

section.title: Realization
section.p: Capital gains are usually realized when a company sells or disposes of its assets. This occurs when an agreement is concluded which legally binds both parties. A merger or a division which qualifies for tax-neutral treatment is not treated as a realization for the absorbed company or its shareholders. It does not interrupt the ownership period or affect the original acquisition cost. Share-for-share exchanges, tax-neutral transfers of business and other exchanges of property are deemed to be disposals of assets and generally give rise to taxation unless exempt (see section 1.7.6.).

If a company is liquidated, the remaining assets are usually distributed among the shareholders. If the value of a shareholder’s distributive share exceeds the remaining acquisition cost for tax purposes (tax-free return of capital), the excess is effectively taxed as a capital gain (see section 9.5.2.). However, liquidation proceeds received by a corporate shareholder are generally exempt (see section 1.7.5.).

section.title: Computation of capital gains and losses
section.p: The sales price or other compensation received is treated as taxable ordinary income, unless exempt. During the tax year of disposal, the taxpayer may deduct the remaining tax cost. No indexation relief is available.

If the difference is positive, it is effectively included in ordinary business income. If the difference is negative, it is set off against ordinary business income. It may also create a tax loss carry-forward.

If the investment from which a gain or loss arises was not made for business purposes, the gain or loss is included in other income and taxed separately under the Income Tax Law (TVL). The gain may not be offset against a loss of the business income source. Equally, a loss arising from other income source may not be offset against ordinary business income.

section.title: Exempt capital gains
section.p: Capital gains derived by a resident company or cooperative on the sale of shares in a company (other than a real estate company or a venture capital company) are exempt if the following conditions are met (sections 6b(1) and (2) of the EVL):

item.p: the shares form part of the seller’s fixed assets;
the seller has owned at least 10% of the share capital in the company directly and continuously for at least 1 year during a period which ended no more than 1 year prior to the sale; and
the company whose shares are sold is resident in Finland or another EU Member State, or in a country with which Finland has a tax treaty in force which applies to dividend paid by the target.

section.p: These rules apply correspondingly in the case of a liquidation.

The gains are, however, taxable for the part that corresponds to a loss incurred on any prior intra-group sale of the same shares. In addition, the gains are taxable if they are a result of prior extraordinary depreciation (see section 1.3.3.) or a subsidy or a reserve attributable to the acquisition of the shares (section 6b(3) of the EVL).

Further, the exemption is not applicable if the seller is a venture capital company (section 6(1) of the EVL). For the purposes of this provision, “venture capital company” means a company that acquires other companies in order to develop them and to improve the value of the company; the ultimate purpose of the company is to sell the acquired companies in the future for profit.

section.title: Deferment of tax on capital gains
section.p: In principle, share-for-share exchanges are also treated as taxable transactions which trigger the taxation of capital gains under the tax law. However, Finland has implemented the Merger Directive (2009/133) pursuant to which the payment of tax may be deferred in such exchanges (see section 9.3.1.).

section.title: Ordinary losses
section.p: If the business operations of a company yield a net loss, this loss may be carried forward for tax purposes and set off against future business profits. The loss may be carried forward for up to 10 tax years (sections 120 to 123a of the TVL). Set-offs must follow the sequence in which the losses occurred. Losses may be set off only against income from the same income source.

If more than 50% of the shares in a company are sold in a loss year or thereafter, the right to carry forward the loss is forfeited. The tax office may, however, authorize such carry-forward if it is necessary for the continuation of the company’s activities (section 122(3) of the TVL). Losses which are only deductible on the basis of such an authorization may not, however, be offset against income which is received as group contribution from another group company. However, the tax office may grant a specific authorization in order to allow the company to offset the losses also against received group contribution if the preconditions for group contributions have been fulfilled prior to the transfer of the shares (see section 8.2.).

The authorization procedure as provided in section 122(3) of the TVL had been under the scrutiny of the ECJ. On 30 December 2011, the Supreme Administrative Court has requested a preliminary ruling from the ECJ regarding the application of the special authorization procedure and its compatibility with EU law, in P Oy (Case C-6/12). On 18 July 2013, the ECJ gave its decision in this case and concluded that Finnish loss carry-forward rules are not incompatible with EU law.

For mergers, the surviving company is entitled to deduct from its taxable income losses carried forward by the merged company, provided that the combined holdings of the surviving company and its shareholders have, since the beginning of the loss year, exceeded 50% of the shares in the merged company (see section 9.2.). These principles also apply when a partnership is transformed into a company.

Indirect ownership changes also affect loss carry-forwards. If more than 50% of the shares of a company that owns at least 20% of the loss-making company change ownership, all the shares of the loss-making company owned by the other company are deemed, for the purpose of loss carry-forward, to have changed ownership.
There are no provisions for the carry-back of losses. Consequently, when a company is liquidated, unabsorbed losses are forfeited.
Foreign losses are discussed in section 7.2.2.

section.title: Capital losses
section.p: Losses suffered on the sale or other disposal of business assets are considered to be part of ordinary losses. Losses suffered on the sale or other disposal of assets not relating to the business belong to “other income”. These losses may only be deducted from capital gains arising from disposals of non-business related assets in the same accounting year or in any of the following 5 years (section 50 of the TVL).

Capital losses incurred on shares are not deductible if corresponding gains would be exempt from tax (see section 1.7.5.) (section 6b(1) of the EVL). Under all other circumstances, such losses are deductible. However, the losses may be offset only against taxable gains on the sale of shares within the same tax year or the 5 following years (section 6b(4) of the EVL). The offset is limited to shares that are treated as fixed assets. In addition, if the company has owned the shares for less than 1 year, distributed dividends, group contributions and similar items that decrease the value of the company are deducted in determining the deductible loss (section 6b(5) of the EVL).

The above rules on share losses apply correspondingly in the case of a liquidation. It should be noted, however, that the liquidation loss is not deductible even if the company has owned the shares for less than 1 year (in which case the corresponding liquidation gain would be taxable) (section 51d of the EVL).

section.title: Accelerated depreciation
section.p: Under the Law on Increased Depreciation on Machinery, Equipment and Other Comparable Movable Fixed Assets in Tax Years 2020-2023, accelerated depreciation may be taken on new machinery, equipment, and other comparable movable fixed assets which have been taken in use during calendar years 2020-2023. The accelerated depreciation may be taken at statutory rates increased by 50% annually during tax years 2020-2023. The incentive is available to all companies including service companies in Finland. It is not limited to investments in developing areas.

section.title: Investment deduction
section.p: Between 2021 and 2027, a temporary incentive for R&D costs applies (Laki tutkimus- ja kehittämistoiminnan lisävähennyksestä verovuosina 2021-2027; Lag om ett tilläggsavdrag för forsknings- och utvecklingsverksamhet under skatteåren 2021-2027; LTKVäh). Accordingly, companies developing intangible rights in cooperation with universities and other institutions of higher education are granted an additional deduction of 50% of the qualifying R&D costs in 2021 and 150% in 2022-2027. The additional deduction is capped at EUR 500,000 per year. A minimum deduction of EUR 5,000 applies.

section.title: Income
section.p: The corporate income tax rate is 20%. Collected corporate income taxes are shared by the state, municipalities and the two state churches.

section.title: Capital gains
section.p: There is no separate tax on capital gains. Capital gains (other than exempt gains, see section 1.7.5.) are taxed as business income or other income at the general corporate income tax rate.

section.title: Dividends
section.p: There are no withholding taxes on payments of dividends to resident companies. For payments to non-residents, see section 7.3.4.

section.title: Interest
section.p: There are no withholding taxes on payments of interest to resident companies. For payments to non-residents, see section 7.3.4.

section.title: Royalties
section.p: There are no withholding taxes on payments of royalties to resident companies. Royalty payments to resident companies are usually subject to VAT. For payments to non-residents, see section 7.3.4.

section.title: Other income
section.p: There are no withholding taxes on any other payments, e.g. rents (immovable and movable property), fees, or capital gains. For exemption to non-residents, see section 7.3.4.

section.title: Administration
section.p: With effect from 1 January 2017, various amendments to the Law on Tax Procedure, the revised Tax Collection Law (Veronkantolaki, VKantoL), as well as the modified OVML, entered into force. Various other laws are amended, resulting in substantial changes in respect of tax administrative issues. In particular, under the amendments:

item.p: certain tax returns must, in principle, be filed electronically with a few exceptions;
the amounts of late payment interest and penalties for certain offences, as well as the relevant calculation methods, are reviewed;
the statute of limitation is set at generally 3 years following the year of assessment. However, this limit may be extended to 6 years, subject to conditions; and

the appeal procedure is simplified and the deadlines for appeals are streamlined. Taxpayers may appeal against the tax administration's assessment decisions to the local rectification board within 3 years after the end of the tax year. In turn, a decision of the rectification board may be appealed to the regional administrative court within 60 days following the decision of the rectification board.

section.p: The transitional rules generally provide that the tax year ending on 31 December 2016 and the tax years ending on 31 December in the previous years are assessed under the law which prevailed at the time. Tax year 2017 is assessed according to the amended Law on Tax Procedure. The appeals for tax years ending on 31 December 2016 and before are handled under the rules applicable at the time, and the appeals for tax year 2017 - under the amended Law on Tax Procedure. However, once the first-level decision, e.g. a decision concerning the rectification for a tax year which ends on 31 December 2016 or before, has been issued, the subsequent process follows the amended rules (see section 1.11.3.).

section.title: Tax returns
section.p: A company must file a tax return on an accounting year basis, within 4 months from the end of each accounting year. The accounting year of a company ordinarily runs from 1 January to 31 December (calendar year) and the tax return is filed on or before 30 April of the following year. If the due date occurs on a weekend or a public holiday the tax return may be filed or mailed on the following working day. Companies whose accounting year does not correspond to the calendar year may file their tax returns within 4 months from the beginning of the calendar month immediately following the end of their accounting year. For example, if a company’s accounting period ends on 15 March 2022, the corporate tax return will be due on 31 July 2022. If several accounting periods end during a calendar year, the company must file a combined tax return for all of them. The tax administration issues instructions on the filing and information requirements for the tax return.

Companies must generally file their tax returns electronically using an online filing system (“MyTax service”), electronic data interchange or “Tyvi service”. Instructions in English are available at www.vero.fi.

A non-resident or a branch of a foreign company must submit its tax return to the tax administration via the online filing system. It is handled by the Corporate Tax Unit (Helsinki). If, as an exception, a non-resident files its tax return on paper because of a specific reason, such as "MyTax service" not being available, the tax return may be submitted to any tax office in Finland or a foreign embassy of Finland that will forward it to the Tax Office of Etelä-Suomi or Tax Office for Major Corporations.
The tax office may require a company to furnish additional information pertinent to its tax return.

A company is obligated to maintain accounting records in Finland for at least 6 years after the end of the calendar year in which the accounting year ended. (This time period corresponds to the maximum period for additional assessments levied by the tax authorities.)

section.title: Assessment
section.p: With effect from 1 May 2018, the assessment is finalized individually for each taxpayer. The date of the end of the assessment is stated on the assessment decision. If the company provides additional information or a revised tax return affecting its assessment before the end date of the assessment, the tax administration issues a revised assessment decision (section 49 of the VML).

Ordinary assessments must be completed by the end of October in the calendar year following the company’s tax year. However, for companies, the assessment must be completed within 10 months from the end of the last month of the accounting year (section 49 of the VML). If 2 or more accounting years end during the calendar year, the 10-month period runs from the end of the last month of the most recent accounting period. For example, if a company’s accounting year runs from 1 April 2021 to 31 March 2022, the tax return must be filed on 31 July 2022, at the latest. If mailed, the tax return must arrive by the due date of 31 July 2022 at the tax administration. The assessment will then be finalized on 31 January 2023.

Irrespective of the date of the assessment decision, the tax administration may extend the assessment period if it is required for the purposes of the audit or inspection. The tax administration must send a notification to the taxpayer prior to the end of the assessment period. The assessment is finalized on the date of the new assessment decision.

The assessment and tax audit, as well as any advisory work, for the largest companies engaged in international operations are concentrated at the Tax Office for Major Corporations. This tax office is located in Helsinki, but also companies resident elsewhere in Finland fall under its jurisdiction. It is authorized to assess both corporate income tax and VAT, to control the payment of withholding tax on wages, and to perform tax audits in all these tax areas.

The tax office may, for the final assessment, deviate from the tax return filed by the company, but the taxpayer is allowed to give an explanation with respect to disputed issues before any deviation takes place. If the tax return is considered unreliable, tax may be assessed on the basis of estimated income. The taxpayer has, however, an opportunity to provide additional information to support his original tax return. If no tax return is filed, the tax office can also make the assessment on the basis of estimated income, but the taxpayer has the opportunity to provide information on the correct amount of income (section 27 of the VML).

section.title: Appeals against assessment
section.p: If the assessment is incorrect, it may be corrected by the tax office. Any correction that is detrimental to the taxpayer must generally be made within 3, 4 or 6 years (for tax years that ended before 1 January 2017, within 1, 2 or 5 years from the end of the assessment year) from the beginning of the year immediately following the end of the tax year, depending on the prerequisites in the law. In contrast, corrections that are favourable to the taxpayer may be made within 3 years from the beginning of the year following the end of the tax year (sections 55, 56, 56 b of the VML).For tax years that ended before 1 January 2017, the correction time is 5 years following the year of assessment. With effect from 1 January 2017, in the case of certain criminal proceedings, an additional assessment may be carried out within 1 year from the end of the year in which the public prosecutor started the prosecution (section 56 c of the VML). The tax authorities must make the decision on the correction within the period stated in the law.

Unless the case has already been decided on appeal, a company which is dissatisfied with a final tax assessment may appeal to a rectification board. A company must file a rectification request to the rectification board, in general, within 3 years (before 1 January 2017, within 5 years) from the beginning of the year immediately following the end of the tax year. In turn, the tax authorities must file an appeal within 4 months (before 1 January 2017, within 1 year) (section 64 of the VML). If the rectification board agrees with the taxpayer, the tax administration rectifies the assessment (section 61 of the VML). In these cases, the tax administration may rectify the assessment to the extent it does not dispute the taxpayer’s appeal.

For example, for the tax year from 1 January until 31 December 2019, for which the assessment may be completed by the end of October 2020, the appeal for a correction must be filed by 31 December 2022, at the latest.

Any decision of the rectification board may be appealed to an administrative court, which is an intermediate administrative tribunal. With effect from 1 January 2017, the taxpayer and the tax administration must file the appeal within 60 days after the decision of the rectification board is handed down (sections 66 and 67 of the VML). The statute of limitation for the tax authorities is calculated from the date of the decision, and for the taxpayer from the date of the receipt of the decision. Before that date, the taxpayer was required to file the appeal within 5 years from the beginning of the year immediately following the end of the assessment year, while the tax administration was required to file the appeal within 1 year from the beginning of the calendar year following the end of the assessment.

The taxpayer and representative of the state may appeal the decisions of the administrative court to the Supreme Administrative Court within 60 days, but only if the Court grants permission for the appeal. Permission is granted only if:

item.p: the review is important in view of other similar cases or for uniform application of law;
there is an apparent mistake in the decision; or
exceptionally important economic or other reasons are involved.

section.p: However, if the Supreme Administrative Court grants permission, and if the counterparty agrees in writing, it is possible to appeal directly to the Supreme Administrative Court, without appealing first to the administrative court.
Appellate documents must be filed with the tax administration (sections 70 and 71 of the VML).

section.title: Payment of tax and refunds
section.p: Most company taxes are collected during the tax year through advance payments. The advance payment system is governed by the Law on Tax Procedure and the Precollection Law (EPL) and has two distinctive features:

item.p: withholding from wages, salaries and similar sources of income; and
preassessment and collection of estimated tax amounts with respect to business and other income.

section.p: Withholding taxes from wages, salaries, etc. are paid monthly using the online filing system ("MyTax service") on a self-assessment basis.

The preassessment of taxes on, for example, business income is carried out by the tax administration. Pre-assessed taxes are ordinarily established with reference to the taxpayer’s income in the previous ordinary assessment and match, as accurately as possible, the taxpayers’ final taxes for the entire tax year. The pre-assessed tax amounts for the relevant tax year may be changed until the company’s assessment has been finalized if it becomes evident that they will not match the final taxes (chapter 2, section 24 of the EPL). With effect from 2019, the tax authorities' decisions on pre-assessed tax amounts do not expire automatically and remain enforceable until the tax is paid or the decision is nullified following the taxpayer's application. Accordingly, where a pre-assessed tax amount is excessive, a taxpayer must submit an application, and claim the excessive advance taxes to be nullified.

Pre-assessed tax amounts for companies are collected in 2 or 12 instalments. If the total amount to be paid is not more than EUR 2,000, the instalments are due in the third and in the ninth month of the accounting period. If the total amount to be paid exceeds EUR 2,000, the instalments are due monthly from January to December for calendar year-based companies (section 2 of VEROH 967/2016).

Advance payments are credited against the taxpayer’s final taxes. If the final taxes exceed the advance payments, the difference is payable in the form of supplementary payments as stated in the final assessment decision by the tax administration. A non-deductible penalty interest is imposed on the supplementary payments at an annual rate of 2% in 2017-2022 (2.5% for 2014-2016). To avoid the penalty interest, the taxpayer must make the supplementary payment within 1 month following the end of the last month of the accounting and tax year. The supplementary payment is hence made on a self-assessment basis.

If the advance payments exceed the final tax assessed, the excess is refunded (plus an interest of 0.5% for 2017-2022) to the taxpayer when the final assessment for the taxpayer is completed (within 10 months following the end of the relevant tax year).

section.title: Late payment interest and penalties
section.p: If advance taxes paid by a taxpayer do not cover the final taxes assessed by the tax authorities, a non-deductible penalty interest is charged (section 40 of the VML). For details, see section 1.11.4.

If the assessed tax is paid after the due date or if the tax has been assessed outside of the ordinary assessment, interest is imposed on late payment of tax. The interest rate varies annually (7% for 2017-2022, and 7.5% for 2014-2016).

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, a support measure was introduced for unpaid taxes that were part of a repayment arrangement agreed with the tax authorities. With effect from 1 May 2021, the interest rate was reduced to 2.5% (from 7%) on unpaid taxes covered by payment arrangements already in place and new arrangements for which the application had to be submitted until 31 August 2021. The reduced rate applies until the end of the payment arrangement. The maximum duration is 2 years. With effect from 1 January 2018, a penalty of EUR 100 may be imposed for the late filing of a return.
If a tax return includes incomplete, inaccurate or incorrect information, and in the cases where a taxpayer fails to file a tax return, a penalty of up to 10% of the added income may be imposed.
If the taxpayer does not provide information requested by the tax authorities during the assessment or a tax audit, a penalty of up to 10% of the added income applies.

A penalty of up to 50% is calculated on the adjusted tax, based on an estimated assessment by the tax authorities, where a taxpayer failed to comply with his obligation to file tax returns (sections 32 and 32a of the VML), see also section 1.11.2.
None of the above-mentioned payments are tax deductible.

The Law on Tax Procedure (VML) includes penalties for filing fraudulent returns and other violations. Serious violations are punishable as fraud or embezzlement under the criminal law, for example by the imposition of fines or prison terms for a maximum of 2 years. In the most serious cases, the minimum prison term is 4 months and the maximum is 4 years. If the misconduct is not sufficiently serious to warrant imprisonment, fines are the only form of punishment imposed (section 86 of the VML; chapter 29 of the Penal Code). Administrative penalties may also be imposed.

section.title: Statute of limitations
section.p: Control and reassessment or additional assessment by the tax authorities may be made within the time limits discussed in section 1.11.3., i.e. within 3, 4 or 6 years from the beginning of the year following the end of the tax year (before 1 January 2017, within 1, 2 or 5 years from the end of the assessment year).

section.title: Rulings
section.p: Taxpayers may apply for advance rulings from the Central Tax Board (Keskusverolautakunta) on issues involving income tax, value added tax, taxation of non-residents, withholding tax on interest or insurance tax. Rulings are issued on matters that are considered to be important and that may set a precedent, and on those of significant economic value to the taxpayer. Rulings are issued ordinarily within a couple of months from the date of the request. They must be applied during the tax year in question and until the tax return for it must be submitted. While the Central Tax Board lays out the tax consequences of a proposed transaction upon the taxpayer’s request, it does not advise the taxpayer on how to minimize taxes. Hence, the formulation of the question is of crucial importance. A legal fee varying between EUR 980 and 4,200 is payable for advance rulings of the Central Tax Board (Decree 1135/2021, valid through 31 December 2024).

Decisions of the Central Tax Board are binding on the tax authorities, but not on the taxpayer. The taxpayer may freely choose whether it demands the tax authorities to apply the ruling. In order for the ruling to be binding there is a requirement that all relevant facts relating to the transaction have been disclosed. Both the authorities and the taxpayer may appeal an advance ruling to the Supreme Administrative Court (chapter 3 of the Law on tax administration, Laki verohallinnosta/Lag on skatteförvaltningen).

The tax administration, including the Tax Office for Major Corporations, issue advance rulings on matters involving income tax, value added tax, taxation of non-residents, withholding tax on interest, insurance tax, payroll withholding, inheritance tax, transfer tax, lottery tax and real estate tax (section 85 of the VML and chapter 3 of the Law on tax administration). The cost of an advance ruling issued by a tax office varies between EUR 255 and 2,520 (Decree 1135/2021, valid through 31 December 2024).

The most important difference between the advance ruling from the tax office and that from the Central Board of Taxation is the fact that only the tax office is permitted to rule on valuation matters. For example, an advance ruling on transfer pricing matters must be sought from the tax office if, as is often the case, a judgement on valuation is sought.

section.title: Tax audit/examination
section.p: Tax audits are performed at irregular intervals by tax auditors employed by the tax administration. Tax audits are normally integrated, which means that income taxes, VAT matters and salary withholdings are examined at the same time. Tax auditors are entitled to examine the accounts of a company and to request additional information which they deem necessary to the examination. Audits may take place at the taxpayer’s premises or elsewhere (section 14 of the VML; section 3 of the VMA).

The tax administration usually gives the taxpayer advance notice of an audit. However, in rare cases, they may conduct an audit without prior notice if they have sufficient evidence that the taxpayer is likely to destroy accounting records to avoid an additional assessment.

section.title: Dividends, interest and royalties
section.p: There is no obligation to withhold tax on dividend, interest and royalty payments to resident companies.

A resident company paying dividends and royalties to non-residents must withhold tax at source (for rates, see section 7.3.4.). The payer is obliged to give the recipient a certificate on income paid and tax withheld (section 5 of the LähdeVA). There is no obligation to withhold tax on interest, management fees and service fees paid to non-residents.

A Finnish permanent establishment of a non-resident company may be required to withhold tax on royalties paid to non-resident third parties, but not on payments to the head office (royalties paid to the head office are not regarded as expenses of the permanent establishment).

section.title: Subcontract payments
section.p: There are no obligations to withhold tax on payments to resident or non-resident subcontractors. Only where the subcontractor is regarded as an employee do the salary withholding tax obligations apply. Companies are usually registered in the entrepreneur register. Should a payment be made to a company acting as a subcontractor but which is not registered, a withholding tax of 13% is payable on the part of the payment which is remuneration for the work performance.
