No withholding tax is payable on goods sold by the subcontractor to the principal (section 15 of the EPA).

section.title: Fees for technical and other services
section.p: There is no obligation to withhold tax on technical, management or other service fees paid to non-resident companies. There is an obligation to withhold tax on royalties paid to non-resident companies, as described in section 7.3.9.

section.title: Other
section.p: Employers are required to withhold tax on salaries and any other type of compensation for employment. The tax offices issue tax cards to all individuals and the applicable withholding tax is set forth in the tax card. If no tax card is presented, the withholding tax rate is 60% (section 3 of the EPA). Employers remit the taxes withheld to the tax authorities and the amounts withheld are credited against the employees’ final taxes.

The general withholding tax obligations may apply to salaries paid by non-resident companies to employees who are residents for Finnish tax purposes if there are at least two employees regularly working for that company in Finland. There is also a reporting obligation for non-resident companies providing rental labour to Finland.
Employers must withhold social security contributions (i.e. health insurance, pension insurance and unemployment insurance) payable by employees (see section 4.2.).

section.title: Local income tax
section.p: No local taxes are levied on the income of a company. A portion of the corporate income tax collected is allocated to municipalities and the two state churches (see section 1.10.1.), but this has no direct effect on companies.

section.title: Business tax on income
section.p: No business tax on income is levied.

section.title: Other
section.p: A special tax, the TV tax, applies. The TV tax is aimed at financing Finland’s national public service broadcasting company.
Subject to the TV tax are companies, cooperatives, savings banks and foundations.
The following persons are exempt from the TV tax:

item.p: the state and the municipalities (including their public entities);
parishes of the state churches and religious communities;
entities exempt from taxation under the Income Tax Law; and
companies resident in the Åland Islands (instead of the TV tax, they are subject to a special media fee with effect from 1 January 2021 and the amount is the same as for the TV tax).

section.p: The annual tax for entities with taxable income of at least EUR 50,000 is EUR 140 plus 0.35% on the taxable income exceeding EUR 50,000. The amount of the tax is capped at EUR 3,000.
For a description on a tonnage tax regime available to qualifying shipping companies, see section 12.1.

section.title: Payroll tax
section.p: No payroll taxes are imposed on corporate taxpayers.

section.title: Social security contributions
section.p: Employers must make various social security contributions in respect of their employees:

item.p: a health insurance contribution;
an employment pension insurance contribution;
an unemployment insurance contribution; and
an accidental insurance contribution, including a group life insurance contribution.

section.p: Employers must make a health insurance contribution to the state to cover the costs of the national health insurance. The contribution is applied to the annual total amount of the gross remuneration paid to the employees, without a ceiling amount. The contribution is computed on the basis of the amount of monthly salaries paid. The rate for 2022 is 1.34% (1.53% in 2021) (Decree on Social Security Contributions).

In addition, employers must pay an employment pension insurance contribution of 17.40% (on average) (16.95% in 2021), an unemployment insurance contribution of 0.5% on the first EUR 2,197,500 in 2022 (0.5% on the first EUR 2,169,500 in 2021) and 2.05% on the excess in 2022 (1.9% in 2021) (Law 24.7.1998/555), and an accidental injury insurance contribution (including group life insurance) of approximately 0.76% of the employees’ annual gross wages and salaries in 2022. These types of insurance are usually purchased from private insurance companies. Private insurance companies give client rebates that vary on average between 0.25% and 0.5% of the employer’s total employment pension premiums and thus reduce the total premiums.
The social security contributions mentioned above and made by employers are deductible as business expenses.

An employment pension insurance contribution of 7.15% (8.65% if the employee is 53 to 62 years old, and 7.15% if the employee is 63 to 67 years old) and an unemployment insurance contribution of 1.5% (1.4 in 2021) of the employee’s salary income are collected from employees. These contributions are tax deductible for the employee. Employees must also make a health insurance contribution. In 2022, the health insurance contribution of 1.71% (2.04% in 2021) consists of two components, i.e. a 1.18% health care component and a 0.53% daily allowance component. Only the latter component is deductible for income tax purposes. The employee contributions are withheld by the employer and remitted to the relevant authorities.

A resident company and a permanent establishment of a non-resident company having foreign employees in Finland are required to pay premiums for the compulsory employment-related insurance, i.e. employment pension, group-life, accident and unemployment insurance. These forms of insurance are required regardless of whether the employees are seconded from abroad or reside in Finland. A resident company is also required to pay the employer health insurance contribution on salaries paid to foreign employees working in Finland (section 1 of the TyEL, and section 1 of the Law on Employer's Health Insurance Premium). However, a company can avoid the obligation to insure its employees and pay the employer health insurance contribution for employees seconded from abroad if a social security agreement exists between Finland and the country from which the employees are sent, or if the employees are seconded from an EEA country. In this case, a certificate for the seconded employee is needed to show that the employee remains insured in his country of residence.

A non-resident company that has employees in Finland is required to participate in certain compulsory employment-related insurance schemes, i.e. employment pension, group-life, accident, and unemployment insurance, regardless of whether the employees are seconded from abroad or reside in Finland. The obligation to insure employees does not depend upon the existence of a permanent establishment or representative of the non-resident company in Finland. However, the obligation to pay the employer health insurance contribution only arises when the non-resident company has a permanent establishment or a representative in Finland, which pays the salaries of employees in Finland. If the non-resident company has neither a permanent establishment nor a representative in Finland, which pays salaries, it has no obligation to pay the employer health insurance contribution.

section.title: Net worth tax
section.p: The net worth/wealth tax was abolished with effect from 1 January 2006.

section.title: Business tax on capital
section.p: No business tax on capital is levied.

section.title: Real estate tax
section.p: Real estate tax (kiinteistövero; fastighetsskatt) is levied on immovable property in Finland regardless of its function, except farm and forest land (sections 1 to 3 of the Real Estate Tax Law). Real estate tax is also levied on buildings situated on leased land, although such buildings are generally treated as movable property under the Finnish legal system (section 2 of the Real Estate Tax Law).

The real estate tax rate that applies to buildings used for residential purposes ranges between 0.41% and 1%. With effect from 1 January 2020, the real estate tax rates applicable to other kinds of immovable property range between 0.93% and 2%. A special rate between 2% and 6% may be applied to certain unbuilt immovable property within city zoning areas. In the metropolitan area, an addition of 3% to the general real estate rate must be applied on unbuilt land. However, the maximum may not exceed 6% of the taxable value of the property. Municipalities may set a rate of real estate tax that falls within these limits; the revenue collected belongs entirely to the municipality in which the immovable property is located (sections 11, 12 and 13 of the Real Estate Tax Law). Real estate tax is a deductible expense for corporate income tax purposes.

section.title: Shareholders and Directors of Resident Companies
Dividends in general
section.p: Until 1989 and with effect from 1 January 2005, Finland has applied the classical double tax system with some modifications. With effect from 1 January 2005, double taxation of dividends received is alleviated at the shareholder level under the participation exemption in section 6a of the EVL and section 33 of the TVL.

For corporate shareholders, dividends received are tax-exempt income with a few exceptions. For individual shareholders dividends received from a quoted company are either tax-free or taxable capital income. Dividends distributed by a private company are tax exempt, or taxed as capital or earned income.

A dividend is not defined in the tax law. Distributions which are treated as a dividend in the company law and which are based on shares owned and distributable earnings of the company are also dividends for tax purposes. Redemption of shares and liquidations are not treated as dividend distributions.
The distribution of assets by a quoted company from its free own capital is treated as a distribution of dividends.
The participation exemption for dividends applies to profit distributions by domestic cooperatives, savings banks, mutual insurance companies and insurance associations (section 6a.4 of the EVL)

topic.title: Dividends paid to non-resident shareholders
topic.p: Dividends paid to non-resident shareholders are generally subject to withholding tax (see section 7.3.4.1.).

section.title: Individual shareholders
section.p: The tax treatment of domestic dividends depends on whether or not the distributing company is quoted. A quoted company is defined in the Income Tax Law (section 33 of the TVL).
A distribution of 85% of dividends from a quoted company to a Finnish resident individual is taxed as capital income, while the remaining 15% is tax exempt.

When a non-quoted company distributes dividends, 25% of the annual dividends are taxed as income from capital and 75% are exempt up to EUR 150,000 per shareholder per year, provided the amount of the dividends does not exceed an 8% annual yield on the net worth of the company per share calculated according to the Law on Valuation of Assets for Taxation Purposes. Fifteen per cent of such dividends exceeding EUR 150,000, but within the 8% yield ceiling, is exempt, with the remaining 85% being taxed as the shareholder’s income from capital.
If the amount of dividends exceeds the 8% yield ceiling, 75% of the exceeding part of the dividends are taxed as earned income and 25% are exempt. Earned income is subject to progressive taxation.

Dividends from a resident quoted company to a resident individual shareholder are subject to advance withholding at a rate of 25.5%. Dividends up to EUR 150,000 from a non-quoted company to a resident individual are subject to an advance withholding tax at a rate of 7.5%. The rate of the advance tax is 28% on the amount of dividends exceeding EUR 150,000. The paying company must monitor the ceiling for each individual recipient (section 15 of the Pre-collection Decree: Ennakkoperintäasetus).

Dividends paid to non-resident individuals from resident companies are subject to taxation at source. The rate is normally reduced by the relevant income tax treaty. For domestic dividends, individuals resident in the European Economic Area benefit from the same tax treatment as resident individuals. Additionally, the dividends may be exempted from the domestic withholding altogether if certain requirements are met (see section 7.3.4.1.).

section.title: Substantial corporate shareholders
section.p: In general, dividends received by a resident corporate shareholder from another resident company are exempt (section 6a of the EVL).
However, dividends are taxable if they are distributed by a quoted company to a non-quoted company that holds directly less than 10% of the capital in the distributing company (portfolio dividends).

If the recipient company is a financial institution (i.e. a bank, pension or insurance company) holding the shares as investment assets, 75% of the dividends are treated as taxable income and the remaining 25% of the dividends are exempt. Investment assets are securities, immovable property and similar property acquired by financial institutions in order to make an investment or to secure it (section 11 of the EVL); see section 1.3.4.
For foreign-source dividends derived by resident companies, see section 7.2.1.3.; for dividends derived by non-resident companies from resident companies, see section 7.3.4.1.

section.title: Portfolio corporate shareholders
section.p: If the company (Oy) or a financial institution does not qualify for the participation exemption discussed in section 6.1.3., 100% or 75%, respectively, of the dividends received are treated as taxable income.
There is no withholding on dividend distributions between resident companies.

section.title: Hidden profit distribution
section.p: As regards the recipient, 75% of the hidden dividend constitutes taxable income both for companies and individuals. If the recipient is a corporate shareholder, the hidden dividend is deemed to be business income or other income. As regards individual shareholders, the taxable portion of the hidden dividend is deemed to be earned income and taxed at progressive rates.
A hidden profit distribution is not tax deductible for the payer, see section 1.4.4.

section.title: Individual shareholders
section.p: Individual shareholders who are resident for Finnish tax purposes pay tax of 30% on capital gains up to EUR 30,000 received from the sale of shares and 34% on the excess. The capital gain is the difference between the sales price and the purchase price. However, an individual shareholder is entitled to deduct as the purchase price 20% of the sales price, or for property owned for at least 10 years, 40% of the sales price. This rule was enacted for the benefit of the taxpayer, which means that any actual purchase price greater than 20% or 40%, respectively, of the sales price may be used. The sales expenses are tax deductible when the actual acquisition price is used, but not when a higher proportional acquisition value is used.
Capital losses may be carried forward for up to 5 years and deducted from future capital gains.
Capital gains derived by non-residents on shares in resident companies are exempt according to section 10 10-k of the Income Tax Law; see section 7.3.3.5.

section.title: Substantial corporate shareholders
section.p: Capital gains on shares are in most cases tax exempt; see section 1.7.5. For computation of capital gains and losses, see section 1.7.4. For treatment of capital losses, see section 1.8.2.
The payment of tax on capital gains may be deferred in certain cases, such as in a share-for-share exchange (see section 1.7.) or in the case of a merger (see section 9.2.).

For capital gains derived by resident companies from the disposal of shares of non-resident companies, see section 7.2.1.5.; for capital gains derived by non-resident companies from the disposal of shares of resident companies, see section 7.3.3.5.

section.title: Portfolio corporate shareholders
section.p: Gains derived by resident portfolio corporate shareholders which own less than 10% of the share capital in the target or which do not meet other requirements for the tax exemption under section 6b of the EVL are treated as taxable business or other income as described in section 1.7.5. The resulting taxable business income may be set off against business losses. Furthermore, it qualifies for group relief.

The deductibility of corresponding tax-deductible capital losses is generally limited to gains on shares treated as fixed assets during the tax year and 5 following years, as described in section 1.8.2.

section.title: Purchase by a company of its own shares
section.p: According to company legislation, a company is allowed to purchase its own shares, but not all of them, if the company has retained earnings which cover the acquisition price of the shares. The number of own shares held by a public company may not, however, exceed 10% of all its shares (chapter 15, section 11(1) of the OYL). Shares which are acquired in this manner and exceed the 10% threshold must be sold or invalidated within 3 years (chapter 15, section 12(2) of the OYL) (see Finland – Business and Investment – Country Surveys).
Companies other than public companies must divest their own shares within 1 year from the purchase.

A company may also redeem its own shares by decreasing the share capital of the company. This requires permission from the trade register. The shares must be invalidated and the company which made the redemption by decreasing its share capital may not distribute dividends in the subsequent 3 years, unless the share capital is increased back to the previous level by issuing new shares.

Income on the sale of shares is not taxable for the selling public or private company. The related acquisition cost of the company’s own shares is not tax deductible either, except when a public company disposes of its shares as a salary to employees. The public company may claim such a deduction during the tax year in which it disposes of the shares acquired from the stock market to its employees.

A redemption of shares may be regarded as a hidden profit distribution, especially if only part of the shares of each shareholder are redeemed. A redemption of all of the shares from one or more shareholders, to transfer the company, e.g. from father to son, is however usually not regarded as hidden profit distribution. For the tax treatment of hidden profit distribution, see section 6.1.5.

section.title: Liquidation
section.p: From the shareholder’s point of view, a liquidation is treated as a sale of shares and not as a dividend. Unless the liquidation proceeds are tax exempt (see section 1.7.5.), the shareholder pays corporate income tax on the difference between the consideration received in a liquidation and the acquisition price. For liquidation losses, see section 1.8.2.

section.title: Directors
section.p: Fees and salaries paid by a resident company to a resident or non-resident director for board meetings of the company or for any other services rendered in the capacity of the board member for the company are taxable in Finland, regardless of whether the meeting is held in Finland (sections 9 and 10 of the TVL).

As for resident directors, the fees are subject to the salary withholding tax and are included in the taxable income of the person. The employer’s social security contributions must also be paid on the fees, subject to conditions (see section 4.2.).
For non-residents, the ordinary withholding tax rate is 35%. However, the applicable tax treaty should be consulted, as some tax treaties may contain special provisions on directors’ fees.

section.title: Resident and non-resident companies
section.p: With effect from 1 January 2021, a definition of the concept of residence was introduced in the tax legislation. Accordingly, a company is a Finnish resident if it is registered in Finland, incorporated in Finland or has its place of effective management in Finland (section 9 of the TVL, and section 1 of the OYL), see section 1.1.5. Such companies are liable to tax on their worldwide profits.

Companies not included in the above-mentioned definition are treated as tax non-residents. Such companies are liable to tax on income from the Finnish sources only, unless the domestic law or the relevant treaty prevents Finland from taxing their income.

section.title: Definition under domestic law
section.p: Domestic legislation provides a definition of permanent establishment of a non-resident company, which is applicable unless a double tax treaty provides otherwise. According to the Income Tax Law (section 13a of the TVL), a permanent establishment is a place in which a specific business is permanently conducted or there are special arrangements for carrying on business, such as:

item.p: where the management is located;
where there is a branch, office, industrial plant, production plant, workshop or shop;
where there is another kind of place for buying or selling purposes;
where there is a mine, quarry, fuel peat swamp, or gravel pit; or
in construction business, where such a business is largely carried on.

section.p: The definition of a permanent establishment in the domestic law is very similar to that of most double tax treaties concluded by Finland.

According to the opinion of the tax authorities (VH/1642/00.01.00/2021) published on 19 April 2021, exceptional and temporary changes in the circumstances of a non-resident company (e.g. employees working from home) caused by the COVID-19 pandemic do not, generally, lead to creating a permanent establishment in Finland.

section.title: Definition under treaties
section.p: Finland applies the OECD Model definition of permanent establishment in most of its tax treaties. However, there are important exceptions, such as the treaty of 4 May 1996 with Russia, as amended by the protocol of 14 April 2000 and as modified by the MLI signed by Finland and Russia on 7 June 2017. Under that treaty (article 5(3)), a building site or construction, assembly or installation project or connected supervisory activities constitute a permanent establishment if the site, project or activities last, in the case of a site or project involving mainly the erection of factories, workshops, power stations or any other industrial buildings or structures, for more than 18 months and, in all other cases, for more than 12 months. The use of an installation or drilling rig or ship for the exploration for or exploitation of natural resources constitutes a permanent establishment if the rig or ship is used for more than 12 months.

section.title: General principles
section.p: Resident companies are taxed on their worldwide income. Non-resident companies are subject to tax on Finnish-source income only, provided that domestic law and the relevant treaty allow taxation.

section.title: Business profits
section.p: Companies are taxed on income regardless of whether it originates from Finland or elsewhere. Profits of permanent establishments in foreign countries are calculated according to domestic rules and the resulting double taxation is generally alleviated in Finland under the ordinary credit method or under the exemption method if the relevant treaty so provides.
The tax administration publishes instructions on Finnish international taxation which give guidance on treatment of foreign permanent establishments in addition to case law.

Income and the related expenses are allocated to the foreign permanent establishment as the taxpayer may not conclude transactions between the headquarters and the permanent establishment for civil law purposes. The allocation is a matter of evidence. To its annual tax return in Finland, the taxpayer must annex a profit and loss calculation of a foreign permanent establishment prepared according to Finnish tax rules.

Depreciation is calculated using the same rate the taxpayer has claimed for the tax year in question. In general, assets including inventory may be transferred from the resident head office to a branch without tax consequences. “Payments” to a branch are not deductible and “profit distributions” by a branch do not affect the taxation of the head office.

A business loss of a foreign branch is netted against business income in Finland unless it originates from a treaty country applying the exemption method to relieve double taxation. A foreign branch loss exceeding the taxable business income in Finland is carried forward as part of the business loss.

section.title: Dividends
section.p: Dividends received by a non-quoted resident corporate shareholder from a non-resident quoted company, where the resident shareholder holds less than 10% of the share capital of the distributing company, are taxable.
Dividends received by the quoted and non-quoted resident companies from an EU distributing company referred to in article 2 of the Parent-Subsidiary Directive (2011/96), are exempt.

In turn, dividends received by the quoted and non-quoted resident companies from the EEA distributing company, which is not a company referred to in article 2 of the Parent-Subsidiary Directive (2011/96), are exempt, provided that:

item.p: the distributing company is subject to at least 10% tax on the income from which the dividends are being distributed, and
the residence of the distributing company is in an EEA country and it is not outside of the EEA country under an applicable tax treaty.

section.p: If the above-mentioned conditions are not met, the dividends are taxable.

If the recipient company is a financial institution holding the shares as investment assets, 75% of the dividends are subject to corporate income tax of 20% and the remaining 25% of the dividends are exempt (see section 6.1.3.).
If the non-resident distributing company is none of the corporate entities discussed above, the dividends are taxable for both quoted and non-quoted recipient companies.
Distribution of assets by a quoted company from its free own capital is treated as distribution of dividends.

With effect from 1 January 2016, dividends received from non-resident companies are taxable if the paying company is allowed to deduct the dividends from its taxable income. If the dividends are partially deductible, only the deductible amount of dividends is treated as taxable income.

Tax treaties usually prevent the taxation of inbound subsidiary dividends also where the distributing companies are resident outside the European Union. In general, the dividend is treated as a subsidiary dividend if the recipient’s ownership is at least 10%. However, the limit should be investigated on a case-by-case basis in the applicable tax treaty.

Double taxation is avoided by applying domestic law or treaty provisions, whichever are more favourable to the taxpayer. For the credit for the withholding tax payable on dividends in the source country, see section 7.4.1.2.

section.title: Interest, royalties and other income
section.p: Interest and royalties derived by resident companies from sources outside Finland are taxable in Finland.
Fees, rents, etc. derived by resident companies from foreign sources are taxable in Finland. Double taxation is avoided by applying domestic law or treaty provisions.

section.title: Capital gains
section.p: Because resident companies are subject to tax on their worldwide income, capital gains derived from foreign sources are also subject to Finnish tax, with the exception regarding the sale of shares (see section 1.7.5.).

section.title: Foreign losses
section.p: Finland usually applies the credit method to avoid the double taxation of foreign-source business income. Therefore, all income derived by a foreign branch is also income in the hands of the head office and all costs paid by the branch are deductible by the head office. This means that the losses incurred by the foreign branch may be deducted by the resident head office.

If an exemption method applies pursuant to the terms of a treaty, the income and costs of the permanent establishment are excluded from the taxable base of the resident head office. As a result, the losses incurred by the foreign branch are not deductible in Finland under the Law on Elimination of International Double Taxation (section 7 of the KVPL).

With effect from 1 January 2021, a special group deduction applies, under which a resident parent company may deduct the final losses of its subsidiary (resident in another EEA state). See section 8.2.

section.title: Other taxes on income
section.p: There are no special taxes on foreign-source income. For a description of the tonnage tax regime available to qualifying shipping companies, see section 12.1.

section.title: Taxes on foreign capital
section.p: There is no net worth tax. Real estate tax is not levied on immovable property located abroad.

section.title: Emigration
section.p: Apart from the rules concerning SEs and European Cooperative Societies (SCEs), until 2020, Finland has not had specific rules on emigration of resident companies abroad or exit taxes of companies.

With effect from 1 January 2020, the EVL and the Law on Tax Procedure are amended to transpose the exit tax regime as provided in the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (2016/1164) (ATAD) into Finnish legislation. The exit tax rules apply to tax years or accounting periods, which end on or after 1 January 2020.

Under the exit tax regime, unrealized capital gains are taxed upon transfer of assets abroad. A taxpayer is subject to exit tax on an amount equal to the market value of the transferred assets (see below), at the time of exit of the assets, less their residual value for tax purposes, in any of the following circumstances (section 51e of the EVL):

item.p: a resident taxpayer transfers assets from its head office to its permanent establishment in another country and Finland no longer has the right to tax the transferred assets due to the transfer;

a non-resident taxpayer transfers assets from its permanent establishment in Finland to its head office or to another permanent establishment in another country in so far as Finland no longer has the right to tax the transferred assets due to the transfer;

a taxpayer transfers its tax residence to another country according to domestic law or relevant tax treaty; however, the residence transfer does not affect those assets which remain effectively connected with a permanent establishment in Finland;

a non-resident taxpayer transfers the business carried on by its permanent establishment in Finland to another country in so far as Finland no longer has the right to tax the transferred assets due to the transfer.

section.p: Provided that the assets are set to revert to Finland within a period of 12 months, the exit tax does not apply to asset transfers related to the financing of securities, assets posted as collateral or where the asset transfer takes place in order to meet prudential capital requirements or for the purpose of liquidity management.

The “market value” is the amount for which an asset can be exchanged or mutual obligations can be settled between willing unrelated buyers and sellers in a direct transaction as provided in section 18.2., points 3 and 5 of the EVL.
Possible reserves are added back to taxable business income to extent they do not relate to assets of a permanent establishment which remains in Finland or which will be created to Finland.

If assets, tax residence or business conducted by a permanent establishment are transferred to another EU Member State or to an EEA country a taxpayer shall be given the right to defer the payment of an exit tax, by paying it in instalments over 5 years provided the countries in question have concluded an agreement with Finland or with the European Union on the mutual assistance for the recovery of tax claims, equivalent to the mutual assistance provided for in Recovery Directive (2010/24).

If a taxpayer defers the payment of tax, interest is charged. If there is a demonstrable and actual risk of non-recovery, taxpayers may also be required to provide a guarantee as a condition for deferring the payment. This requirement may be waived in certain cases. The deferral of tax payment may be immediately discontinued and the tax debt becomes recoverable, in certain cases, as provided by law.

section.title: Double taxation relief
section.p: Under all tax treaties concluded by Finland, double taxation of dividends, interest and royalties is eliminated by the credit method. Credit is also granted for business income under the treaties concluded since the mid-1970s, while under the older treaties the exemption method applies until they are renegotiated.

section.title: Business profits
section.p: Foreign-source income may be derived directly or through a permanent establishment in the foreign country.

For the purposes of corporate income tax, foreign-source income is included in the company’s income, and tax is computed thereon in the normal manner. Double taxation is eliminated by crediting the tax paid on the foreign income in the source country. Only taxes paid to a foreign state qualify for the credit. Other taxes qualify for a credit if so provided under a treaty (section 3 of the Law on Elimination of International Double Taxation KVPL). The credit is computed separately for each source of income (per basket limitation).

The credit is limited to the amount of Finnish tax payable on the foreign-source income. Any unused credit may be carried forward to the following 5 tax years. Foreign income or withholding taxes are not deductible as business expenses.

entry.p: Foreign tax EUR 14,000; Finnish tax EUR 12,500; only EUR 12,500 may be credited; EUR 1,500 may be carried forward to the following 5 tax years.
Foreign tax EUR 9,000; Finnish tax EUR 10,500; the unused foreign tax credit of EUR 1,500 from the previous tax year may be utilized and credited; no Finnish tax payable on foreign income in year 2.

section.p: The foreign tax credit must be requested before the final assessment of Finnish tax is carried out. All necessary documents that show the amount of foreign tax and that it has been paid, must be filed to support the application. If, on the date of final assessment, the resident taxpayer has not yet paid the foreign tax, it may request a correction of the final assessment at a later date (section 8 of the KVPL).

section.title: Dividends
section.p: If foreign-source dividends are not exempt from tax in Finland under the provisions of the Business Income Tax Law discussed in section 7.2.1.3., they are included in the resident shareholder’s total taxable income, which is subject to tax at the ordinary rate. Unilateral relief from double taxation is granted in the form of a foreign tax credit. No credit for underlying foreign corporate tax is available.
If the dividend is exempt, Finland does not credit the withholding tax payable in the source country.

section.title: Interest, royalties and other income
section.p: There are no special rules governing interest, royalties, rents, etc. Such income is treated in the same way as business income (see section 7.2.6.1.).

section.title: Capital gains
section.p: There are no special provisions governing the unilateral relief for foreign taxes on capital gains. The same rules that apply to (ordinary) business income apply to capital gains.

section.title: General
section.p: For the definition of “non-resident company” and “permanent establishment of non-resident company”, see sections 7.1.1. and 7.1.2.

Companies are treated as non-residents if they are founded or registered abroad and are not effectively managed in Finland. If a non-resident entity carries out business activities in Finland through a permanent establishment, it is taxed on income attributable to such permanent establishment (sections 9(3) and 13a of the TVL and the relevant treaty provisions).
A branch must be registered in the Finnish trade register, see Finland – Business and Investment – Country Surveys.

section.title: Immigration
section.p: With effect from 1 January 2021, it became possible for foreign companies to immigrate to Finland when a definition of the concept of residence was introduced in tax legislation. Accordingly, a foreign company becomes a Finnish resident if it establishes its place of effective management in Finland (section 9 of the TVL and section 1 of the OYL). Such companies are liable to tax in Finland on their worldwide profits.

With effect from 1 January 2020, a valuation rule on the immigration of a non-resident company to Finland is provided in section 51(f) of the EVL. Under this rule, when transferring assets, tax residence, or business carried on by a permanent establishment to Finland, transferred assets are valued at the market value established by the transferring EU Member State of the taxpayer or of the permanent establishment as the starting value of the assets for tax purposes in Finland. Until 2020, apart from the rules concerning SEs and SCEs, Finland has not had specific rules on the immigration of non-resident companies.

If an SE or an SCE transfers its seat to Finland, its status changes from a non-resident company with a branch in Finland to a resident company that is taxable on its worldwide profits. As to the taxation of a European Company, a continuity principle is applied in the transfer of its assets, by virtue of section 52e of the EVL.

The taxable period begins on the date on which (i) business activities commence in Finland; or (ii) the non-resident entity becomes a tax resident due to having transferred its effective management to Finland. Any foreign branch or non-resident company with its effective management in Finland is required to report this date to the tax authorities. The first taxable period ends on the last day of the ordinary accounting period. A branch must have the same accounting period as its head office.
On 1 April 2021, the tax administration issued the instructions VH/8343/00.01.00/20 on the tax treatment of resident and non-resident corporations.

section.title: General
section.p: A non-resident company is taxed on income derived from Finnish sources. The Income Tax Law (TVL) defines the types of income deemed to be from Finnish sources. Of the types of income listed, the following are generally subject to tax in Finland (sections 9 and 10 of the TVL):

item.p: business income from business activities carried on in Finland;
dividends from Finnish companies;
royalties and similar income if based on property or rights used in business activities in Finland or if the licensee or lessee is a resident of Finland; and
income from immovable property located in Finland.

section.p: Interest received by a non-resident is exempt according to section 9.2 of the TVL. The only exception is interest on a loan which is deemed as equity. However, even this is exempt under the treaties concluded by Finland.

The Law on Taxation of Non-residents (LähdeVL) taxes the income of a non-resident by either imposing a withholding tax on the gross payment or by assessment. Income not subject to withholding tax or at the election of the non-resident (see section 7.3.4.) is taxed by assessment at the general corporate income tax rate (see section 1.10.1.) (section 4 of the LähdeVL). Examples of income not subject to withholding tax include income from immovable property and business income derived through a permanent establishment.

If dividends, interest or royalties are derived through a Finnish permanent establishment of a non-resident company, such income is included in the taxable profits of the permanent establishment and taxed as part of the business profits of the permanent establishment. Otherwise they are subject to withholding taxes unless exempt (see section 7.3.4.).

section.title: Business profits
section.p: Generally speaking, all income derived from Finnish activities and all costs, including general administrative costs incurred in the head office, which, under the relevant treaty, may be attributed to a permanent establishment in Finland, is allocated to it. Arm’s length conditions must be applied to transactions between the foreign head office and its branch in Finland even though the branch legally may not conclude contracts with the company to which it belongs (section 31 of the VML). In addition, the section 9 of the Income Tax Law provides that all such income which is attributed to the assets held by the Finnish permanent establishment must be allocated to the Finnish permanent establishment. The accounting treatment generally determines whether or not the asset is deemed to be part of the permanent establishment’s assets.

Branches of non-resident companies are treated for tax purposes as companies: the income attributable to the branch is subject to tax, costs attributable to the branch are deductible, and the tax rate is the general corporate income tax rate (see section 1.10.1.). Cost allocation between branch and head office should follow the arm’s length principle and all costs should clearly be connected to the activities of the branch. On the other hand, payments received from the head office are not taxable in the hands of the branch.

Interest on loans between a branch and its head office is not tax deductible. On the other hand, interest paid to third parties by either the head office or the branch is tax deductible if the loan benefits the business of the branch (and is therefore attributable to the branch). Similarly, royalty payments to the head office are not deductible from the income of the branch. However, if the head office pays royalties to third parties and these royalties are attributable to the activities of the branch, they are deductible from the branch’s income.
Profits may be freely transferred from a Finnish branch to its head office. There are no thin capitalization rules applicable to branches.

section.title: Dividends, interest and royalties
section.p: Dividends received by a Finnish branch of a non-resident company are exempt income in the same way as for a resident company according to section 6a of the EVL (see sections 6.1.3. to 6.1.5.). Interest and royalties on assets attributable to the branch are generally treated as taxable business income in the same way as for a resident company, and subject to corporate income tax.
If dividends, interest and royalties derived by a non-resident company do not pertain to a branch, they may be subject to withholding tax unless exempt (see section 7.3.4.).

section.title: Other income
section.p: Rents on immovable and movable property, fees and other income when attributable to a branch under the relevant treaty constitute taxable income for the branch in the same way as for a resident company.
These payments are not subject to withholding tax in Finland when received directly by a non-resident.

section.title: Capital gains
section.p: Capital gains arising from the sale of assets and immovable property are subject to Finnish corporate income tax and gains on shares are exempt in the same manner as for resident companies (see section 1.7.) if the seller is a Finnish branch of a non-resident company, provided that the assets, shares or immovable property belong to the branch. The capital gain on the sale of immovable property located in Finland is taxable, irrespective of whether the seller is a resident or a non-resident (section 10 of the TVL).

If shares of a Finnish company – other than a mutual real estate company – are sold and the seller is non-resident, the capital gains are not subject to Finnish tax. Capital gains on shares in a Finnish mutual real estate company are subject to tax in Finland (section 10 of the TVL). The gains on the shares in other real estate companies are generally exempted under the relevant income tax treaty.
If a resident company is liquidated, the capital gain derived by the non-resident shareholder is not taxable in Finland.

section.title: Dividends
section.p: EU and EEA residents are treated in the same way as resident shareholders when receiving dividends from Finland. The dividends are subject to withholding tax at the rate of 20%, unless an exemption or lower rate of 15% applies. If the treaty rate is lower, the recipient of the dividend may claim it. For domestic treatment, see sections 6.1.1. to 6.1.5. For treaty rates, see section 7.4.1.5.
The dividend is tax exempt (section 3(5) of the LähdeVL), if:

item.p: the non-resident company receiving the dividend is similar to a resident company in section 6a of the EVL and section 33d.4 of the TVL;
the dividend would be tax exempt for the resident company according to section 6a of the EVL and section 33d(4) of the TVL;
the recipient resides in the EEA;

there is a treaty on mutual assistance and exchange of information in force between Finland and the country of the recipient according to Mutual Assistance Directive (77/799) or otherwise (EEA countries, including, with effect from 1 January 2011, Liechtenstein);

the recipient may not fully credit the Finnish withholding tax under the relevant treaty in the country of residence, and the recipient provides evidence of that fact (e.g. a certificate from the tax administration).

section.p: The distribution of assets by a quoted company from its free own capital is treated as a distribution of dividends.

Dividends may also be exempt from withholding tax on the basis of the Parent-Subsidiary Directive (90/435). Under the domestic law implementing the provisions of the Directive (section 3(6) of the LähdeVL), as amended with effect from 1 January 2009, outbound dividends are exempt from withholding tax if the recipient is a company that qualifies under article 2 of the Directive and owns directly at least 10% of the capital of the paying company or such a company’s permanent establishment situated in another Member State (section 3 of the LähdeVL). No minimum holding period is required.

Under article 15 of the Savings Agreement of 26 October 2004 between the European Union and Switzerland providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in the Savings Directive (2003/48), the EU Member States must exempt dividend payments to qualifying recipients resident in Switzerland under essentially the same conditions as those laid down in the Parent-Subsidiary Directive (2011/96) (before the amendments effective from 1 January 2005; thus, a minimum holding of 25% for at least 2 years is required) (section 3(7) of the LähdeVL).
The reduced domestic withholding tax rate of 15% applies if the requirements for the exemption listed above are not met and (according to section 7(1)3k of the LähdeVL):

item.p: the non-resident recipient is a corporate entity, as defined in section 6a of the EVL or section 33d(4) of the TVL, which meets the requirements of section 3(5) of the LähdeVL;
the shares belong to its investment assets as defined in section 11 of the EVL; and
the non-resident recipient is a non-quoted company and not a company as defined in the Parent-Subsidiary Directive (2011/96) which owns less than 10% of the capital of the distributing company.

section.p: As the portfolio treaty rate is in most cases lower than the above-mentioned domestic withholding rates, the latter are rarely applied.
The procedure to claim other than treaty exemption requires a filing of a tax return in Finland.

section.title: Interest
section.p: Interest income derived directly by a non-resident from Finnish sources is exempt from tax under domestic law if the interest is paid in respect of (section 9(2) of the TVL):

item.p: bonds, debentures and other such debts;
deposits on bank accounts;
accounts originating from international trade; or
debt which is not equivalent to equity.

section.p: In practice, debt is only seldom regarded equivalent to equity. If interest is deemed to be a hidden profit distribution (see section 6.1.5.), withholding tax is levied on such payments (constructive dividends) at a rate of 20% or 15%, unless a tax treaty provides for a lower rate or an exemption.

section.title: Royalties
section.p: Royalties derived directly by a non-resident from Finnish sources are subject to withholding tax at source. The rate is 20%, unless a tax treaty provides for a lower rate or an exemption (section 3 of the LähdeVL) (see section 7.4.1.5.).

Under the domestic law implementing the provisions of the Interest and Royalties Directive (2003/49), (interest and) royalty payments are exempt from withholding tax, provided that the recipient is an associated company of the paying company and is resident in another Member State or such a company’s permanent establishment situated in another Member State. Two companies are “associated companies” if (i) one of them has a direct minimum holding of 25% in the capital of the other or (ii) a third EU company has a direct minimum holding of 25% in the capital of the two companies. The relevant companies must have a legal form listed in the Annex to the Directive and be subject to corporate income tax. No minimum holding period is required (section 3b-f of the LähdeVL).

Under article 15 of the Savings Agreement of 26 October 2004 between the European Union and Switzerland providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in the Savings Directive (2003/48), Finland exempts royalty payments to Swiss companies under essentially the same conditions as those of the Interest and Royalties Directive (2003/49). It should be noted, however, that royalties are exempt also under the tax treaty between Finland and Switzerland.

section.title: Other income
section.p: Profit shares distributed by resident investment funds are treated as dividends and are subject to the same withholding tax rules as dividends above; see section 7.3.4.1. (section 3(2) of the LähdeVL).

The withholding tax may only be levied in Finland where a tax treaty’s “Other income” article allows the source state to levy a withholding tax; otherwise in treaty situations such distributions are exempt. Under the treaty with Germany, however, the dividend rate and treatment are applicable.
Service and management fees, rents, lease payments, etc. are not subject to withholding tax in Finland. Rents and lease payments are not treated as royalties.

section.title: Withholding procedure
section.p: Resident companies paying dividends or royalties to non-residents must withhold tax on these payments whenever appropriate (see sections 7.3.4. and 7.4.). The withholding tax must be paid to the tax office by the 12th day of the following month. The resident company is liable for failure to pay the proper amount or failure to pay such amount on time. Interest and penalties of up to 30% of the amount of the unpaid withholding tax may be imposed on late payments or upon the company’s failure to pay (section 8 of the LähdeVL). For the interest rate, see section 1.11.5.

The company withholding the tax must give a payment receipt certificate (certificate on final tax in Finland) to the non-resident recipient (section 5 of the LähdeVA). The certificate should state the type of income, year of payment, name of the recipient, the amounts of income and final tax in Finland and the name of the payer.

Interest income derived by a non-resident from Finnish sources is usually exempt from tax under domestic law (see section 7.3.4.2.). The company paying the interest is not required to withhold the tax on interest if the non-resident recipient provides the payer with sufficient information to be able to identify the recipient as a non-resident (i.e. the name, date of birth and address in residence state). No particular form is used.

If excess tax has been paid in Finland by a non-resident recipient, refund may be claimed from the tax administration. The application must be filed within 3 years immediately following the payment year (section 11(2) of the LähdeVL). The time limit is 5 years for dividends that have been paid in 2016 at the latest. An informal application must include the information that should have already been given to the original payer. A certificate on payment should be attached. The same applies if a Finnish payer has not been able to take into account the exemption granted to qualifying EEA recipients as described in section 7.3.4.1.

A special regime applies to dividends paid to non-residents on nominee-registered shares (shares of Finnish companies that are not registered under the name of the beneficial owner but as held by a nominee). If the payer of the dividend has diligently ensured that the recipient is resident in a state with which Finland has a tax treaty, a rate reduced to 15% (or the higher treaty rate) is applied instead of the general 20% rate (which is applied if the recipient is resident in a non-treaty state). If the treaty provides for a rate lower than 15%, the payer may apply the lower rate only if complete information on the nominee-registered beneficial owner of the dividends has been provided.

section.title: Branch tax
section.p: There is no branch profits tax. The profits distributed from a branch to the head office are not subject to withholding tax.

section.title: Other taxes on income
section.p: There are no other taxes on the domestic income of non-residents.

section.title: Taxes on capital
section.p: There is no net worth tax. Non-resident companies are subject to real estate tax (see section 5.3.) on their immovable property located in Finland.

section.title: Closure of branch/permanent establishment
section.p: For treatment of transfer of assets, see section 7.2.5. Closure is deemed to be the last business transaction of the branch and all assets transferred to the head office are valued according to their fair market value at the time of the closure. A branch may be converted to a subsidiary in Finland without additional tax consequences by utilizing the tax rules on transfers of assets. The rules were enacted on the basis of the Merger Directive (2009/133) and they require, inter alia, that the head office of the branch be located in an EU Member State.

section.title: Administration
section.p: A branch of a non-resident company must file the tax return electronically with the tax administration; a paper return may be filed in exceptional circumstances, as defined.
See section 1.11.1. for details on tax administration.

section.title: Treaty policy
section.p: Finland has an extensive network of double taxation treaties in the areas of income and capital taxes. The treaties are based on the OECD Model.

Under all tax treaties concluded by Finland, double taxation of dividends, interest and royalties is eliminated by the credit method. Credit is also granted for business income under treaties concluded since the mid-1970s, while under older treaties exemption applies until such treaties are renegotiated.
Tax sparing credits are available in many treaties with developing countries (see section 7.4.1.6.2.).

section.title: Treaty relief from double taxation
section.p: To be entitled to apply a reduced withholding tax rate under a treaty, the payer must verify (i.e. the non-resident recipient should give the identity information to the payer) whether the recipient resides in a treaty country and a lower withholding tax rate applies. The payment procedure is similar to that applied to payments to recipients who reside in non-treaty countries (see section 7.3.4.5.).

If excess tax has been paid in Finland by a non-resident recipient, refund may be claimed from Finnish tax authorities (i.e. the payer’s tax office or Corporate Tax Office of Uusimaa (Uudenmaan yritysverotoimisto)). An informal refund application must include the information that should have already been given to the original payer. A certificate on payment should be attached.

section.title: Tax treaties in force
