section.title: The Nordic Conventions
section.p: The Nordic countries (i.e. Denmark, including Greenland and the Faroe Islands, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden) have a long history of legislative co-operation and share a social and cultural background. This has enabled them to conclude multilateral agreements with each other in various fields. It differs, however, from one agreement to another which countries have concluded the agreement in question. Another factor affecting the applicability of the Nordic Conventions is that only Denmark, Sweden and Finland belong to the European Union. However, Norway and Iceland are part of the EEA.
The relevant Nordic Conventions are listed below:

The Income and Capital Tax Treaty (signed on 23 September 1996, entered into force on 11 May 1997, and became effective from 1 January 1998) as amended by Protocols signed on 6 October 1997, 4 April 2008 and 29 August 2018. The treaty has been concluded by Denmark, the Faroe Islands, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden. Greenland is not included in the treaty but has concluded separate tax treaties with Denmark, Iceland and Norway. Denmark, the Faroe Islands, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden have signed on 29 August 2018 a new amending protocol to the Treaty, which became effective on 1 January 2020. The amending protocol implements the minimum standards as entailed in the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project and, hence:

item.p: amends the preamble are modified to express the fact that the Treaty aims to eliminate double taxation without creating opportunities for non-taxation or reduced taxation through tax evasion or avoidance including through treaty-shopping arrangements aimed at obtaining reliefs provided in the Treaty for the indirect benefit of residents of third states;
introduces a Principal Purpose Test (PPT) to article 26(4); and
enables a person to apply for a mutual agreement procedure (MAP) under article 28(1) with the competent authority of any of the contracting states.

section.p: The Inheritance and Gift Tax Treaty (signed on 12 September 1989, entered into force on 19 August 1992 and became effective from 18 October 1992). The treaty has been concluded between Denmark, Finland and Iceland. Sweden and Norway were also included in the Treaty, but Sweden terminated it with effect from 24 August 2007 and Norway with effect from 22 August 2014. In consequence, the Inheritance and Gift Tax Treaty is no longer effective for relevant transfers, etc. between Sweden/Norway and the other signatory states. The Inheritance and Gift Tax Treaty does not cover the Faroe Islands and Greenland.

The Nordic Social Security Agreement was signed on 12 June 2012 and entered into force with respect to Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden on 1 May 2014. The Agreement entered into force in respect of the Faroe Islands and Greenland on 1 May 2015. The entry into force dates are also the effective dates of the Agreement.

The Nordic Social Security Agreement was concluded in order to provide a wider personal coverage than that provided by the former EU Regulations (Social Security Regulation (71/1408) and Social Security Regulation (72/574)). Whereas the EU Social Security Regulations applied only to employed and self-employed persons and the family members of such persons, the Nordic Social Security Agreement extends to persons outside the labour market (e.g. students and pensioners). As the former EU Regulations have been replaced by the Social Security Regulation (2004/883) with effect from 1 May 2010, and this new Regulation covers, inter alia, all EU nationals, there was an overlap in the personal scope of the EU Regulation and the Nordic Social Security Agreement. Thus the former Nordic Social Security Agreement concluded on 18 August 2003 was replaced by a new one. The new agreement complements Social Security Regulation (2004/883) and extends its scope to also cover the Faroe Islands, Greenland and nationals of third countries residing in the Nordic countries.

The Mutual Assistance Treaty (signed on 7 December 1989, entered into force on 8 May 1991 and became effective on 9 May 1991). The treaty has been concluded by Denmark, the Faroe Islands, Finland, Greenland, Iceland and Norway, and concerns provisions dealing with mutual administrative assistance in tax matters. The scope of the treaty is very wide: it covers not only national income and capital taxes and municipal taxes, but also inheritance and gift taxes, VAT, car taxes, excise duties and social security contributions. Article 2 of the treaty should be consulted for the detailed list of the taxes covered by the treaty with respect to each jurisdiction.

The treaty enables automatic exchange of information between the contracting states, concerning individuals and legal entities in respect of, inter alia, credit balances with banks, payments of dividends, interest and royalties, and ownership of immovable property. Requests and documents regarding assistance may be drawn up in Danish, Norwegian or Swedish, or be accompanied by a translation into one of those languages.

section.title: General
section.p: Company and tax laws recognize three types of groups:

item.p: for company law purposes (chapter 1, section 5 of the KPL), if a company holds a sufficient amount of the shares in another domestic or non-resident company, so that the holding represents more than 50% of the voting right or otherwise can exercise control, the former company is deemed to be a parent company and the latter a subsidiary;
for group contribution purposes, the parent company must own directly, or through subsidiaries at any tier, at least 90% of the capital in a subsidiary (tax group); and
for VAT purposes, companies in the financial or insurance sector can form a group (see section 13.2.1.).

section.p: Only companies (and not, for example, partnerships) may be included in a tax group ((2) above). Generally only domestic companies may become members of a tax group. Non-resident companies may be, in certain cases, intermediate companies, but do not qualify as payers or recipients of group contribution except for their branch in Finland.

A tax group has no minimum period of existence. However, the benefits available to a tax group may be obtained only if the necessary holding was achieved in the previous tax year (see section 8.2.). The existence of a qualifying ownership structure is reported in the tax return. There are no registration requirements for a tax group.

The members of a tax group do not file consolidated tax returns and the taxable income of the members is not consolidated for tax purposes. The consolidation of taxable income is achieved by paying and receiving group contribution during the tax year from one company to another. Group contribution may be deducted by the paying company from its business income and is taxable income in the hands of the recipient.

section.title: Consolidated income
section.p: The concept of consolidated income tax return is unknown in Finnish tax law, although a group of companies for company law purposes is required to prepare a consolidated balance sheet. The same result may, however, be achieved through group contributions.
According to the Group Contributions Law (KonsAvL), contributions between resident companies may be deducted under the following conditions (sections 2-5, 7 of the KonsAvL):

item.p: the resident company (parent company) has owned, either directly or indirectly, during the entire tax year, at least 90% of the shares of another resident company (subsidiary);
both companies are engaged in business and are not financial, insurance or pension institutions;
the accounting year of the paying and receiving companies ends on the same date, unless the Accounting Committee has granted an exception;
the contribution is recorded in the annual accounts of both companies and affects their annual net income; and
the contribution is not a mere capital investment.

section.p: With effect from 1 January 2021, the law has been extended to foreign companies that are treated as Finnish tax residents.

Group contributions, subject to the conditions stated above, are allowable expenses for the paying company and part of the taxable income of the receiving company. A group contribution may not exceed the net taxable business income of the paying company and may not be part of losses to be carried forward for tax purposes by that company (sections 4, 6 of the KonsAvL).

Allowable group contributions are ordinarily made between a parent company and its subsidiary. However, they may also be made between two resident subsidiaries. Although both the paying and receiving companies must carry on business activities and may not be mere passive entities, such as holding companies, indirect ownership through passive group companies is also considered when determining whether a qualifying 90% ownership exists.

Under the Group Contributions Law, passive group companies must also be resident companies. However, several decisions of the Supreme Administrative Court have considered non-resident intermediate companies or even non-resident parent companies to qualify, when determining the minimum ownership, on the basis of non-discrimination provisions of the applicable tax treaty. Nevertheless, a payment of a group contribution to a non-resident subsidiary or to a non-resident parent company is not tax deductible.

The ownership structure must be in force from the first day of the accounting period of both payer and recipient. This means that if shares in another company are acquired, group contribution is not an allowable expense during the acquisition year. Only if a subsidiary is a new company established during the accounting year is group contribution possible. Generally, the accounting year must end on the same date for both the payer and the recipient. If, for instance, a company is merged into another company during the accounting year, a group contribution is not possible between the companies in that tax year.

The decision to pay a certain amount of group contribution must be recorded in the minutes of the paying company’s board meeting during the tax year. Necessary entries in the accounts of both payer and recipient must be made, at the latest, when the books for the accounting year are closed.

It is not necessary to pay the group contribution in cash during the tax year or the following tax years. The group contribution receivable may be offset by reverse group contribution or by offsetting it against accounts payable in the recipient company.

If the recipient has loss carry-forwards to be deducted from taxable income, and the deduction is only allowed on the basis of a special authorization granted by the tax office (see section 1.8.1.), group contribution received is not available to cover the loss carry-forwards.

With effect from 1 January 2021, through the introduction of the Law on Deducting Final Loss of EEA Subsidiary (Laki Euroopan talousalueella sijaitsevan tytäryhtiön lopullisen tappion konsernivähennyksestä; Lag om ett tilläggsavdrag för forsknings- och utvecklingsverksamhet under skatteåren 2021–2025; EtaTappioL), a resident parent company may deduct final losses of its subsidiaries that are resident in another EEA state. This is achieved by way of a special group deduction from its taxable income. The deduction is only granted if (i) the parent company holds at least 90% of the shares of the foreign subsidiary; and (ii) the subsidiary has been dissolved through liquidation. The group deduction the parent company may take corresponds to the final loss made by its EEA subsidiary but may not exceed the taxable profits of the parent company in the relevant year.

section.title: Intercorporate dividends
section.p: For treatment of intercompany dividends, see sections 6.1.3. and 7.2.6.2.
According to a decision of the Supreme Administrative Court (KHO 1999 T 254) a subsidiary may distribute interim dividends to a parent company under the following conditions:

item.p: the recipient of the dividends is the parent company (as) of the company distributing dividends or otherwise has influence in the company;
the recipient company has informed the distributing company that it will require a certain amount of dividend in the annual shareholders’ meeting;
a decision concerning the distribution of interim dividends has been adopted in an extraordinary shareholders’ meeting; and
the decision has been ratified by the annual shareholders’ meeting.

section.p: The interim dividend is tax-free income for the parent company for the year in which the decision concerning the distribution of interim dividends is adopted. The possibility to use interim dividends also for tax purposes means that a dividend flow through to the ultimate parent company may be made during 1 year instead of having to wait for dividends to be distributed the following year from adopted financial statements. The interim dividends may be used, for instance, in situations where a group contribution (see section 8.2.) is not possible (e.g. by financial institutions or if the conditions for a group contribution are otherwise not satisfied).

section.title: Intercorporate transfers
section.p: All transactions between group companies must be made at arm’s length and may trigger capital gains taxation. Only where an entire business is transferred to another company may the transfer be carried out at book values if the special tax rules on transfer of business apply (see section 9.4.). Gains on transfers of shares are generally exempt (see section 1.7.5.). However, if another group company has previously suffered a tax-deductible loss in connection with the sale of the shares that the other group company transfers forward tax exempt, the part of the capital gain corresponding to the earlier loss is taxable income in the hands of the second transferor.
In addition, share exchanges may be carried out without triggering the taxation of capital gain (see section 9.3.).

section.title: Partial and total dissolution
section.p: If a company is sold or otherwise disposed of in such a way that the ownership and other requirements for the group contributions are not met, it may not give or receive a group contribution during the relevant accounting period. A sale or other disposal of one group company may also prevent group contributions between the remaining group members if the disposed company was in a passive position required for the group contribution, see sections 8.1. and 8.2.

There are no applicable recapture provisions in the tax law. From the tax perspective, group contributions are not required to be returned or paid in cash after the dissolution. A departure from a group may trigger other tax consequences for the departing company, such as a loss of its tax loss carry-forwards.

section.title: Assessment and administration
section.p: The group contribution must be reported in the tax returns of both the payer and the recipient for the tax year in which it was paid. Because group taxation is not applied as such, no single company is required to file a consolidated tax return or otherwise comply with reporting requirements for the whole tax group. All companies are responsible for their own tax payments and all income taxes are assessed by the tax authorities on each company. There is no joint tax responsibility.

section.title: Restructuring and Liquidation
section.p: The provisions of the Merger Directive (90/434) were generally implemented with effect from 1 January 1996. Finland has also implemented the Amending Directive to the Merger Directive (2005/19). The changes took effect for the tax year 2007.

section.title: Change of business entity
section.p: According to the Income Tax Law (section 24), single proprietorships and partnerships may be converted to companies without triggering the taxation of unrealized gains. The assets of the entity must be transferred to a new company using book values as transfer prices. No goodwill is recognized as taxable income in the conversion. The tax values of the assets remain unchanged in the conversion and the new company continues, for example, to depreciate the assets in the same manner as the previous entity.

The owner of a single proprietorship or the partners in a partnership must become shareholders in the new company. After the conversion, the company may accept new shareholders. Loss carry-forwards are also transferred to the new company in the conversion.

A company may not be converted to another entity, such as a general or limited partnership. The company must be liquidated first and then the assets transferred at current fair market value to the new entity.

A permanent establishment of a non-resident company may be converted into a resident company without triggering the taxation of unrealized gains. However, this favourable treatment applies only if (1) the conversion meets the requirements of the regulations governing the transfer of a business (see section 9.3.) and (2) the permanent establishment was a branch of a company that resides in an EU Member State.

section.title: Companies
section.p: The Company Law and the Business Income Tax Law provide for two basic types of tax-neutral company mergers, variations of which may be devised (chapter 16, section 2 of the OYL; sections 52a and 52b of the EVL). In all mergers, at least one of the companies will cease to exist. According to section 52a of the EVL a merger means an operation whereby:

item.p: one or more companies, on being dissolved without going into liquidation, transfer all their assets and liabilities to another company in exchange for the issue of new or existing shares to their shareholders representing the capital of that other company, and, if applicable, a cash payment not exceeding 10% of the nominal value, or, in the absence of a nominal value, of the accounting par value of those shares;

a company, on being dissolved without going into liquidation, transfers all its assets and liabilities to the company holding all the securities representing its capital to a company owned by the latter company.

section.p: The acquiring company and the absorbed company are treated separately for tax purposes until the merger is registered in the trade register (section 52b of the EVL). Consequently, a company that is absorbed must prepare annual accounts and file a tax return for the period ending on the registration date, which becomes the official date of merger.

A merger is treated as a general succession. When companies merge, the assets and liabilities of the absorbed company are treated for tax purposes in the same manner by the acquiring company. For example, inventory and fixed assets are taken over by the acquiring company at the values shown in the books of the absorbed company. Deductible expenses are set off against income for the acquiring company in the same manner as for the absorbed company. The losses of the absorbed company are carried forward, provided that the combined holdings of the acquiring company and its shareholders have, since the beginning of the loss year, exceeded 50% of the shares in the absorbed company. The imputation tax credit of the absorbed company is also carried forward, provided that the combined holdings of the acquiring company and its shareholders have, since the beginning of the loss year, exceeded 50% of the shares in the absorbed company.

Profits resulting from a merger are not taxable and losses are not deductible by the merged companies (sections 52a and 52b of the EVL). Taxation is deferred until the assets are sold or assigned by the acquiring company. A merger qualifies for a tax exemption (or deferral) even if the shares (assets) of the absorbed company are exchanged, in addition to shares of the acquiring company, for cash. However, the cash consideration may not exceed 10% of the nominal value of the shares of the acquiring company (section 52a of the EVL).

Divisions qualify for special tax treatment under the Business Income Tax Law (section 52c of the EVL). The current law provides for two kinds of tax-neutral divisions, i.e. the complete division and the partial division. The complete division is a transaction in which one company transfers, without being dissolved, its entire business (assets and liabilities) to two or more existing or newly created companies for newly issued or existing shares in such companies for pro rata issue to its shareholders of shares representing the capital of the companies receiving the assets and liabilities. For purposes of the EVL, divisions are recognized even if the shares (assets) of the divided company are exchanged, in addition to newly issued or existing shares of the acquiring or receiving companies, for cash. However, the cash consideration may not exceed 10% of the nominal value, or in absence of a nominal value, of the accounting par value of the newly issued or existing shares of the acquiring company or companies (section 52c of the EVL). The partial division is a transaction in which the company undergoing a division will retain at least one business and one or more independent businesses will be transferred to a company that will continue those businesses.

The tax treatment of divisions is the same as that for mergers. The assets, liabilities, reserves, losses, etc. of the divided company are treated for tax purposes in the same manner by the acquiring companies as they would have been treated by the divided company. Taxation is deferred until the assets of the divided company are alienated by the acquiring company or companies. The acquiring companies, in principle, share in the reserves, book values of fixed assets, losses, unused imputation credits, etc. of the divided company that may not be attributed clearly to a certain branch of activity or certain assets, in the same proportion that they share in the net property of the divided company.

The tax provisions governing mergers and divisions also apply where they are implemented between companies that reside in different EU Member States. The special provisions for tax exemption of mergers and divisions do not apply if the sole or principal purpose of the merger or division is tax avoidance (section 52g of the EVL).

For purposes of the transfer tax, the transfer of immovable property and securities in connection with a merger or a division has been deemed not to constitute a taxable transaction (sections 4, 15 of the VSVL).

section.title: Shareholders
section.p: In general, there are no tax consequences to shareholders of companies involved in a merger or division, as long as the merger or division qualifies for tax-free treatment under Finnish law. The consideration paid to the shareholders of the alienating company need not consist exclusively of newly issued or existing shares of the acquiring company or companies: up to 10% of the consideration may be paid in cash. To the extent that cash is paid, the shares of the alienating company are deemed to have been sold for tax purposes (sections 52b, 52c of the EVL).

An exchange of shares in a merger or division for newly issued shares of the acquiring company or companies is not regarded as a disposal for purposes of capital gains tax. Capital gains taxation is deferred until the shares acquired in the exchange are sold (sections 52b, 52c of the EVL).

section.title: Companies
section.p: Tax law recognizes tax-neutral share exchanges. An exchange of shares is a transaction in which a company (acquirer) purchases shares of another company (target) and ends up with more than 50% of the voting power of the target, provided at least 90% of the consideration paid to the target’s shareholders consists of newly issued or existing shares of the acquirer. This means that no more than 10% of the consideration may be paid in cash (section 52f of the EVL). To the extent that the consideration consists of shares of the acquirer, the exchange of shares is not deemed to be a taxable transaction either to the company or its shareholders.
The special provisions that provide for the tax-free treatment of share exchanges do not apply if the sole or principal purpose of the exchange is tax avoidance (section 52g of the EVL).

section.title: Shareholders
section.p: The exchange of shares is not deemed to be a taxable transaction and does not trigger capital gains taxation (of the shareholders who give up their shares) if the cash consideration does not exceed 10% of the nominal value of the newly issued shares. To the extent that cash is paid, the shares alienated in the transaction are deemed to have been sold for tax purposes (section 52f of the EVL) and the capital gain is subject to tax.

If the shares received in the exchange are sold, the acquisition value of the shares for the purposes of capital gains tax is the tax value of the original shares. If a shareholder of the other company receiving shares of the purchasing company becomes, within 3 full calendar years after the exchange, resident in another country under the Finnish domestic law or tax treaty, any untaxed gain becomes taxable in the hands of the shareholder.

section.title: Purchase of an existing business
section.p: The purchase of a business may be carried out under Merger Directive (2009/133) rules governing transfers of assets and by selling the shares subsequently. Under section 52d of the EVL, a transfer of assets is a transaction in which a company transfers either all its assets, liabilities and reserves or those relating to one or more of its independent branches of activities, to an existing or newly created company in exchange for newly issued or existing shares of the latter. The receiving company must continue the business that is transferred to it, but the transferring company need not necessarily continue its business.

A transfer of assets is tax neutral. For the seller, the transfer price is the tax book value and the transferee continues with the same values in its taxation. Tax-free treatment does not apply, however, if the sole or principal purpose of the reorganization is tax avoidance (section 52g of the EVL).

If, in connection with the transfer of a business, immovable property or securities of the transferring company are transferred to the company continuing the business and the latter paid transfer tax, it may, upon application within 3 years, obtain a refund of the tax (section 43 of the VSVL).

section.title: Company
section.p: For liquidation provisions in company law, see Finland – Business and Investment – Country Surveys.

When a company is liquidated, the company is deemed, for the purpose of taxation of the company itself, to have sold its inventory, fixed and other assets at fair market value. In other words, the company is taxed on fictitious capital gains equal to the difference between the book value and the market value of the assets at the moment of liquidation (section 51d of the EVL). Generally, only immovable property and securities may have a market value that is above the current book value of the assets. No deemed goodwill value, e.g. on business relations, customer lists or market know-how, is evaluated and taxed at the liquidation.

section.title: Shareholders
section.p: Liquidation proceeds are tax exempt on the conditions described in section 1.7.5. In all other circumstances the liquidation proceeds are taxable, in which case the difference between the liquidation proceeds received by the shareholders and their original investment is taxed as a capital gain in the hands of the shareholders. The capital loss is generally not tax deductible; see section 1.8.2.
If the shares of the other company are not part of the parent company’s business assets, the capital gains are taxed as “other income” according to the Income Tax Law.
Non-resident shareholders are generally not taxed on the share of the liquidation proceeds.

section.title: General anti-avoidance rules
section.p: The tax authorities and tax courts apply the principle of substance over form as stated in the tax legislation (e.g. section 28 of the VML). If they conclude that there is no or not an adequate business reason underlying a transaction between group companies, or if they believe that a transaction is given a legal form which does not correspond to its actual character, they consider the transaction to be void for tax purposes and tax it as if the real form had been used. For company law and for other legal purposes, the transaction in its original form may still be valid.

If it is clear that a company has paid, as salary, housing benefit, entertainment, insurance etc. to its shareholder more than the amount that would have been reasonable, or if the company pays the shareholder interest, lease payments, commissions and the like, in an amount which exceeds that ordinarily paid by the company to third parties, tax is assessed on the amount which the tax authorities and courts deem to be in excess of the reasonable amount. The income stipulated by this tax rule in the Law on Tax Procedure is called hidden profit distribution. For the tax treatment, see section 6.1.5.

If the tax authorities conclude, based on section 31 of the VML, that the arm’s length principle has not been observed in transactions between group companies, the taxation may be corrected and reassessment may be made to reflect the arm’s length conditions. Subsidiaries and branches of non-resident companies are treated as companies owned by residents.

section.title: The Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive
section.p: On 21 July 2016, the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (2016/1164) (ATAD) was adopted. This Directive applies to all taxpayers subject to corporate income tax (including permanent establishments of companies based in third countries) and contains several rules to prevent tax avoidance. The ATAD was later amended by Amending Directive to the 2016 Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (2017/952) (ATAD 2 – see also section 10.6.1.), which amends the ATAD to address hybrid mismatches involving third countries.
Below is an overview of the implementation status of the ATAD in Finland:

section.title: Statutory framework
section.p: With effect from 1 January 2022, section 31 of the VML has been amended to allow for non-recognition of a controlled transaction between related parties or to disregard it according to the OECD Guidelines.

If, in a transaction between a taxable person and a related party, terms or conditions differ from those which would have been agreed between independent parties and the taxable income related to the taxable person’s business or other activities has been reduced (or the loss has been higher than it would otherwise have been), the amount that would have accrued if the terms corresponded to what would have been agreed between the independent parties will be added to the taxable income of the taxable person.

When assessing, in accordance with the arm’s length principle, whether terms or conditions agreed or imposed in a controlled transaction differ from those which would be agreed on in an uncontrolled transaction, the relevant commercial or financial relations and the economically relevant characteristics affecting those relations are identified. These include contractual terms, functions, assets and risks of the parties, characteristics of the property or service, economic circumstances of the markets and parties and their business strategies. The transaction will be determined based on these characteristics.

If, in exceptional circumstances, a related-party transaction differs from what would have been agreed between economically sound independent parties in similar circumstances, it may be disregarded and, if necessary, replaced by another arm’s length transaction.

The parties to a transaction are related if one party to the transaction has control over the other party, or in case the third party, alone or together with its related parties, has control over both parties to the transaction. A party has control over the other party when:

item.p: it directly or indirectly holds more than half of the capital of the other party;
it directly or indirectly holds more than half of the voting rights of all the shares or units of the other party;
it has the right, directly or indirectly, to appoint more than half of its members to the management of another entity or to a comparable body or body having that right; or
it is jointly controlled with another party or it may otherwise effectively exercise control over the other party.

section.p: The arm’s length principle also applies to transactions between a company and its permanent establishment.

section.title: Documentation and disclosure requirements (including penalties)
section.p: Provisions (section 14(a)-(c) of the VML) requiring transfer pricing documentation took effect for accounting periods starting on or after 1 January 2007. The law generally applies to foreign-owned subsidiaries and branches in Finland and Finnish groups that have 250 employees or more and a turnover exceeding EUR 50 million, or total assets greater than EUR 43 million. The groups are defined in section 6 of the KPL.

topic.title: Rules applicable in tax years 2007-2016
topic.p: According to section 14(b) of the VML, the transfer pricing documentation was required to contain the following:

item.p: ownership structure;
a description of associated enterprises;
information on controlled transactions and transactions between the company and its permanent establishment;
a functional analysis of controlled transactions and transactions between the company and its permanent establishment;
a comparability analysis, including available information on comparables; and
a description of the transfer pricing method and its application.

topic.p: If the total amount of controlled transactions between a resident company and a non-resident controlled enterprise did not exceed EUR 500,000 in a tax year, the documentation had to include items (1) to (3) only.

Small and medium-sized enterprises were generally exempt from the documentation requirements if they fulfilled the relevant criteria recommended by the European Commission (Commission Recommendation of 6 May 2003 concerning the definition of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, 2003/361/EC).

The transfer pricing documentation had to be submitted within 60 days of a request by the tax authorities, but no earlier than 6 months from the end of the financial year in question (section 14(c) of the VML). The tax authorities had the right to request additional information to supplement the transfer pricing documentation; such information had to be provided within 90 days of the request.

If the documentation was insufficient or missing, a penalty of up to EUR 25,000 applied. Where transfer prices were reassessed, the taxpayer may have been liable for a penalty of up to 10% of the adjusted income and for a variable-rate annual penalty interest (section 32 of the VML).

topic.title: Rules applicable in tax year 2017 and onwards
topic.p: According to section 14(b) of the VML, the transfer pricing documentation must include the following information regarding the group:

item.p: ownership structure;
description of business;
description of operation relating to intangible assets;
description of financing activity;
financial statements or similar documentation; and
description of advance pricing rulings and agreements (APAs) relating to cross-border allocation of income among countries.

topic.p: The transfer pricing documentation must contain the following information regarding the taxpayer:

item.p: description of the organizational structure and management structure;
information on business;
description of related-party relationships;
information on related-party business transactions and transactions between the enterprise and its permanent establishment;
functional analysis of the related-party transactions and of the transactions between the enterprise and its permanent establishment;
comparability analysis and information on available comparables;
description of the transfer pricing method and its application;
financial statements or similar documentation; and
APAs concerning related-party transactions that the taxpayer has concluded and that Finland has not issued or to which Finland is not a contracting party.

topic.p: The group-wide information may be limited to an independent business area that the taxpayer belongs to provided that the relevant data can be extracted. However, the centralized functions and transactions must be included.

The group-wide information listed in points (1)-(6) above is not required if the total amount of transactions between the taxpayer and all of its counterparties does not exceed EUR 500,000 during a tax year.

The taxpayer-specific information listed in points (5)-(7) above is not required if the total amount of transactions between the taxpayer and its counterparty in those transactions does not exceed EUR 500,000 during a tax year.

Small and medium-sized enterprises are generally exempt from the documentation and disclosure requirements if they fulfil the relevant criteria as provided by the European Commission (Commission Recommendation of 6 May 2003 concerning the definition of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, 2003/361/EC).

The transfer pricing documentation must be submitted within 60 days of a request by the tax authorities, but no earlier than 6 months from the end of the financial year in question (section 14(c) of the VML). The tax authorities may request additional information to supplement the transfer pricing documentation; such information must be provided within 90 days following the request.

If the documentation is insufficient or missing, a penalty of up to EUR 25,000 may be imposed. Where transfer prices are reassessed, the taxpayer may be liable for a penalty of up to 30% of the adjusted income and for a variable-rate annual penalty interest (section 32 of the VML).

topic.title: Country-by-country reporting
topic.p: Country-by-country (CbC) reporting applies to resident taxpayers and to permanent establishments of non-resident entities that are members of multinational enterprises (MNEs) with a global turnover of EUR 750 million during the preceding tax year.

The CbC report must be filed within 12 months from the end of the relevant tax year. The data to be included corresponds to the data listed in OECD BEPS Action 13 and Annex 3 of the Final Report. If the tax administration does not receive the relevant data through the information-sharing mechanism, the taxpayer is required to provide such data. However, the resident taxpayer that is not the ultimate or the surrogate parent entity in the MNE group is only required to provide the data at its disposal. On 30 June 2021, the tax administration published updated instructions, VH/3086/00.01.00/2021, online at www.vero.fi.

The taxpayers are required to provide the name, address and tax identity code of the reporting MNE and the country to which the report is given by the end of the accounting period or tax year that will be reported. However, regarding tax year 2016, the information must have been provided by the end of May 2017.
The reports must be filed electronically.

If the taxpayer has not filed the CbC report on time or if it is essentially incomplete or erroneous, or if the taxpayer has not notified the tax administration of the reporting MNE, as well as in the case of its refusal to provide the required information, the tax administration may impose a tax penalty of up to EUR 25,000.

section.title: Transfer pricing methods and practice
section.p: According to section 14b(2)7k of the VML, a company must describe the transfer pricing method and its application (a financial analysis). There is no other reference in the tax law to the permitted transfer pricing methods. Hence, the matter is ultimately left to case law. The case law on methods is sparse but one should expect a total valuation of the case and its merits.

In the updated statement VH/1189/00.01.00/2021 of 21 April 2021, the tax administration endorses the OECD Transfer Pricing Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and tax administrations (OECD Guidelines), and states that they will be used as guidance when interpreting the arm’s length principle in section 31 of the VML. They will also be used in the assessment of cases from prior years provided that the updated texts of the OECD Reports are not in fundamental conflict with the OECD Guidelines applicable at the time of filing of the relevant tax return, nor in conflict with the taxation practice and case law that prevailed during the relevant tax year.

The updated instructions VH/44/00.01.00/2022 of 28 April 2022 (currently in Finnish and Swedish only), issued by the tax administration, endorse the methods under the OECD Guidelines and discuss the most appropriate one in more detail.

There are several recent decisions of the Supreme Administrative Court (KHO), which give guidance on the interpretation of the OECD Guidelines (e.g. KHO 2013:36, KHO 2014:119, KHO 2017:146, KHO 2018:173, KHO 2020:34, KHO 2020:35, KHO 2021:73 and KHO 2021:127).

section.title: Corresponding adjustments
section.p: Economic double taxation caused by a transfer pricing adjustment can be mitigated under Finland’s income tax treaties that contain a provision similar to article 9(2) of the OECD Model or other appropriately worded provisions. Within the European Union, cases of economic double taxation caused by a transfer pricing adjustment can also be dealt with under the Arbitration Convention (90/436). The Arbitration Convention (90/436) was first applicable with respect to the 15 old Member States. With respect to the 10 EU Member States that acceded to the European Union on 1 May 2004, a new Accession Convention was signed on 8 December 2004 (EU Official Journal, C 160, 30 June 2005) and implemented in Finland by means of Law 411/2006, effective from 1 September 2006. The Arbitration Convention (90/436) entered into force in relation to Bulgaria and Romania on 1 July 2008.

section.title: Secondary adjustments
section.p: If, for example, a foreign country adjusts its transfer pricing rules by reducing purchase prices for companies residing in the foreign country, resulting in economic double taxation, the Finnish counterparty has the following options:

item.p: ordinary appeal process according to chapters 5 and 6 of the VML;
unilateral relief procedure under section 89(3) of the VML;
right to request an initiation of a mutual assistance procedure under the relevant income tax treaty; and
EU arbitration.

section.p: The preconditions vary, but in principle, in the three latter cases, the tax authorities have a right to pursue an appropriate outcome. A successful appeal requires an error or similar condition.

section.title: Limitations on interest deductibility
section.p: There are no official thin capitalization rules. For the general limitation on the deductibility of interest expenses, see section 1.4.5.

A general limitation on the deductibility of interest expenses between related parties applies (section 18a of the EVL). Section 18a of the EVL was revised with effect from 1 January 2019 due to implementation of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (2016/1164) (ATAD). Among other changes, the costs of obtaining financing were added to the definition of interest expenses.

The general limitation applies to directly or indirectly related companies or general and limited partnerships, resident in Finland or abroad. Companies and general and limited partnerships which are “independent”, i.e. which are not part of a consolidated group or affiliated to one, are exempted from the application of the revised provisions. The limitation does not apply to financial, insurance and pension institutions. In addition, (i) loans to finance long-term infrastructure investments, (ii) financial companies and (iii) corporate entities are exempted from the scope of the limitations subject to requirements stated in section 18b of the EVL. Examples of such long-term infrastructure investments include construction of public housing, and with effect from 1 January 2022 onwards, construction of roads, railways, waterways, and provision of public services.
Interest expenses are, however, deductible up to the amount of interest income (section 18a of the EVL).
Furthermore, a safe harbour rule applies, under which net interest expenses exceeding interest income are deductible up to EUR 500,000.

Net interest expenses on loans between related parties exceeding EUR 500,000 are deductible up to a maximum of 25% of earnings before interest expenses, taxes, depreciation and amortization for tax purposes, but after received group relief (adjusted EBITDA for tax purposes). For the calculation of the threshold of EUR 500,000, both related- and third-party interest expenses are taken into account. Where the net interest expenses exceed EUR 500,000, the limitation applies to the entire amount of these expenses.

For the purposes of interest deduction limitation, parties are treated as related if one party has direct or indirect control over the other party or if a third party has control over both parties. The direct or indirect ownership or control limitation was reduced from 50% to 10% of the share capital or voting power over the other party with effect from 1 January 2022 onwards.
A loan from a third party is treated as a loan from a related party if:

item.p: a related party has a receivable from a third party and the receivable is connected to the loan; or
a receivable of a related party serves as a pledge for the third-party loan.

section.p: An interest payment, even if treated as non-deductible for the debtor, is treated as taxable interest income for the resident or non-resident creditor.

The above-mentioned rules on interest deductibility do not apply if the entity can demonstrate that its equity-to-balance-sheet ratio is equal to or higher than the corresponding ratio of the adopted audited consolidated group balance sheet which has been prepared in either an EU/EEA state or a country with which Finland has a tax treaty. The balance sheets subject to comparison must be prepared using the same accounting principles and they must have been audited as of tax year 2022 onwards.

With effect from 1 January 2019, the general limitation on the deductibility of interest expense is extended to cover also interest on loans from unrelated parties (companies or general and limited partnerships). The same rules as in the case of interest expense on loans between related parties apply, except that under the safe harbour rule, for loans from unrelated parties, interest expense is deductible up to EUR 3 million. However, the limitation does not apply to: (i) loans concluded before 17 June 2016 even if the underlying money transfer was made at a later stage; and (ii) interest expenses included in the depreciation and amortization costs before 1 January 2019 (section 18a of the EVL).
Non-deductible net interest expenses may be carried forward indefinitely.
It is possible to file an appeal concerning the amount of non-deductible net interest expenses.

The deductibility of interest may not be denied in a discriminatory manner, provided there is an income tax treaty in force between the creditor’s country and Finland and if it contains a relevant non-discrimination rule.
Interest paid on a subordinated loan the purpose of which is to strengthen the equity position of the borrower is deductible when recorded in the accounts.

section.title: Controlled foreign company
section.p: With effect from 1 January 2019, the CFC Law is amended, among others, to implement the EU ATAD. The amended Law applies to tax years or accounting periods, which end on or after 1 January 2019.

According to the CFC Law, a resident taxpayer (company, individual or a partnership), who is a shareholder or a beneficiary of a non-resident corporate entity (alone or through related entities or individuals), is taxed on the income of the non-resident entity regardless of whether or not the income is distributed to the taxpayer if:

item.p: the taxpayer alone or through related entities or individuals holds a direct or indirect participation of at least 25% of the voting rights, or owns directly or indirectly at least 25% of the capital of the non-resident entity, or is entitled to at least 25% of the yield of the entity’s assets (section 2 of the CFC Law); and
the effective rate of tax in the entity’s jurisdiction of tax residence is less than three fifths of the Finnish corporate income tax rate, i.e. 12% (3/5 × 20%) (section 2 of the CFC Law).

section.p: The CFC Law applies to non-resident taxpayers only if the CFC income earned by a non-resident relates to a permanent establishment, which the non-resident according to Finnish domestic law has in Finland.
The following entities or individuals are treated as related to the resident taxpayer when calculating the 25% affiliation:

item.p: an entity or an individual who holds directly or indirectly a participation in terms of voting rights or capital ownership of at least 25% in the resident taxpayer, or is entitled to at least 25% of its profits;

an entity in which the taxpayer holds directly or indirectly a participation in terms of capital ownership and voting rights of at least 25%, or is entitled to receive at least 25% of the profits of that entity;
an entity which is related to the taxpayer through an individual or another entity that holds directly or indirectly a participation of at least 25% in the taxpayer and the first entity; or
if the taxpayer is an individual, specified relatives and their spouses.

section.p: In calculating the income on the basis of which it is determined whether the effective rate of tax is less than three fifths of the Finnish tax rate, dividends received by the CFC from another CFC are not taken into account, provided the dividends are distributed from profits that, during the 5 previous years, have been included in the tax base in determining the effective rate of tax (section 2 of the CFC Law).

The CFC Law is not applied to entities residing in the EEA if such an entity has in reality been established in the EEA state, it resides there, and it conducts an economic activity there supported by staff, equipment, assets and premises, see below (section 3 of the CFC Law).
However, for entities resident in jurisdictions outside of the EEA, in order to be excluded from the scope of CFS anti-tax avoidance rules, it is also required that:

item.p: the relevant jurisdiction has not been included in the EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions for tax purposes at the end of the tax year, and at the end of the immediately preceding tax year;
there is an agreement on exchange of information in tax matters between Finland and the relevant jurisdiction which ensures adequate exchange of information that is actually carried out;
it has been substantiated that entity’s income has mainly been derived from industrial or comparable production activities or similar services or from shipping activities in that jurisdiction;

it has been substantiated that the entity undertakes sales or marketing activities in its jurisdiction of tax residence that directly support the industrial, comparable production activities, or comparable services or shipping activities there; or

it has been substantiated that the entity which belongs to the same group as the aforementioned entities and is a resident in the same jurisdiction mainly generates its income from payments received from these entities.

section.p: The entity is deemed to have its tax residence and to have been established in the relevant jurisdiction and to conduct economic activity there when, considering the nature of its activities:

item.label: (a)
item.p: it has premises, fixed and financial assets there necessary to conduct its business;

item.label: (b)
item.p: it has adequate personnel there authorized to conduct its business independently; and

item.label: (c)
item.p: the personnel decides independently on matters concerning the daily operations of the entity.

section.title: Closely held company
section.p: There are no special rules governing closely held companies. The provisions regarding hidden profit distribution are also applicable to transactions between a closely held company and its shareholders (see section 6.1.5.).

section.title: Hybrid mismatches
section.p: Generally, the goal of the legislation combating hybrid mismatches is to neutralize the effects of arrangements that exploit differences in the tax treatment of an entity or instrument under the laws of two or more countries.

Within the European Union, Member States are obliged to implement, through the ATAD, as amended by ATAD II (see also section 10.1.1.), into their domestic law the anti-hybrid rules that address such mismatches between Member States, as well as between Member States and third countries.
For more information on the rules regarding hybrid mismatches as contained in the ATAD, see European Union – Direct Taxation – Global Topics section 3.4.5.
Finland has implemented the hybrid rules contained in the ATAD into its domestic law.
With effect from 1 January 2022, Finland has also implemented the rules regarding reverse hybrid mismatches.

section.title: Taxation of Special Types of Entity
Holding company
section.p: There are no special tax provisions that are targeted at holding companies. However, the tax treatment of a holding company depends in part on whether the holding company is deemed to be carrying on a business. The different tax treatment of holding companies and companies carrying out business activities is due to special provisions in various laws and to the fact that income resulting from business activities is subject to tax under the Business Income Tax Law (EVL) and other income is taxed under the general Income Tax Law (TVL).
The following examples may illustrate the different tax treatment of holding companies and companies carrying on business:

item.p: a group contribution (see section 8.2.) is tax deductible only if made between companies carrying on business activities;
a transfer of assets (see section 9.4.) from one company to another receives special tax treatment only if the transferring company carries on business activities.

section.title: Partnership
section.p: General and limited partnerships (see Finland – Business and Investment – Country Surveys) are transparent for tax purposes (sections 15 and 16 of the TVL). Every partnership is, however, required to file an annual tax return and the taxable income of a partnership is computed in general in the same manner as that of a company. However, partnerships do not themselves pay income taxes. The income of the partnership is considered to pass to each partner and the latter is assessed on his share of the partnership’s income, regardless of whether or not it is actually distributed to him.

Each partner is required to report in his tax return his share of the partnership’s income, as well as any salary, interest or other remuneration received from the partnership. The distribution of the partnership’s profits does not trigger additional taxable income in the hands of the partners because that income has already been taxed at the partner level at the time it was earned by the partnership.

Individuals who are partners pay tax at the rate of 30% (34% on income exceeding EUR 30,000) on the income allocated to them from the partnership to the extent that the allocated income does not exceed 20% annual yield computed on the net worth of the partnership (section 40 of the TVL). The rest of the income is taxed at ordinary progressive tax rates.
Losses of general and limited partnerships are deducted on the partnership level and may not be deducted from other income of the partners.

section.title: Economic interest grouping
section.p: Resident partners of an economic interest grouping (see Finland – Business and Investment – Country Surveys) are taxed in the same manner as partners in general and limited partnerships (see section 11.2.). There is one difference: losses incurred in an economic interest grouping are allowed to be deducted from the other income of the partners during the loss year (section 16a of the TVL).

section.title: Association and cooperative
section.p: Associations (see Finland – Business and Investment – Country Surveys) are often non-profit organizations whose income is exempt from tax (see below). If associations have business income, it is taxed in the same manner as the business income of companies. Cooperatives (see Finland – Business and Investment – Country Surveys) are treated like companies for tax purposes. Even profit distributions from cooperatives to their members are taxed like dividend distributions.

section.title: Non-taxable entities
section.p: There are certain entities which are defined to be non-taxable in the Income Tax Law (section 20). These entities, which do not pay income tax even if they may have business income, include inter alia:

item.p: Bank of Finland, Finnish Broadcasting Company, Nordic Investment Bank, Nordic Development Fund (Pohjoismaiden kehitysrahasto), Nordic Environmental Finance Company (Pohjoismaiden ympäristörahoitusyhtiö), Finnvera Oyj, Teollisen yhteistyön rahasto Oy, Ekokem Oy Ab, Suomen itsenäisyyden juhlarahasto, rahoitusvakausrahasto and talletussuojarahasto;

Social Insurance Institution, Keva, sairaus- ja hautausavustuskassa, employee funds, erorahasto Central Unemployment Fund, työttömyyskassojen keskuskassa, työttömyyskassojen tukisäätiö, valmennusrahasto and urheilijarahasto;
a company established by a municipality for housing purposes; and
investment fund, Special Mutual Fund and Sub-Fund.

section.p: These entities are usually owned or financed by the state. Moreover, their activities are usually of a social nature. Investment funds are tax exempt because the owners of the funds are taxed on the income received through the fund. If the funds were also taxed, the result would be double taxation of the income.

In addition, there are certain entities that are exempt from state tax. These entities are nevertheless required to pay municipal and church tax (total rate 6.26%) mainly on their business income (sections 21 and 124 of the TVL):

item.p: the state and state institutions;
Veikkaus Oy (Pools Office); and
municipalities and provinces, and their pension insurance institutions.

section.p: In addition, the two state churches are required to pay income tax to municipalities at approximately 5.7%, mainly on their business income (sections 21 and 124 of the TVL).

Non-profit associations are liable for income tax on their business income (section 23 of the TVL). The business income is computed in the same manner as that for companies and is subject to the general corporate income tax rate (see section 1.10.1.). There are certain types of income of non-profit associations that do not fall under the definition of business income (section 23 of the TVL) and that are not taxed in the hands of the association:

item.p: income from lotteries, bazaars, sporting events, entertainment, etc. to finance the activities of the association;
income from membership bulletins;
income from the sale of cards, patches, banners and other membership materials;
income from the sale of goods or services manufactured or supplied by persons who are patients in hospitals and nursing homes, by prisoners, etc.; and
income from bingo games.

section.p: A public company conducting the rental of property (REIT) may be exempted from income tax provided certain strict conditions for the scope of its operations, dividend distribution, debt/equity ratio and control are met. The shareholders are taxed on the dividend distribution.

section.title: Taxation of Special Types of Activity
Tonnage tax
section.p: The tonnage tax regime is governed by the Tonnage Tax Law (Tonnistoverolaki; Lag om tonnageskatt – the references below are to this law), enacted on 5 June 2002. The regime was substantially amended, on 1 March 2012, see below. The amendments apply from tax year 2011. The regime constitutes a form of state aid approved by the European Commission.

Resident shipping companies carrying out international transport of goods or passengers may elect, instead of the normal corporate income tax regime (based on actual profits), to be taxed based on the total net tonnage of the company’s ships. Once a company has elected the tonnage tax regime, it commits itself to the regime for a (renewable) period of 10 years (section 5).
For tonnage tax purposes, the tax base is computed as follows (section 9.):

The tax base is calculated by multiplying the daily rate, which is established by reference to the net tonnage of a vessel, by the number of days of the year (365).

Apart from resident companies that are effectively managed from Finland, Finnish permanent establishments of international shipping companies resident in other EU Member States qualify for the regime. In addition to ships owned and operated by the company itself, ships held or chartered out on bareboat or time charter basis qualify. However, at least 20% of the gross tonnage of the shipping company must consist of vessels by which the shipping company itself exercises passenger traffic and carries freight. In addition, there are certain conditions as to the composition of the company’s fleet aiming at preventing that companies not genuinely operating in/from Finland be granted the benefits of the regime (section 2).

It is irrelevant whether the ship is actually operated on each day. As the regime applies also to ships chartered out to be operated by another resident company, the same vessel may become subject to the tonnage tax simultaneously twice. The regime allows no deductions, and depreciation does not affect the tonnage tax.

The tonnage tax regime applies only to income pertaining to international transport of goods and passengers and activities directly relating thereto. Any other income of the shipping company, such as from sales to passengers of goods not to be consumed on board the ship, is subject to ordinary corporate income tax assessment (section 7).
Under the regime applicable before 1 March 2012, income subject to the tonnage tax was exempt from ordinary taxation until distributed.

section.title: General
section.p: With effect from 1 June 1994, Finland adopted the value added tax (arvonlisävero; mervärdesskatt), replacing the partly cumulative turnover tax. Finland amended the VAT Law (AVL) substantially, with effect from 1 January 1995, to conform with the Sixth VAT Directive (77/388), when it became a member of the European Union.

The province of Åland’s status as a third country was confirmed by a special law which entered into force on 1 March 1997. Although it has a special status, Åland is considered to be a part of Finland and Finnish VAT laws apply in that province.

As the VAT system imposes significant burdens on registered entrepreneurs, the law allows taxpayers to obtain advance rulings on VAT matters from tax offices, and in more important cases, from the Central Tax Board (Keskusverolautakunta). In addition, a person engaged in or planning to engage in an activity which may entail VAT liability may apply for an advance ruling. Advance rulings concerning customs duties are issued by the Customs authorities (Tulli).
The application for an advance ruling must concern a specific, non-theoretical matter. An advance ruling is binding on the tax authorities for a fixed period of time.

Advance rulings may, subject to the restrictions discussed in section 1.11.3., be appealed to the Supreme Administrative Court. A tax office ruling must, however, first be appealed to the Administrative Court of Helsinki (Helsingin hallinto-oikeus).

section.title: General
section.p: In principle, all resident entrepreneurs who are engaged in the commercial supply of goods or services are subject to VAT and are required to register for VAT purposes. However, supplies of selected goods and certain services are exempt. The system is based on self-assessment by registered entrepreneurs. Entrepreneurs are required to pay VAT when they use their own products for private purposes or give their products as free gifts (self-supply).
The following persons are subject to VAT (sections 2, 2a, 2b and 86 of the AVL):

item.p: entrepreneurs who, in the course of business, supply taxable goods and services in Finland and are therefore registered for VAT purposes;
all persons who import goods (with minor exceptions);
non-resident entrepreneurs who supply taxable goods and services in Finland unless the reverse charge mechanism applies; and
entrepreneurs, non-profit organizations and other legal persons on their intra-Community acquisitions.

section.p: Private persons may be deemed to be taxable persons with respect to acquisitions of new means of transport and, if they so elect, letting out of buildings and land.
The state and municipalities are taxable on their supplies of goods and services in connection with their business activities, but not in their capacity as public bodies.

The public health care, social welfare and rescue services will be reformed in Finland. The responsibility for organizing these services will be transferred from municipalities to well-being service counties with effect from 1 January 2023. The city of Helsinki as well as the Åland islands will organize their own health, social and rescue services. Well-being service counties shall have equal VAT treatment with the municipalities when providing supplies of goods or services or when buying those.

Registered entrepreneurs are subject to VAT on self-supply (i.e. the entrepreneur takes goods or services from his business for private use or uses them for purposes other than his taxable business). The self-supply of a service is, however, subject to VAT only if the entrepreneur has purchased the service from a third party or he provides a similar service to customers and if the service is rendered in connection with the entrepreneur’s taxable business. A de minimis rule applies to taxation of self-supply (section 22a of the AVL).

However, there are many exceptions to these general rules. For instance, if a non-resident entrepreneur supplying goods or services in Finland does not have a fixed establishment in Finland, it is normally the customer (if he is registered for VAT in Finland) who is responsible for paying VAT (reverse charge or reverse tax liability). Small businesses, i.e. businesses whose turnover does not exceed EUR 15,000 (EUR 10,000 before 2021), non-profit organizations, religious communities and disabled persons, subject to certain conditions, are exempt from VAT. For details on these exemptions, see section 13.8.

Small businesses, non-profit organizations, religious communities, disabled persons and landlords who rent out immovable property may, upon application, opt to be subject to VAT, if they carry on a business which, but for the exemption, would be taxable (sections 12 and 30 of the AVL). Although this renders their sales subject to VAT, they are able to deduct the input VAT charged on their purchases.

All entrepreneurs subject to VAT are registered with the tax offices. This registration requirement (as well as other obligations) also applies to non-resident entrepreneurs that have a fixed establishment in Finland or tax liability for other reasons (see section 13.4.).

section.title: Groups
section.p: Companies operating in the financial or insurance sector may register as one taxable person for VAT purposes if certain requirements regarding the ownership and economic, financial and administrative relationships are fulfilled. Companies may want to register as a group to avoid output VAT on the taxable transactions between them where one of the companies is not allowed to deduct the input VAT on a sale (section 13a of the AVL).

section.title: Taxable events
section.p: VAT is levied at all stages of the production and distribution chain on the basis of the value added to the goods and services at each stage. The supplier of goods and services is required to account for tax on all supplies made by him to his customers (output tax). However, he may deduct the tax charged on the supplies made to him by his suppliers (input tax) from the tax to be paid to the government. VAT is thus paid on the value added at each stage in the production and distribution chain. It is the ultimate consumer who bears the aggregate tax. As it is rolled over to the final consumer, VAT is not an element of cost for businesses in the production and distribution chain.

Only transactions carried out, or deemed to have been carried out, and services rendered, or deemed to have been rendered, within Finland are subject to VAT. Exportation of goods is zero rated. However, supplies to other EU Member States are subject to special rules. For instance, distance sales to a private person in another Member State may render the Finnish seller liable for VAT in that other Member State. Furthermore, sales to a taxable person in another EU Member State are exempt from Finnish VAT if the seller can prove that the goods were transported to the other Member State and he has indicated the VAT identification number of the buyer on the invoice. The import of goods is also subject to VAT. VAT is imposed, regardless of whether the customer is a registered entrepreneur or a private person. However, special rules apply with respect to the acquisition of goods from other EU Member States (intra-Community acquisition).

section.title: Supplies of goods and services
section.p: For VAT purposes, taxable goods include (section 17 of the AVL):

item.p: all tangible goods, unless specifically listed as non-taxable or exempt (see section 13.8.); and
electric power, gas, heating, refrigeration and similar energy commodities.

section.p: The sale and lease of immovable property are generally exempt, but there are exceptions. The sale of extractable soil resources is taxable. The lessor may opt to tax, providing the premises he is letting out are used by the tenant for business subject to VAT. Bills and coins used as means of payment are exempt. Trading in securities is exempt.

With effect from 1 January 2020, in accordance with the provisions of Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2018/1910), Finland has implemented harmonized rules for chain transactions (section 63c of the AVL). On 18 December 2019, the tax administration issued guidelines on chain transactions rules (Arvonlisäverotus EU-tavarakaupassa, VH/2863/00.01.00/2019). For the place of supply of goods in the case of chain transactions, see section 13.4.2.2.

All services are taxable, unless they are specifically exempt (see section 13.8.). Several types of services are subject to a reduced rate (see section 13.7.). Services include everything that can be sold or otherwise supplied in the course of business and which are not goods (section 17 of the AVL).

Supply is defined as a delivery of goods or performance of services for consideration, including the exchange of goods and services. A deemed supply is taxable and defined as the use of goods or services for purposes other than for activities subject to VAT (self-supply).

Where assets and inventory are sold as part of the sale of a business undertaking (transfer of a business as a going concern), the transfer is not treated as a supply for VAT purposes and the transferee is treated as a successor of the transferor (section 19c of the AVL).

topic.title: Importation
topic.p: Imported goods are subject to VAT, whether or not the importer is an entrepreneur registered for VAT. However, import of those goods which would have been exempt if sold in Finland, is exempt. Consequently, the import of, for example, certain types of sea-going vessels and aircraft, is exempt. In addition, the import of goods that originate from outside the European Union and are free from customs duty, is exempt. These include, for example, medicines for use in research, goods to be tested and goods imported for exhibitions.
A registered entrepreneur may deduct VAT paid on imports in the same manner and subject to the same conditions as VAT may be deducted on purchases made from local suppliers.

With effect from 1 March 1997, importation from the province of Åland to the mainland of Finland is a taxable import. Similarly, the import of goods from the mainland to Åland is a taxable import of goods to Åland. However, the supplies of newspapers and other periodicals that are published once a week or less frequently and are transported from Åland to the mainland of Finland are treated as domestic supplies of goods and are taxed accordingly for VAT purposes.

With effect from 1 January 2018, the tax administration administers the VAT paid by registered entrepreneurs on importation instead of the customs authorities (who continue to supervise importation and are responsible for criminal investigations). The customs authorities administer other importation than importation by registered entrepreneurs, e.g. importation by individuals.

With effect from 1 January 2018, Finland applies the postponed accounting system on importation. This implies that VAT may be reported and deducted in the VAT return of the tax period to which the importation relates (i.e. import VAT is not effectively paid because it is deductible as input VAT through the same return).

Under the One-Stop Shop (OSS) scheme, a distance sale of goods will also be deemed to take place in the European Union when the recipient of the goods is the importer (if the sale must be reported under the OSS scheme). This sale is taxed in Finland for VAT purposes if the transport of the goods ends in Finland.

topic.title: Intra-community acquisitions
topic.p: When an entrepreneur or a legal person, including registered associations, acquires goods from another EU Member State, the purchaser is liable to account for acquisition VAT in Finland. He must provide the seller with his VAT identification number. The VAT on intra-Community acquisitions is deductible under the same rules that apply to input VAT on local purchases.
Except for new means of transport, no Finnish VAT is due if the goods are purchased from another EU Member State and the purchaser is a private person.

section.title: Place of taxation
section.p: VAT shall be paid on intra-Community acquisitions, supplies or importations of goods, or on services rendered within the territory of Finland (section 1 of the AVL). Finland comprises the territory of Finland as defined in the legislation of the European Union and the Åland Islands.

section.title: Place of taxation of domestic events
Place of taxation of supplies of goods
section.p: The place of supply of goods is in Finland if the goods are located in the territory of Finland at the moment of the supply. When the goods are transported to the purchaser, the place of supply of goods is deemed to be in Finland if the goods are in Finland when the transportation begins. The place of supply of goods is in Finland also when the goods are outside the European Union at the moment transportation begins, provided that the supplier imports the goods to Finland for sale (section 63 of the AVL).

Where goods are deemed to be supplied within Finland and the supplier is not resident or has not opted for VAT in Finland, the purchaser is liable to VAT based on the reverse charge mechanism (section 9 of the AVL). This means that the liability to pay VAT is shifted to the purchaser. The purchaser may recover the same VAT, provided that the goods were acquired for such purposes as to give entitlement to input VAT recovery. VAT is not payable if the purchaser is the state of Finland. The foreign seller is, however, liable to VAT if the purchaser is another foreign company that does not have a fixed establishment in Finland and is not registered for VAT in Finland, or if the purchaser is a private person, or in cases of distance selling, or in cases of sale of passenger transportation services, or teaching, scientific services, cultural, entertainment, or sports events and other comparable services, and the services directly linked to these services.

The rules for distance sales changed with effect from 1 July 2021, when Finland adopted new rules based on the Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2017/2455) and on the Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2019/1995).

The OSS scheme regarding the sellers established outside the European Union and the equivalent scheme regarding the sellers established in the European Union covers also all the services other than telecommunications services, radio and TV broadcasting services and electronically supplied services sold to consumers. The OSS scheme is further expanded to also cover distance sales of goods within the Community regardless of the country of establishment of the distance seller.

Local distance sales thresholds determined by the Member States (including the Finnish threshold of EUR 35,000) were abolished with effect from 1 July 2021. The distance sale shall be taxed in Finland if the transport of the goods ends in Finland. To ease the administrative burden for small businesses that are established only in one Member State, the distance sales of goods within the European Union are taxed in the Member State from where the transport of goods begins, provided that the value of the telecommunications services, radio and TV broadcasting services and electronically supplied services supplied within the European Union and supplies of goods supplied within the European Union does not exceed EUR 10,000 in a calendar year. In Finland, when calculating this threshold, the value of telecommunications services, radio and TV broadcasting services and electronically supplied services is taken into account for the whole year of 2021 and the value of supplies of goods is taken into account only for the supplies provided after 1 July 2021.

Use of the OSS scheme is optional. This scheme applies to supplies of services and supplies of goods in business-to-consumer (B2C) situations, provided that the supplier does not have a domicile or a fixed establishment in the Member State of the consumer to whom the services or goods are sold.

The local reverse charge mechanism applies to supplies of metal waste and scrap if both the supplier and the customer are registered for VAT purposes in Finland. However, this does not apply if the customer or supplier is a private individual.

section.title: Place of taxation of services
section.p: With effect from 1 January 2010, the place of supply rules for services have been amended. This follows the provisions of Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2008/08). The main rule is that services supplied to businesses (business-to-business, B2B) are deemed to be rendered at the place where the customer is domiciled or has a fixed establishment. The reverse charge applies in the country of the customer.
The place of supply of services rendered to non-taxable persons (B2C) is the place where the service provider is domiciled or has a fixed establishment.
