Special rules apply to services connected with immovable property, transportation services and services connected thereto, work on movable goods, hiring of means of transport, cultural and entertainment services, restaurant services, travel agency services, certain intangible services, radio and television broadcasting services, electronic services, telecommunications services, and intermediary services.
Services connected with immovable property are deemed to be supplied in Finland if the immovable property is situated in Finland.

In B2C situations, cultural and entertainment services are deemed to be supplied in Finland if the activities are physically carried out in Finland. In B2B scenarios, the place-related rule continues to apply to admission to cultural and entertainment events. Other cultural and entertainment services supplied to businesses are deemed to be supplied in Finland if the customer’s fixed establishment to where the services are supplied or his domicile is situated in Finland.
The place of supply of restaurant transactions and catering services is where the services are physically rendered.

Where work on movable goods is supplied to a non-taxable person (B2C), the place of supply is in Finland if the work is physically performed in Finland. Where such work is supplied to a taxable person (B2B), the main rule applies.

In respect of intangible services, the main place-of-supply rule applies to taxable persons (B2B). Intangible services supplied to non-taxable persons (B2C) resident in the European Union are deemed to be supplied in Finland if the service provider is domiciled or has a fixed establishment in Finland. Intangible services rendered to non-taxable persons (B2C) resident outside the territory of the European Union are excluded from the scope of the general B2C place-of-supply rule. Correspondingly, the place of supply is outside Finland if the intangible services are supplied to the consumer’s fixed establishment or domicile outside the territory of the European Union.

The place of supply of telecommunications, radio and television broadcasting and electronic services (TBE services) is the same as for intangible services in B2B situations. With effect from 1 January 2015, the place of supply of TBE services in B2C situations has changed, in line with the requirements of Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2008/08). Accordingly, the place of supply of B2C TBE services is where the consumer is established. The service provider must, in principle, register for VAT purposes in each EU Member State in which final consumers are located. However, instead of such a registration, the taxable persons supplying TBE services were able to use a Mini One-Stop Shop (MOSS) scheme. With effect from 1 July 2021, the MOSS system was replaced by the One-Stop Shop (OSS) system, effectively expanding the prior system with the intra-Community distance sales of goods and services. The system applies to supplies of services and distance sales of goods within the European Union to consumers by businesses established or domiciled in the European Union (EU special scheme). The non-EU special scheme is available to businesses that are established outside of the European Union and supply services to consumers in the European Union. Both schemes are optional.

The place of supply of intermediary services rendered to non-taxable persons (B2C) is in Finland if the goods and services are supplied in Finland. If the intermediary services are supplied to taxable persons (B2B), the main place-of-supply rule applies.

Transport of goods on behalf of a non-taxable person (B2C) is deemed to be supplied in Finland if it is performed in Finland, or, in case of intra-Community transport, begins in Finland. The main place-of-supply rule applies to transport of goods on behalf of a taxable person (B2B).

In addition, certain rules apply to the hiring out of means of transport. For both taxable (B2B) and non-taxable persons (B2C), short-term hiring of means of transport (maximum period of 30 days for vehicles and 90 days for vessels) is deemed to be supplied at the place where the means of transport is actually put at the disposal of the customer. The same rule applies to long-term hiring of means of transport for taxable persons (B2B). The place of supply of long-term hiring of means of transport (other than pleasure boats) to non-taxable persons (B2C) is in Finland if the customer’s fixed establishment or domicile is in Finland. Long-term hiring of a pleasure boat is deemed to be rendered in Finland if the vessel is actually put at the disposal of the customer in Finland, where this service is actually provided by the supplier from his place of business or a fixed establishment situated in Finland.
The reverse charge mechanism applies in respect of construction services. The reverse charge rules are applicable when:

item.p: the service is a construction work, supply of staff for such work or an intermediary service related to construction;
the place of supply of the service is in Finland;
services are connected to real estate located in Finland; and
the customer renders services mentioned above on a regular basis.

section.p: Correspondingly, sub-contractors do not charge VAT to the main contractors. Instead, the main contractors charge VAT in a normal way to the final customers.
These rules also apply to foreign businesses supplying the above-mentioned services in Finland.

section.title: Place of taxation of cross-border events
Place of taxation of imports
section.p: The place of taxation of imports is Finland if the goods are in Finland when imported into the European Union, or if the customs arrangement ends when the goods are within Finland (section 86a of the AVL).

If the importer is not resident in Finland, the VAT paid on importation may be applied back from Finland as a refund provided that the importer does not have to register for VAT. The onward supply of goods in Finland is subject to the reverse charge mechanism if the purchaser is registered for VAT in Finland. Non-EU businesses may act as importers only by using an indirect representation (for example, a forwarding agent may act as an importer).

section.title: Place of taxation of intra-Community acquisitions
section.p: Intra-Community acquisition of goods is deemed to be in Finland if the goods to be transported to the purchaser are in Finland at the moment the transportation ends (section 63e of the AVL).

Intra-Community acquisition is also deemed to take place in Finland if the purchaser uses in the acquisition a VAT identification number obtained in Finland, and the transportation of goods began in another EU Member State, and the purchaser does not show that the intra-Community acquisition has been taxed, or he has reported the acquisition in the Member State in which the transportation of goods ended.

Triangulation occurs when three parties in three different EU Member States are involved in selling and purchasing the same goods. The goods are sent directly from the first supplier’s Member State to the one of the second purchaser of the goods. For example, A in Denmark sells goods to B in Sweden, who sells goods to C in Finland, and the goods are directly sent from Denmark to Finland, i.e. from A to C. In this example, B would, under the main rule, acquire the goods in Finland (the place where the transportation ends), and he would be required to register for VAT and at least report the acquisition in Finland. Certain simplification measures have been introduced within the European Union. According to these rules, an intermediate supplier (B) is not required to register for VAT purposes in Finland and fulfil the administrative formalities connected with the registration and reporting.

For the simplification to apply, certain formalities must be fulfilled. These formalities include that invoices are issued including certain information, and that the reporting is done correctly. For example, the invoice B issues must include B’s VAT identification number in Sweden and C’s VAT identification number in Finland. In addition, B (if in Finland) must include “triangulation” or another similar reference in the invoice. C must report the acquisition in Finland as an intra-Community acquisition, and B (if in Finland) must report the acquisition as a triangulation supply in the EC Sales List. There may be differences in the application of the triangulation rules in various EU Member States.

With effect from 1 January 2020, article 36a of VAT Directive (2006/112), as amended by Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2018/1910), harmonizing the rules on chain transactions has been transposed into domestic law. Implementation of the rules on chain transactions entails that in the case of chain transactions consisting of a series of supplies between various taxable persons established in different EU Member States, with one single transportation of goods between the first supplier and the last purchaser, the place of taxation can be referred to the “organizer of the transport”, if the organizer of the transport has provided the first supplier with the VAT identification number of the Member State from where the transport begins. The organizer of the transport is a supplier, other than the first supplier, who transports the goods or on whose behalf the goods are transported to the destination country. See also section 13.3.1.
The provisions regarding chain transactions do not affect the simplification rules regarding triangular transactions.

taxtopics.taxtopic: Time of Supply / Chargeability of VAT
Time of Supply / Chargeability of VAT

section.title: Time of taxation
section.p: VAT becomes payable at the time the goods are delivered or services rendered, or goods or services have been put into use. The liability to pay VAT on importation of goods arises when the goods are released from Customs supervision (sections 15 and 16 of the AVL). The sales are attributed to the month during which the liability to pay VAT has arisen.
For advance payments, the time of taxation is when the payments are made to the seller, to the seller’s account, or otherwise.

During the accounting period the supplier may also pay VAT based on the invoices issued. However, during the last month of the accounting period the supplier must pay VAT on all goods delivered or services rendered even though invoices have not yet been issued.

Cash accounting is available to farmers and other taxable persons who are not required to comply with the obligations under the KPL and have the right to make a financial statement on a payment basis.

With effect from 1 January 2017, optional cash accounting is also available to small businesses whose turnover does not exceed EUR 500,000 during an accounting year. The option only applies if the place of supply is in Finland. The optional cash accounting may not be applied to imports or exports of goods, intra-Community supplies of goods or cross-border supplies of services subject to the reverse charge. If a taxable person opts to apply cash accounting, he must apply it both to his supplies and to his purchases. The VAT liability for the cases where no payment is made for the supplies or purchases of goods or services may be deferred by a maximum of 12 months from the time of supply of the goods or the services.
With effect from 1 January 2018, the postponed accounting system applies as regards importation (see section 13.3.2.).
The Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2016/1065) has been transposed into the AVL with effect from 1 January 2019 (sections 18c, 18d and 73f of the AVL).

A voucher is defined as an instrument where there is an obligation to accept it as a consideration or a part consideration for a supply of goods or services and where the goods or services to be supplied or the identities of their potential suppliers are either indicated on the voucher itself or in related documentation such as the terms and conditions of use of such instrument.
The VAT treatment of the vouchers depends on whether they qualify as “single-purpose” vouchers or “multiple-purpose” vouchers.

A single-purpose voucher is a voucher where the place of supply of the goods or services to which the voucher relates, and the VAT due on those goods or services are known at the time of issuance of the voucher.
Multi-purpose voucher is defined negatively, i.e. as a voucher, other than a single-purpose voucher.
Single-purpose voucher is comparable to an advance payment for the goods or services purchased. VAT is due at the moment of payment for the voucher.
In the case of supply of multi-purpose vouchers, VAT is due at the moment the voucher is used for payment for the goods or services purchased.
A stamp is not considered a voucher.

With effect from 1 January 2020, in accordance with the provisions of Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2018/1910), Finland implemented harmonized call-off stock simplification rules (sections 18c and 18d of the AVL). The transfer by a taxable person of goods forming part of his business assets to Finland under call-off-stock arrangement will not be treated as a supply of goods for consideration. For the simplification to apply, the following conditions must be met:

item.p: goods are dispatched or transported by a taxable person (the seller), or by a third party on his behalf, to Finland with a view to those goods being supplied there, at a later stage and after arrival, to another taxable person (the buyer) who is entitled to take ownership of those goods from the stock based on the agreement between both taxable persons;
the seller has not established his business nor has a fixed establishment in Finland;

the taxable person to whom the goods are intended to be supplied (the buyer) has a valid VAT identification number in Finland and both his identity and the VAT identification number assigned to him by Finland are known to the taxable person referred to in item (2) above at the time when the dispatch or transport begins; and

the seller records the transfer of the goods in the register (section 209s of the AVL) and includes the identity of the buyer and the VAT identification number assigned to him by Finland in the recapitulative statement (section 162(2)(4) of the AVL).

section.p: When the conditions apply at the time of the transfer of the right to dispose of the goods as owner to the taxable person (purchaser in Finland), a supply of goods shall be deemed to be made by the seller and an intra-EU acquisition of goods shall be deemed to be made by the buyer provided that the goods are taken from the stock within 12 months. If the goods are not supplied within 12 months, a transfer shall be deemed to take place on the day following the expiry of the 12-months period.

The goods are deemed to be supplied before the 12-months period if the goods are supplied to a person other than the taxable person to whom the goods were initially meant to be supplied to or if the goods are dispatched or transported to a country other than Finland, as well as in the event of the destruction, loss or theft of the goods.

With effect from 1 January 2020, under the call-off stock arrangements, the supplier must indicate in the recapitulative statement the VAT number of the intended buyer. There is a special form for that purpose, which will be enclosed with the recapitulative statement.

section.title: Taxable amount
section.p: VAT is levied on the sales price of taxable goods and services, excluding the amount of the VAT itself. The taxable amount includes all surcharges. On the other hand, the entrepreneur may deduct, inter alia, bad debts (relating to receivables for which VAT has already been paid) and discounts, including discounts allowed to the client after delivery.

In the case of imported goods, VAT is levied on the value of goods for customs duty purposes, including customs duty and any other national tax or charge other than VAT (sections 88 to 93 of the AVL), including transport costs, regardless of whether the importer is a registered entrepreneur and whether the goods are intended for resale or are merely intended for private use. Consequently, the taxable amount includes, for example, packing, freight, loading, unloading and insurance expenses, regardless of whether these costs are included in the total price or are charged separately. The taxable amount of a standard computer programme includes both the value of the programme and the hard copy.
The taxable amount of goods which have been outside the European Union for repairs, completion or processing, is the value added abroad, including transport costs (sections 90 and 91 of the AVL).

For goods that are taken from the entrepreneur’s taxable business for the entrepreneur’s private use or that are taken to be used for purposes that do not allow VAT deduction, the taxable amount is the purchase price or market value, whichever is lower. In the case of self-manufactured goods, however, the tax is accounted for on the direct and indirect manufacturing costs. Similar principles apply to the self-supply of services (sections 74 and 75 of the AVL).

Special rules apply to supplies made below the market value between related parties (sections 73c, 73d and 73e of the AVL). The basis for taxation is the market value if the consideration is considerably lower than the market value, the seller and the purchaser are related, and the purchaser does not have full recovery of the input VAT. In this context, “related” refers to family relationships, ownership relationships, employment relationships, or where the purchaser has control over the seller.

section.title: Rates
section.p: The standard VAT rate is 24% (section 84 of the AVL).
A reduced rate of 10% applies to (section 85a of the AVL):

item.p: passenger transport services;
lodging (hotel) services;

amounts received by the National Broadcasting Company (Yleisradio Oy) from the TV and Radio Fund and amounts received by Ålands Radio and TV based on the television licence fees imposed by the Åland Islands self-governing area on inhabitants of Åland Islands;
entrance fees to commercial theatre, circus, music and dance performances, sports events, amusement parks, as well as to art exhibitions;
presentation of motion pictures;
services relating to physical exercise;
medicines and some qualifying pharmaceutical products;
books (except for books consisting mainly of advertisements, video content or music);
newspapers and periodicals subscribed to for a period of at least 1 month (except for newspapers and periodicals consisting mainly of advertisements, video content or music);

e-books, newspapers and periodicals in electronic format and single copies of printed magazines (from 1 July 2019). However, the reduced rate does not apply to e-publications consisting mainly of advertisements, video content or music;
works of art when the artist or his right owners that made the piece of art sell it or occasionally other entrepreneur than a taxable reseller; and
remuneration relating to copyright where received by an organization representing the copyright owners.

section.p: With effect from 1 April 2019, the performing artists and athletes may opt to apply VAT on their performances (generally, such performances are exempt from VAT). If they do so, the remuneration is subject to a reduced rate of 10%.
A reduced rate of 14% applies to the supply and import of foodstuff and animal feed (section 85 of the AVL). Restaurant services are subject to a reduced rate of 14%.

Until 31 December 2021, as part of the COVID-19 pandemic measures, supplies, intra-Community acquisitions and imports of goods used for testing, treating or preventing COVID-19 were zero rated, provided that such goods were supplied to public health care facilities, public social welfare organizations and state organizations, including state bodies, public bodies and other bodies governed by public law or by or on behalf of organizations approved by the competent authorities in the Member States (as defined in Commission Decision (EU) 2020/491) or to non-profit organizations (as defined in section 4 of the AVL) or to a body that supplies the goods without consideration to the above facilities or organizations.

Supplies, importation and intra-Community acquisitions of in vitro diagnostics medical devices for home testing for COVID-19 shall be treated as zero rated with effect from 1 January 2022 until 31 December 2022. The supplier is entitled to a refund of input VAT.

With effect from 1 January 2021, the importation and intra-Community acquisition of goods by the European Commission or by an agency or a body established under Union law where the European Commission or such an agency or body imports those goods in the execution of tasks conferred on it by the Union law in order to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic is exempt (except where the goods imported are used, either immediately or at a later date, for the purposes of onward supplies for consideration by the European Commission or such an agency or body). Also, the supplies of goods and services in response to the COVID-19 pandemic are exempt when supplied to the European Commission or to an agency or body established under the Union law. The input VAT relating to such supplies can be refunded.

section.title: Exemptions
section.p: There are a large number of exemptions from VAT and only those that are the most important for companies are discussed below.

In general, if the sale of certain goods is exempt from VAT, the import of such goods is also exempt. In addition, the import of certain goods which are free from customs duties, safety devices used by foreign airlines, and documents and forms, is not subject to VAT (section 94 of the AVL).
There are two main classes of VAT exemption:

item.p: those which preclude the deduction of input VAT by the entrepreneur carrying out the exempt transaction; and
those which result in the right to deduct the input VAT, e.g. export supplies (zero rating).

section.p: Output VAT is not charged on transactions involving goods and services that are exempt from VAT, and input VAT related to such supplies may not be claimed.
The following goods and services are exempt without right to input tax deduction:

item.p: the grant and transfer of the right to use immovable property or a dwelling (section 27 of the AVL). Note, however, that construction of and restoration work on a building, as well as real estate and apartment brokerages are taxable. The rental of hotel rooms, cottages and similar short-term accommodation is taxable (albeit at a reduced rate of 10%). The rental of space for temporary exhibitions, conferences and parking lots is also taxable;
health care and medical treatment (but not, for example, cosmetic care or services of a veterinary) (sections 34 and 35 of the AVL);

social welfare services (sections 37, 38, 38a and 38b of the AVL). With effect from 1 January 2019, the services are extended to include primary education and interpreting services that are provided based on the law or that are subsidized from the state budget and that are provided to persons that suffer from hearing, hearing and seeing or speaking disorders;
education (teaching), except if commercial or relating to leisure activities (entertainment and e.g. skiing schools) (sections 39 and 40 of the AVL);
financial and banking services, with some exceptions (e.g. hiring of safe deposit boxes, collection of debts and portfolio management are taxable) (sections 41, 42 and 43 of the AVL);
insurance services, including the services of insurance brokers (section 44 of the AVL);
cultural, sports and entertainment events, if organized by non-profit organizations (section 4 of the AVL);

author’s honoraria and fees for an artist’s or sportsman’s public performances, as well as copyrights (however, photos, books, tapes, records, etc. are taxable, as are industrial rights, e.g. patent rights) (section 45 of the AVL);
picking of berries and mushrooms, in general (section 59.1(6) of the AVL);
lottery tickets (however, winnings are subject to lottery tax) (section 59.1(2) of the AVL);

small businesses with an annual turnover not exceeding EUR 15,000 (EUR 10,000 before 2021), non-profit organizations and religious communities for other than business activities and blind persons are exempt, but they may opt to be subject to VAT (see section 13.2.1.); and
investment gold, unless the seller has opted for taxation.

section.p: The small-business threshold of EUR 15,000 (EUR 10,000 before 2021) does not apply to non-resident entrepreneurs without a fixed establishment in Finland (section 3.3 of the AVL). Non-profit organizations and religious communities are exempt only for other than commercial business activities referred to in the Income Tax Law.

With effect from 1 January 2020, Finland implemented article 138 of Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2018/1910), providing for harmonized rules for the substantive requirements of zero rating intra-Community supply of goods. Accordingly, for the supply to be zero rated, the goods must be transported from one EU Member State to the other, the buyer needs to have a valid VAT identification number in the Member State of arrival and the supplier needs to file a correct recapitulative statement regarding the supply.
Zero rating allows goods and services to be supplied free of VAT, but entitles the entrepreneur to deduct input VAT charged on his purchases made in connection to the zero-rated supplies.
The supply of the following is exempt with right to input tax deduction (sections 55 to 58 and 70 of the AVL):

item.p: printing work of membership publications (newsletters) published by non-profit organizations, if at least four issues are published annually;
vessels over 10 m in length and goods installed in these vessels, unless the vessel is intended to be used principally for pleasure or sporting purposes and the chartering of such vessels;
aircraft and their spare parts, if the buyer is engaged in commercial international traffic;
services relating to items (2) and (3) above; and
exportation of goods and services.

section.title: General
section.p: VAT liability is initially computed by applying the appropriate tax rate to the tax base of the goods and services supplied in each month (output tax). In general, the method applied is the accrual basis. Accordingly, VAT is payable or deductible for the goods that have been delivered and the services that have been rendered during the month. However, VAT becomes payable when the seller receives consideration if this takes place prior to the supply. The taxable person may deduct from the amount of output tax the VAT paid by him on his purchases and imports during the same month (input tax), as long as these are connected with his supply of taxable or zero-rated goods and services and exports and the input tax is clearly indicated on a purchase invoice.
To the extent the entrepreneur supplies goods or services which are exempt without input tax deduction, his right to a deduction of input tax is restricted on basis of the use.
No deduction is allowed for VAT paid with respect to, inter alia, the following (sections 114 and 115 of the AVL):

item.p: the dwelling, day nursery or place for leisure time activities of the entrepreneur or his employees;
travelling costs between home and work;
representation and customer entertainment; and

passenger cars, motorcycles, caravans, vessels intended to be used principally for pleasure or sporting purposes, and aircraft not exceeding 1,550 kg (however, the purchaser of a vehicle is entitled to a deduction if the vehicle is purchased for sale, rent, commercial passenger transport or use in a driving school, or, in the case of a passenger car, if the car is used exclusively for business purposes).

section.p: According to the special regime applicable to second-hand goods, the seller of second-hand goods may apply the “profit margin” method on sales of second-hand goods acquired in Finland or from other EU Member States. Under the profit margin method, VAT is payable on the profit margin, which is the difference between the sale price and the purchase price of the goods. The seller of second-hand goods may opt for the application of these rules. If the profit margin method is applied, the invoice of the sale must include a statement that the profit margin method is applied, and that the selling price does not include any refundable VAT. The profit margin method also applies to works of art and collectors’ items and antiques in certain situations (sections 79a to 79k of the AVL).

A non-resident entrepreneur who has no fixed establishment and no obligation to register due to his sales in Finland, and who has not registered voluntarily for VAT, but who has made taxable purchases from Finland for use in his business carried on abroad, may also apply for a VAT refund (refund according to EU VAT Refund Directive (2008/9) or the Thirteenth Directive (86/560)). However, no refund is granted to a non-resident entrepreneur engaged in intra-Community supplies or other zero-rated transactions in Finland if the non-resident entrepreneur has not registered for VAT purposes in Finland.
An excess of input VAT is refunded monthly, unless it is used to cover other taxes or if the taxable person wishes to retain it in the account for future use.

section.title: Partial deduction
section.p: Input VAT may be recovered if incurred for taxable purposes. If the same taxable person has taxable and non-taxable activities, only the input VAT of the goods and the services that are acquired for taxable activities may be recovered. If the goods or services are purchased for non-taxable activities, the input VAT may not be recovered. If goods or services purchased are used for both taxable and non-taxable purposes, partial recovery is available. How the deductible proportion is determined depends on the business in question: sometimes the basis of turnover derived from taxable and non-taxable transactions may be appropriate, at other times, it may be more appropriate to use other factors, such as the time employees spend on taxable and non-taxable activities, or the actual use of the goods and services concerned.

section.title: Adjustment of input tax deduction
section.p: Rules exist regarding adjustment for real estate. During an adjustment period of 10 years, the input VAT recovery of construction works (investments) must be adjusted based on use, and changes in use. If there is a reduction in use for taxable purposes, a repayment of the corresponding part of the input VAT recovery must be made. Conversely, if there is an increase, the taxable person may recover more input VAT.

The adjustment rules are applied only to construction works relating to new buildings or land, and to major renovation works of old buildings or land. Major renovation works are those that must be capitalized in the books of the person.

Input VAT need not be adjusted if the real estate is sold and remains in taxable use, unless otherwise agreed. The purchaser will then continue to adjust the input VAT recovery as a successor for the seller of the real estate.
For capital goods other than real estate, Finland does not apply a similar adjustment system.

section.title: Registration
section.p: Entrepreneurs engaged in a taxable activity must be registered as persons liable to VAT (section172 of the AVL). In the case of a non-resident entrepreneur, the competent tax office is the Tax Office of Etelä-Suomi (Etelä-Suomen yritysverokeskus), located in Helsinki.

section.title: Invoices
section.p: According to section 209a of the AVL, taxable persons are required to issue invoices when making taxable supplies of goods and services to another taxable person or to a non-taxable legal person. The requirements are based on Amending Directive 77/388/EEC with a view to simplifying, modernising and harmonising the conditions laid down for invoicing in respect of value added tax (2001/115). With effect from 1 January 2013, Finland transposed provisions of the Amending Directive to the VAT Directive (2010/45), which is aimed at promoting and further simplifying the VAT invoicing rules, into its national VAT legislation. Electronic invoicing is allowed if so agreed between the supplier and the customer.
Invoices must include the following information (section 209b of the AVL):

item.p: the date of issuance of the invoice;
a sequential number;
the VAT number of the supplier;
the customer’s VAT number where the reverse charge is applied and in the case of intra-Community supplies;
full names and addresses of the supplier and the customer;
the quantity and nature of the goods supplied or the extent and nature of the services rendered;
the date on which the goods or services were supplied or the date on which a prepayment was made;
the consideration, exclusive of VAT, per rate of VAT;
the rate of VAT chargeable;
the VAT payable in respect of the supply of the goods or services;
the term “self-billing”, if the customer issues the invoice;
the terms “margin scheme – travel agencies”, “margin scheme – works of art”, “margin scheme – second-hand goods” and “margin scheme – collectors’ items and antiques” when applicable; and
indications of any VAT exemption or reverse charge.

section.p: In addition, there are special requirements relating to supplies of second-hand goods, new means of transport, investment gold and some other situations.

Simplified arrangements are applied to invoices whose total amount is not more than EUR 400, and to invoices in the retail business and in the business where the customers are mostly private individuals. In addition, invoices issued in restaurants and in passenger transportation, and invoices obtained from parking meters, etc. are subject to less detailed requirements. The less detailed requirements include the following:

item.p: the date of issuance;
the supplier’s name and VAT number;
a description of the type of the goods (including quantity) and the services rendered;
the VAT due, specified per rate applicable, or alternatively the consideration, exclusive of VAT, per VAT rate.

section.title: Records
section.p: The VAT system is based, to a large extent, on self-assessment by registered entrepreneurs, but the tax offices control the returns to verify their accuracy and assure that the law is otherwise observed.
Imports are supervised by the Customs authorities (Tulli). With effect from 1 January 2018, the tax administration administers the imports made by registered entrepreneurs (see section 13.3.2.).

section.title: Returns and payment
section.p: With effect from 1 January 2017, an online tax reporting portal, OMAVERO, was launched to replace the former tax account system.
Small companies with turnover not exceeding EUR 100,000 may report and pay VAT on a quarterly basis. Small companies with turnover not exceeding EUR 30,000 may report and pay VAT on an annual basis.
Taxable persons must file VAT returns no later than on the 12th day of the 2nd month following the relevant tax period.
Neither annual VAT returns nor annual lists of suppliers and customers are required.

Corrections to previously filed VAT returns may be made by filing a revised return, which must include an explanation of the change. However, small mistakes (i.e. where the amount of tax due is up to EUR 500) may be corrected in the next return and taxable persons do not have to make the correction for the earlier tax period to which the mistake belongs. In such cases, penalties for late payment do not apply.
With effect from 1 January 2017, electronic filing of VAT returns is, in principle, compulsory. Filing on paper is permitted under special conditions.
VAT returns must be accompanied by payment of the VAT due.

Recapitulative statements (EC Sales Lists) relating to intra-Community supplies must be filed monthly (section 162e of the AVL). The statements are due on the 20th day of the month following the end of the reporting month. These statements must also include supplies of services to customers in other EU Member States that are liable to VAT based on the reverse charge mechanism. Services that are exempt from VAT in the country of taxation need not be reported. EC Sales Lists must be filed electronically. Filing on paper is allowed only under special conditions; for example, if electronic filing is not possible for technical reasons.

In addition, taxable persons must file statistical information (Intrastat returns) to the Customs authorities with regard to intra-Community trade. Taxable persons whose annual acquisitions of goods from other Member States exceed EUR 700,000, and whose annual supplies exceed EUR 700,000, must submit monthly Intrastat returns. Monthly returns must be filed 10 days after the end of the previous calendar month. With effect from 1 May 2017, Intrastat returns must be submitted in electronic format.

As part of the special COVID-19 pandemic tax measures, applicable under a law in force between 26 June 2020 and 31 August 2020, taxable persons could apply for refund of VAT remitted during the first quarter of 2020, within 30 days starting from 26 June 2020. The amounts refunded must be repaid to the tax authorities within 2 years with interest of 2.5%.

section.title: Interest and penalties
section.p: Taxable persons must pay interest charged on late payment of tax on their own initiative. The interest rate is 7% in 2022.

topic.title: Rules from 1 January 2017
topic.p: With effect from 1 January 2017, the revised rules regarding penalties apply. The penalty rules for self-assessed taxes (which include VAT) are defined in the OVML. On 16 January 2017, the tax administration issued guidance on the penalties (Seuraamusmaksut oma-aloitteisessa verotuksessa, A18/200/2017). The revised rules are applied for tax periods beginning on 1 January 2017 or after that date, or when negligence has taken place on 1 January 2017 or after that date. The rules applicable before 1 January 2017, are applied for the tax periods that began before 1 January 2017 or if the negligence took place before that date.

The penalty for late filing applies if a VAT return is not filed on the due date. The amount of the penalty is EUR 3 per day (including weekends and holidays) and is calculated during a maximum of 45 days of delay (the total amount being EUR 135). If the tax return is late for more than 45 days, the penalty of EUR 135 is increased by 2% of the amount of the VAT due.

The original return may be corrected without penalties during 45 days following the filing date. If the return is corrected after that, the penalty fee is 2% of the amount of the VAT paid after the due date.

Omission or late payment of VAT also attracts a penalty. The tax administration assesses the tax that is not paid on time and imposes the penalty, which is a percentage of the VAT assessed. The amount of the penalty depends on the negligence or on the nature of the mistake. As a main rule, the penalty is 10% of the VAT assessed. However, the penalty is between 15% and 50% if the negligence continues or the taxable person disregards his obligation to pay VAT.
In the case where a taxpayer fails to assess his VAT liability, the tax authorities estimate the VAT due and apply the penalty of 25% of that amount.

When the relevant VAT issue is ambiguous or unclear, the penalty is 3%. The penalty may also be 3% when it would be unreasonable to impose the regular 10% penalty, e.g. if the taxpayer's mistake is minor and unintentional.
The tax authorities impose a penalty of up to EUR 200 when the taxable person has not fulfilled his responsibility to report information that does not affect the amount of VAT.

A penalty for negligence may be imposed when the negligence does not relate to the reporting of VAT. The maximum amount of the penalty is EUR 5,000. The tax administration must ask the taxable person to fulfil his obligations prior to the imposition of the penalty.
Based on the guidance issued by the tax administration, the penalty fee for late filing of the EC Sales Lists is a maximum of EUR 200.

topic.title: Rules before 1 January 2017
topic.p: Before 2017, the following rules applied. The rules as discussed below are still applicable to issues related to the tax periods that ended in 2016 or earlier.

Fixed administrative fines may be imposed if the entrepreneur does not fulfil his VAT reporting obligations. Where an incorrect return or other incorrect information is submitted, a penalty may be imposed, generally up to 30% of the difference between the VAT assessed and the VAT paid on the basis of the incorrect information. However, for serious violations, the penalty may be 100% of the unpaid amount of VAT or EUR 15,000 (section 182 of the AVL). The taxpayer must be given an opportunity to be heard.

There is a special penalty for late filing. The amount of the penalty is based on 20% annual interest in respect of the amount not reported on time. The maximum amount of the penalty is either the amount of VAT not reported on time, or EUR 15,000. The penalty may be assessed even though there is no VAT to be paid. The tax authorities may decide not to assess the penalty in particular circumstances, and upon the request of the taxable person.
Omissions or inaccurate filing of EC Sales Lists may give rise to a penalty between EUR 80 and EUR 1,700.

A penalty for failure to file the Intrastat return ranges between EUR 10 and 2,500 (section 32 of the Customs Law, Tullilaki, TL). In practice, the EUR 100 penalty is generally applied to the initial failure to file the return; this amount is increased with EUR 100 per month in the case of further non-compliance.

section.title: Appeals
section.p: With effect from 1 January 2017, the Board of Adjustment for VAT matters was established. The Board of Adjustment reviews the decisions of the tax administration as a first instance authority. Its decisions may be appealed to the Administrative Court of Helsinki (Helsingin hallinto-oikeus) (sections 58-61 of the OVML). The decision of the Administrative Court may be appealed, subject to restrictions discussed in section 1.11.7., to the Supreme Administrative Court within 60 days (section 198 of the AVL).
Before that date, the entrepreneurs could appeal a decision of the tax office in a VAT matter within 3 years to the Administrative Court of Helsinki as a first instance authority.

section.title: Non-resident taxable persons
section.p: Non-resident entrepreneurs carrying on business from a fixed establishment in Finland are subject to VAT in the same manner as resident entrepreneurs. In the absence of a fixed establishment, the buyer of the goods or services supplied in Finland is, in general, responsible for VAT (unless he is also a non-resident and the non-resident seller has not voluntarily registered for VAT), regardless of whether the buyer carries on a business (reverse charge). The reverse charge mechanism does not apply to passenger transport, educational, entertainment or scientific services in Finland, and it may not be used if the customer is a private individual.

section.title: Registration
section.p: Non-resident entrepreneurs, i.e. entrepreneurs who do not reside in Finland and who have a fixed establishment in Finland, are subject to VAT, liable for registration and entitled to a deduction for input tax according to the same principles that apply to resident entrepreneurs.

The Finnish VAT legislation does not provide a definition of “fixed establishment”. Taxpayers must take into account the definition included in Regulation laying down implementing measures for Directive 2006/112/EC on the common system of value added tax (282/2011), which is legally binding. A fixed establishment is any establishment characterized by a sufficient degree of permanence and a suitable structure in terms of human and technical resources to enable it to receive and use the services supplied to it for its own needs (article 11 of the Regulation). The leasing of movable or immovable property or intangible rights does not, as such, constitute a fixed establishment.

If a non-resident entrepreneur is engaged in the commercial supply of taxable goods or services in Finland, but does not have a fixed establishment in Finland (and has not applied voluntarily for a taxable status), the buyer – and not the non-resident seller – is liable for VAT (reverse charge; section 9 of the AVL). If the Finnish state is the buyer, neither the seller nor the buyer is, however, liable for VAT, and no VAT is due.
Furthermore, the buyer is not liable for VAT if (sections 9 and 67.1 of the AVL):

item.p: the buyer is a private individual (a private individual is, however, liable for VAT on the purchase of a new vehicle from another EU Member State);
the services supplied are teaching, scientific services or services relating to cultural, entertainment, sports or other similar events in Finland;
passenger transport services are involved; or
the buyer is also a non-resident who does not have a fixed establishment in Finland and who is not registered voluntarily for VAT in Finland.

section.p: In these cases, the VAT liability is not reversed. The non-resident supplier is liable for VAT and must register even though he does not have a fixed establishment in Finland (section 9 of the AVL).

A non-resident entrepreneur engaged in intra-Community acquisitions in Finland must register as a non-resident entrepreneur for reporting purposes which is a simplified VAT registration. Because the liability to file VAT returns on these acquisitions does not mean VAT liability, reverse charge applies. If the non-resident entrepreneur also makes zero-rated supplies in Finland, he should register for VAT purposes in Finland.

A non-resident entrepreneur who carries out taxable activities in Finland, but does not have a fixed establishment in Finland or obligation to register, may voluntarily register for VAT purposes. Taxable persons established in an EU Member State are not required to appoint a tax representative, following the law change based on the judgement of the European Court of Justice of 15 June 2006 in the case Commission v. Finland (C-249/05). Other taxable persons are required to appoint a resident tax representative approved by the tax office. The representative is responsible for maintaining appropriate accounts for the business in Finland, but is not liable for the tax itself.

Landlords who rent out premises to entrepreneurs may opt for VAT registration on their leasing activities, provided that the tenants use the premises for their taxable business purposes which entitle to VAT recovery. If the landlord is not registered for renting out immovable property or other premises, he may not charge VAT on the rents and may not recover input VAT.

With effect from 1 July 2021, the OSS scheme applies to registering, reporting and paying the VAT for the distance sales of goods imported from third countries in consignments of an intrinsic value not exceeding EUR 150. The OSS scheme does not apply to goods that are subject to excise tax. Use of the OSS scheme is optional.

section.title: Returns and payment
section.p: Non-residents submit monthly returns under a general rule.

When using the OSS scheme, the importation of goods is exempt and the seller pays the VAT to the tax authorities on a monthly basis. If the taxable person is established outside of the European Union, the taxable person must choose an intermediary who is liable to pay VAT and who fulfills all the responsibilities under the OSS scheme in the name of the taxable person. If the distance seller does not use the OSS scheme for importation of goods, the transporting company that presents the goods to the customs authorities on behalf of the recipient of the goods may report and pay the VAT.

section.title: VAT refunds
section.p: If the non-resident entrepreneur does not have a fixed establishment in Finland or any other obligation to register, and has not voluntarily registered for VAT, he may not deduct input VAT relating to his purchases from output VAT payable on his supplies in Finland. Therefore, he may be entitled to a VAT refund on goods or services purchased in Finland and used in his business, provided that the business, if it was carried out in Finland, would be taxable or exempt with the right to deduct input tax (section 122 of the AVL).

The VAT refund is subject to certain conditions and restrictions (sections 123 to 126 of the AVL). An application must be filed with the Tax Office of Etelä-Suomi (Etelä-Suomen yritysverokeskus), located in Helsinki, within 6 months (for non-EU companies) or 9 months (for EU companies), from the end of the calendar year in question. However, no refund is allowed for VAT paid with respect to the purchases which are not deductible according to sections 114 and 115 of the AVL (see section 13.9.1.).

EU companies must file their refund applications electronically through the portal on the website of the VAT authorities of their Member State of establishment. The VAT authorities of the Member State of establishment forward the refund application to the refund office in Finland, which processes the application and makes the refund. The VAT authorities must decide on the application within 4 months, unless additional information is requested from the applicant.
Non-EU companies must file their refund applications in paper format directly with the refund office.

section.title: VAT representatives
section.p: Finland does not require a VAT representative for persons from other EU Member States that will register for VAT in Finland without being established in Finland. A VAT representative is required for non-EU persons if the foreigner does not have a domicile or fixed establishment in another EU Member State, or in a state with which Finland has an arrangement about mutual assistance comparable to the Mutual Assistance Directive (for the Recovery of Claims) (76/308). The tax authorities may also require a guarantee for the payment of VAT.

The VAT representative must be Finland-domiciled, and accepted by the VAT authorities. The VAT representative is not responsible for the payment of VAT, but for fulfilling the administrative obligations.

section.title: Capital duty
section.p: No capital duty is imposed.

section.title: Formation and expansion of capital
section.p: Contributions in cash on the formation of capital do not give rise to any duties. If immovable property is transferred to a company, the document effecting such a transfer is subject to a transfer tax (see section 14.2.). Movable property, other than shares, is free from transfer tax if transferred separately from immovable property. If shares are transferred to a company, the document effecting such transfer is subject to a transfer tax (see section 14.2.2.).

section.title: Issue of securities, debentures and loan agreements
section.p: There are no taxes imposed upon the issue of shares or debentures or other loan agreements to be subscribed by the public.

section.title: Capitalization of reserves (stock dividends)
section.p: There are no taxes imposed on the capitalization of reserves. Stock dividends may be distributed to shareholders free of tax.

section.title: Purchase of a company
section.p: Generally, a transfer tax is imposed on the purchase of shares in an existing company (see section 14.2.2.).

section.title: Purchase of an existing business
section.p: The transfer of assets other than immovable property (see section 14.2.1.) is generally free of transfer tax.

Value added tax (see section 11.) is levied on the part of the purchase price allocated to inventory and, in general, to machines and equipment used in industrial production, but the acquiring company is entitled to credit this tax against VAT payable on its sales. If the assets of an entire business are acquired, VAT is not chargeable, provided that the purchaser continues to use the assets in a business that is subject to VAT and for purposes that entitle the purchaser to the recovery of the input VAT.

section.title: Immovable property
section.p: Subject to certain exceptions, a property transfer tax is payable by the transferee (purchaser) on the deeds for the transfer of immovable property. The transfer of a leasehold interest in immovable property is taxed as a transfer of immovable property.

If movable property is transferred together with immovable property, a transfer tax is imposed on the entire, aggregate purchase price, unless the transfer document indicates the part of the purchase price which relates to the movable property.
The rate of this tax is 4% of the transfer price.
The transfer of immovable property is not subject to VAT.

section.title: Shares, bonds and other securities
section.p: The transfer of shares in Finnish companies, other than in housing and real estate companies, and other domestic securities is subject to a transfer tax of 1.6% of the sales price, but only if the transfer is not made through the stock exchange (sections 15, 15a and 20 of the VSVL). The transfer of shares in Finnish housing or real estate companies, as defined, or in companies the activity of which in practice is directly or indirectly owning or controlling real property (e.g. a holding company), is subject to transfer tax of 2% of the sales price (if the transfer is made on or after 1 March 2013). Even though the parties may have agreed which party pays the tax to the tax office, the tax may be collected from the purchaser. Only if the purchaser is non-resident in Finland, is the seller responsible for collecting the transfer tax from the purchaser and for paying it to the tax office.

No transfer tax is due if shares of a foreign company are sold or if both the seller and the purchaser are non-residents. However, this exemption does not apply if one of the parties to the transfer is a Finnish branch of a foreign bank or a foreign investment company (section 16 of the VSVL). Transfer tax is always payable on transfers between non-residents if the transferred shares are shares in a Finnish housing or real estate company, as defined, or in companies the activity of which in practice is directly or indirectly owning or controlling real property (e.g. a holding company).
Furthermore, in addition to the sales price, the transfer tax base includes also:

item.p: any payment which is a condition for the sale and which the purchaser makes to a third party; and
any payment obligation which the purchaser has taken over from the seller, if the settlement of the payment obligation occurs for the benefit of the seller.

section.p: In the case of transfers of shares in housing or real estate companies, the tax base includes any loans the company had taken up (limited to the part of the loans attributable to the transferred shares).

section.title: Stamp duty
section.p: Stamp duties levied in the past on various documents, permits and judgments issued by authorities have widely been replaced by cost-based fees. In the case of the transfer of immovable property and shares, etc., the transfer tax has replaced the stamp duty (see sections 14.2.1. and 14.2.2., respectively).

section.title: Customs duty
section.p: Customs law includes legal and administrative provisions that govern cross-border movement of goods. In the European Union, customs law is harmonized and applies only to movements of goods between the European Union and third countries. Customs duties, as well as other indirect taxes (e.g. VAT), are imposed on the import of goods into the EU Customs Union.

The EU Customs Union consists of the EU Member States, as well as the areas of Akrotiri and Dhekelia (in Cyprus) and Monaco (in France). Until 31 December 2020, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man and the United Kingdom were also part of the EU Customs Union. After that date, due to the United Kingdom’s full departure from the European Union, the movement of goods between these jurisdictions and the European Union is governed by customs procedures and formalities. In general, EU customs rules and facilitations continue to apply to goods entering and leaving Northern Ireland.
Andorra, San Marino and Turkey have separate customs agreements with the European Union.

The basis for calculating the customs duty is the customs value, which is generally the sum of the price paid for the goods and any related insurance and shipping costs. A percentage (tariff), which depends on the type and origin of the good being imported, is then applied to the customs value to determine the customs duty payable. The applicable tariff can be found in the integrated customs tariff database of the European Union (TARIC), which has its legal basis in the Regulation on the tariff and statistical nomenclature and on the Common Customs Tariff (87/2658). For more on customs duty valuation, see below.

EU customs legislation comprises the Union Customs Code (2013/952), the Regulation on the tariff and statistical nomenclature and on the Common Customs Tariff (87/2658), the Regulation Setting Up a Community System of Reliefs from Customs Duty (2009/1186) and various international agreements. The Union Customs Code (2013/952), supplemented by the Union Customs Code Delegated Act (2015/2446) and the Union Customs Code Implementing Act (2015/2447), replaced the Community Customs Code (92/2913) with effect from 1 May 2016. Some transitional arrangements still apply and are included in the Union Customs Code Transitional Delegated Act (2016/341) and the Union Customs Code Work Programme (2019/2151).

A trader importing goods into the European Union must register with the EU customs authorities and obtain an Economic Operators Registration and Identification (EORI) number. A trader established in the European Union must register in the EU Member State of establishment. Third-country traders are required to request an EORI number in the EU Member State where they intend to first file an entry summary declaration. The EORI number is valid for customs purposes throughout the European Union and must be used in the communication with the customs authorities. A single EORI number across the European Union is efficient for economic operators and customs authorities, but also for statistical and security purposes.

Importation of goods from outside the European Union constitutes a taxable transaction for customs duty purposes. The establishment of customs duties takes into account three factors: (i) the customs value of the goods; (ii) the applicable customs tariff; and (iii) the origin of the goods. Customs duties are calculated by applying the customs tariff to the customs value. The customs value of imported goods is based on the transaction value method, which is the price actually paid or payable for the goods when sold for export to the EU customs territory. The transaction value must be increased by certain expenses (e.g. cost of transport, insurance of the imported goods, loading and handling charges associated with the transport of the imported goods to the place of introduction into the EU customs territory and, under certain conditions, royalties and licence fees), and is reduced by certain deductions. If the transaction value cannot be determined, alternative methods must be applied in order to establish the customs value, namely (in order): the value of identical goods, the value of similar goods, the deductive value, the computed value and the fall-back value method. Each of these methods may be used, but only where the previous method is inadequate for purposes of determining the customs value (i.e. the deductive value method may only be used if the value of similar goods method is not adequate).

The person liable for import duties is the person who files the customs declaration or on whose behalf the declaration is filed by a representative. The declarant (or representative) must be established in the EU customs territory. Customs law permits both direct and indirect representation. Where several persons are liable for one customs debt, they are jointly and severally liable for that amount.

There are two main payment schemes for customs duties: immediate payment and deferred payment. In general, import duties must be paid within the period prescribed by the customs authorities, which may not exceed 10 days following notification to the debtor of the customs debt. The obligation to pay import duties may be deferred for a 30-day period upon request if certain conditions are met.

The Union Customs Code (2013/952) provides for three customs procedures: (i) release for free circulation, (ii) special procedures and (iii) export. Special procedures are simplification measures allowing traders to benefit from the suspension or lower rate of customs duties and include four categories: (i) transit (external and internal), (ii) storage (customs warehousing and free zones), (iii) processing (inward and outward processing) and (iv) specific use (end-use and temporary admission).

Regarding transit, under the external transit procedure, non-EU goods may be moved from one point to another within the EU customs territory without being subject to import duties or commercial policy measures. Under the internal transit procedure, EU goods may be moved from one point to another within the EU customs territory and pass through a country or territory outside that customs territory, without any change in their customs status.

As for the storage procedure, customs warehousing allows the storage of non-EU goods without subjecting them to import duties or other commercial policy measures. Goods may be stored in public and private warehouses. Public warehouses are available for use by any person, whereas private warehouses are reserved for use by persons authorized to operate the warehouse.

Under the inward processing procedure, non-EU goods may be used in the EU customs territory in one or more processing operations without being subject to import duties or other commercial policy measures. The outward processing procedure allows EU goods to be temporarily exported from the EU customs territory in order to undergo processing operations. The processed products resulting from those goods may be released for free circulation with total or partial relief from customs duties.

Lastly, under the temporary admission procedure, non-EU goods intended for re-export may be subject to specific use in the EU customs territory, with total or partial relief from import duty. Under the end-use procedure, goods may be released for free circulation under a duty exemption or at a reduced rate of duty on account of their specific use.

Companies having the status of Authorized Economic Operator (AEO), as provided under the Union Customs Code (2013/952), are able to take advantage of customs simplifications and/or benefit from facilitations relating to security and safety. They are also given a more favourable treatment in respect of customs controls, such as fewer physical and document-based controls.

section.title: Excise duty
section.p: Excise duties are levied on various commodities, such as tobacco, alcohol, beer, electricity and fuels. Excise duties on tobacco, alcohol, electricity and fuels are levied even if the goods originate in the European Union. The excise duties are generally based on quantities delivered for consumption or on quantities imported.
Excise duties paid are refunded upon application if the commodities are exported.

section.title: Insurance premium tax
section.p: Insurance premiums are, in general, subject to an insurance premium tax (vakuutusmaksuvero; försäkringspremieskatt) of 24% of the premium (excluding the tax) if the property insured is situated in Finland.

section.title: Motor vehicle taxes
section.p: Passenger cars, vans and motorcycles are subject to a car tax (autovero) when they are registered or brought into use for the first time. The amount of car tax depends on the general retail sales price of the vehicle on the Finnish market and the carbon dioxide emissions.

In addition, there is also a tax on vehicles that are in use in Finland (ajoneuvovero). The tax on the vehicles in use consists of (i) a basic tax; and (ii) tax on driving power (käyttövoimavero). The amount of the basic tax depends on the weight of the vehicle and on the carbon dioxide emissions. Tax on driving power applies to vehicles other than those powered by gas (e.g. it applies to those vehicles powered by diesel, electricity, etc.). The amount of the tax on driving power varies depending on the type of power used (diesel, electricity, bioethanol or a combination thereof), the number of days the vehicle is used, the type of vehicle (personal car, caravan, van, lorry, etc.) and the weight of the vehicle.

section.title: Environmental taxes
section.p: Fuel tax (polttoainevero; bränsleaccis) is levied, in addition to VAT, on liquid fuels used for transportation at rates which are subject to frequent revision.
